user_text: Cool, hip and dimly lit. Such interesting offerings and unconventional ingredients. Fancy some foie gras with chocolate sauce? What about some uni with raw beef? Each bite is a SURPRISE. The place to BE for quality meats, stellar appetizers and bomb dessert. WHAT TO ORDER:Appetizers1) raw beef with uni - super creamy and indulgent. Haven't seen this dish being offered anywhere else!2) foiegras meatball with chocolate sauce - it comes in a hot skillet, wafting aromas of chocolate with fatty foie gras. Omg. Meats1) harami skirt steak - salt n pepper2) kalbi - marinated3) in between rib meat - charrs nicely with a little bit a chewYou must try cooking the meat in butter and garlic.....!!Dessert-1) soft serve vanilla - the mochi (rice dumpling) is SO good.

Came here for midnight ramen with my girlfriend for our anniversary - was really excited by the prospect of eating my favorite food at midnight! We had Takashi's Original Ramen ($16) and Grandma's Spicy Ramen ($17) and the beef broth was really unique - extraordinarily rich, and you could really taste the beefiness. Usually I prefer my ramen spicy, but I found the spicy paste a bit overwhelming in flavor and saltiness and you lost some of the nuances of the original broth, which was disappointing - I'd recommend maybe only using half (when they serve the bowl, they put the paste on top and you mix it in yourself). After finishing my bowl of spicy ramen, I became extremely thirsty and drank like a gallon of water at home. For Kobe beef, I didn't think the meat was as tender as it could have been. The noodles were decent, but the best thing was actually the crispy intestine cracklings. Overall, it's a fun experience and the food is good, but definitely not the best ramen I've had.

We went to Takashi this past Sunday. Because we only had 3 people and they don't accept reservation for group of 1-3 people, we've decided to go there before their opening to make sure we can get in. We arrived around 4:45pm and were the first in the line (so lucky!)Since it is our first time there, we ordered all the favorites from our yelpers.Niu-Uni: A MUST. The beef was first grade and the uni was very fresh. The seaweed and leaf were not just for decoration but contributed to the nice flavor instead.Yooke: personally, I think it is the best dish we had in the entire meal. The seasoning is right, the beef is fresh, and the egg made the meat tender and whole the flavor together. Even our son ate a lot of it.Steamed beef shank bun: we didn't like it. The shank was too dry and tasted kind of bland. We understand that they would need to have at least one dish for kids but it was just not working for us.US Kobe Kalbi: it is our favorite meat for the grill. It was tender, juicy and just melt in your mouth. We ended up getting a second order.Filet mignon with garlic butter dip: we are normally not a filet mignon fan as we prefer fatty/juicy/more flavor cuts, but this dish did not disappoint. By following their instruction, the filet mignon was actually quite juicy! I also love their garlic butter dip. We kept it for the whole meal.Thick tongue: my husband has been looking for thick cut beef tongue in NYC for a long time and was glad to find it here. It is always our preference to have thick cut beef tongue over the thin ones as you can enjoy the texture and flavor.Harami: this was our less favorite dish for the grill. The meat was too chewy for our taste and the marinate was not helping - the garlic sauce didn't go well with the meat for some reason.We gave the restaurant a 4 Star because of the Shank Bun and Harami, but I can see we go back to try other more adventurous dishes!!

I had a huge craving for daechang, so I searched on Yelp and came upon this restaurant. We had the following:niku-uni/chuck flat topped with uni***grilled tetchan/daechang, mino, and akasen***and yooke//thinly sliced chuck eye tartare topped with a raw quail egg yolk, seaweed, and lemon***All were delicious and yakiniku (grilled meat) items were well-cooked. This is one of my favorite restaurants in NYC and I'd highly recommend coming here if you're visiting NY.

Disappointed with their late night ramen. Many reviews claimed it was the best ramen they had. I still prefer Totto and Ipuddo.Why? The broth was way too garlicky and after mixing in the spicy paste, it just tasted like the paste, very one dimensional. Their Grandma's spicy ramen only comes with a small piece of beef, which was on the bland side as well.Now that I've knocked them off my ramen list, I know I won't be back.

So. Delicious. This place has turned me from a Kbbq fan to a Jbbq fan!!!Definitely order the filet mignon and the Kobe skirt steak. I would go back just for these two alone. We also got the uni and beef appetizer which was yummy. As well as the tartare. The Kobe ribeye was good too but overshadowed by the rest in my opinion. The atmosphere was fun and casual without feeling sloppy. Would absolutely return. I'd be interested in coming to try the Midnight Ramen too! (:

The quality of the meat is top notch here. Takashi is one of the best yakiniku restaurants I've been to outside of Japan. They don't accept reservations for small parties less than 4 people so we went at 5:30 p.m. to line up before they opened. There was probably 4 parties ahead of us. The restaurant is pretty small so it's best to go early. We came once on a Saturday night around 7:30 p.m. and they told us the wait was 2-3 hours. We ordered 2 appetizers and 3 meat dishes to share between the 2 of us and we were pretty full after that. We could have eaten more but didn't want to push our limits. Yooke- a dish that's often offered in Japanese yakiniku restaurants. It's beef tartare with a raw egg on top. Loved it!Niku Uni- this was by far my fav dish of the night. It's beef sashimi topped with uni on shiso and seaweed. Best combination ever! But then again uni is one of my fav things in the world. Both the beef and uni were really fresh.

You got a fair amount of money, want a new bbq experience, and lots of flavors? Then give Takashi a shot! If you're a foodie (or at least opened to trying something new), try to book the cow experience menu a week or two ahead of time. I learned that sweetbread is delicious. Portions are small. Quality is high. Presentation of food is good. Decor is cozy and intimate. This is not a place for you to enjoy the standard BBQ. Would recommend coming for special occasions, lest your wallet get drained quick.

Expect to spend a lot of $$$ for high quality of meat! Its been so long that I want to try out this place! Finally me and my bf had a chance to go and we waited about 5 minutes to get a table. The place is not that big and it looks simple and cute inside. I got raspberry soju martini to try their drinks and honestly I didn't really like it. Its too sweet with alcohol. I expect some more flavor in it. For appetizer we got the niku-uni- chuck flap with leaves of seaweed, uni and wasabi. It was good and different. You taste the strong leaves and uni. 4 pieces for 2 people is good. For bbq we got 3 types, kalbi, harami and misuji. Everything was really good and perfect and the serving is small and I eat a lot, so for me and my bf we eat it so fast. Good thing I eat a lot of rice too or else I'll still be hungry and need to order more meat. Its really the best quality of meat so no regret. Its very different from any usual kbbq places. I'm glad to finally try it and I'll save this place for any special occasion.

Super unique bbq restaurant. I came here for my dad's birthday and didn't realize what I was walking into. The have everything that is NOT normal, like intestines, brains, etc. Pretty crazy. My boyfriend wasn't a fan but I thought it was very good, I love trying different foods and this was definitely something intriguing. I ordered the cow's brains, it came out in a tube, and you ate it with some crackers. We also ordered raw wagyu with a piece of leaf forgot what the leaf was called but, super flavorful. We ordered a bunch of other things to bbq, everything was super unique. Would definitely recommend if you consider yourself a food adventurer. They also have midnight ramen, which is pretty interesting, i haven't been but i heard good things about it!

WORTH. THE. WAIT,After not being able to get in our first time in NYC (they only allow reservations for parties 4 or more), my friend and I made a point to get here hella early to grab a seat. Â We got there at 5pm on Thursday and were the first people in line, so needless to say, we were stoked! We ordered three kinds of meat: the Kobe Kalbi, Beef Belly, and the Super-tender Filet Mignon Steak with Garlic Butter Dip. We got both the Kalbi and the Belly marinated in Takashi sauce and it was amazing! I prefer my meat medium-rare to raw plus, so 30 seconds on each side made each piece perfect. Â Such tender meat! Â We ate several plates worth each! Â The star of the meal was the Filet Mignon steak though. We ordered it based on the waiter's recommendation and it was one of the most delicious steaks I have eaten. It comes with a metal pan full of butter and crushed garlic cloves, which you heat on the grill with the meat.  First, you sear the steak bits on the grill, then you finish by cooking them in the butter sauce. It is heavenly! As a lover of garlic, this was everything I could have wanted from steak in garlic butter sauce. Plus, once you finish cooking the steak, you can enjoy the caramelized garlic bits.Overall, I spent $100 on dinner and loved every bit of it! Couldn't recommend this place more!

LOVE LOVE LOVE the midnight ramen. I've gone twice already and I would go back for more. I'm super picky about my ramen and there has not been a place that I love except for this place. I was told to have a drink of sake before the meat and then again after just to taste the difference. There's a completely different taste for both! We ordered the Masumi Okuden Kantsukuri Sake. Give it a try.I have also tried the regular bbq for dinner and it was also very delicious. Â The popular dish is definitely the kobe with uni on top. It just melted in my mouth. I ordered the bbq also which was super yummy.

Holy mother of god the midnight ramen at Takashi is off the charts!!!!!Grandma's Spicy Ramen with Foie Gras: At a hefty ~$36, you can get a bowl of jaw-dropping, lip-smacking, finger-licking beef ramen with melt-in-your-mouth beef belly, crispy intestines, soft boiled egg, and foie gras that you'll be dreaming about for weeks.I know eating late night foods is not healthy for our bodies, but it seems like mental health trumps physical health this time! I am SO happy I can die with no regrets. Definitely the best bowl of ramen in town!Here's some actual useful insights post-rant:Call beforehand to make a reservation as they can only seat ~20 people at a time; there are usually two waves of customers at 12am and 1amThe broth surprisingly is not the usual salt heavy soup bases you get at other ramen placesIf you can take spicy, go for the Grandma - you won't regret it :)

Takashi is owned by Chef Takashi, a 4th generation Korean immigrant, born in Osaka. Â The restaurant is all about the beef and offers choice cuts of Premium Japanese and American Angus for a yakiniku or a horumon dinner. Â They're only opened for dinners, but we came here for their late-night ramen!Just note that this late-night ramen experience is only held on Fridays and Saturdays, with a 12 AM midnight and a 1 AM seating (technically, it's Saturday morning, 12 AM/1 AM, and Sunday morning 12 AM/1 AM). Â The ramen is made with a 24-hour beef broth, and comes with custom-made noodles, a 20-spiced red paste (Takashi's grandma's receipt), US Kobe braised beef belly (SO SO SO GOOD - super tender and juicy, this had an unbelievable taste to it; it literally melts in your mouth!), crispy small beef intestines (kasu), and half of a soft-boiled egg (organic).We had the Grandma's Spicy Ramen, with the spicy paste on the side, and foregoing any additional toppings (there's foie gras!). Â The beef broth was definitely different - a little greasy and can be an issue for those with sensitive stomachs. Â However, the taste was pretty good! Â The noodles were thin and were okay; the intestines were forgettable, but I can see how some may like this for the added crispy texture (which stays crispy for quite some time!). Â The paste added some spice to it, and I thought it'd be similar to kimchi paste; however, the ramen already came spiced up, and the side of the paste requested was not needed. Â I loved the marinated boiled egg, as the yolk was perfect and creamy. Â The star of the show was the braised beef belly, as it had a perfect amount of fat to it - I'd definitely add more of these babies the next time!!!The good thing is is that Takashi does take reservations in advance, both via phone or via email. Â However, the restaurant is set-up as a communal style, so if you're a single- or a party of 2, you will be seated next to a group of 3 or a couple. Â Service was friendly, but slightly slow in getting our refills and the check. Â Great experience, and I'd love to come back for their yakiniku experience, because this place seems to know their beef!+US Kobe braised beef belly!!! MMMM+late-night ramen 12 AM and 1 AM on Fridays and Saturdays+reservations accepted+dinners only

Oh hell yeah.After I saw an insta of uni on wagyu on shiso on seaweed I knew I had to have it. The reservation was easy to make through Yelp and we were seated promptly once we got there. The uni/wagyu/shiso/seaweed dish was $26 for four pieces which I find to be a very reasonable price. We ended up ordering two and it was everything I dreamed it would be!What I didn't know is that takashi also has tons of grilled meats as well. I definitely felt a little bad about bringing a vegetarian friend with our group of 4...just a little bad =P We tried the US kobe kalbi, the beef belly and the tongue. The kobe kalbi was 100% our favorite, the true definition of melt in your mouth!We also got an order of the tartare because it's basically my favorite thing to eat ever and it was super fresh, flavorful and perfectly enhanced with the quail egg and lemon.I am a very adventurous eater so if you're like me this is the place for you. I will definitely be back to check out some of the more interesting items (Testicargot anyone?)

EDIT: 10/16/17 - RIP Chef Takashi Inoue--------------Let me start off by saying, I really love meat. When you go to a restaurant that only serves cow, it's like angel voices ringing in my head. Because who really wants to order a veggie dish? (Vegetarians and vegans excluded). Oh, but the starters were veggies, and they were fine.Everything at Takashi was prepared beautifully, and all the dishes were so good! I wanted to order more, but everyone was full.K-F-C (Kobe beef tartar, foie gras and caviar on toast) - this was good and actually a decent amount of foie and caviar; probably would not order again due to there being other quality menu itemsStewed beef tendon casserole - hands down the best thing we ate; hearty and flavorful, so much flavor! Sooo good. Everyone at the table wanted more.Steamed beef shank buns with spicy mayo - pass; the flavor was underwhelming compared to the beef tendon casserole, but the meat was tenderFoie gras stuffed meatball with chocolate bbq sauce - the sauce was the star, it was weird and satisfying at the same timeSquid ink rice with miso-marinated sweetbreads - I liked this; it had a slight briny taste and the sweetbreads gave a complementary texture to the riceYooke (chuck eye tartare with raw quail egg) - I think I prefer the Korean way with the Asian pears and more, but you could definitely taste the high quality of the meat here; not bad, not greatNiku-uni (chuck flap topped with uni on top of shiso) - we all agreed that this one might have been a bit overhyped for us; it was good, but not "omg I have to get a billion of these" good. Uni and the meat was top notch though for sure, but we thought the shiso overpowered everything a bitOn top of the above, we ordered some ribeye, beef belly, and short rib. I liked them all, but my favorite was the short rib.I highly recommend Takashi. Next time I want to do the Cow Experience, ramen and the cow balls/testicles (they're made escargot style with garlic shiso butter). What can I say? I love an adventure!

If you're an adventurous eater, or an offal fan, this definitely deserves a visit. Â I've been here twice, and I think that my experience was dampened by a recent visit to Japan. Â Before I went to Japan, this place blew my mind - after, I still enjoy the food here, but I'm much more cynical about a couple of the dishes. Â With that said, the service was loads of fun and we still had a great meal. We didn't stay for the not so secret "secret" ramen this time around, but if you have a chance to - do it! Â Last time we ate from the standard menu, and then ended up staying for secret ramen, I definitely walked out of Takashi with a second trimester food baby. This time around, we had a reservation for 7 PM, yet we all coincidentally ended up in the area 30 minutes early, walked by the restaurant, and since there were open tables, we were seated immediately.Niku-Uni: chuck flap topped with sea urchin and fresh wasabi. This is just me being picky, I just had uni from Hokkaido the previous week, so I was definitely not impressed with this dish. Â Also, as much as I try, I still just don't love shiso leaves. Â Worth a try if you haven't had it, but I doubt I'd personally order it again.Takashi K-F-C: Kobe beef tartar, whipped Foie gras marinated in white miso and Caviar from Hackleback, served with sake-pickled Japanese cantaloupe and toast. Â If only I could keep this "Miraclewhip" in a giant tub in my fridge. I worried needlessly that the white miso would overwhelm the flavor of foie gras, and be overpowered by the saltiness of the caviar. Â I was wrong, this is decadence in every mouthful. Â Thinly sliced A5 Miyazaki Kalbi with Hokkaido Scallop Sashimi and Spring Garlic chives: the scallop just melted onto the kalbi in our mouths, and this was one of the highlights of the night, though we all agreed that there were too many chives. Do not skip this. We ended up saving the chives on the side of our plates for nibbling throughout the rest of the meal.Super-tender Filet Mignon Steak with Garlic Butter Dip: I'm usually not a filet mignon girl, but anything in garlic and butter will always get me. Â This is worth ordering - unless you're on a first kiss kinda date - we're talking whole cloves of garlic.Bone Marrow and Crawfish Dumplings with Hong Kong-Style Hot Peanut Oil Sauce: I wanted to love this, the dumpling blend was extremely tender, but even with a copious dip into the peanut oil sauce, it leaned towards blandness, which is a shock since I can't rock spicy.Grandmom's Steamed Beef Shank Buns with Spicy Mayo: This was the other dish I was underwhelmed by, and I think that it's just the Asian in me, this was no more remarkable than a typical bun from a dim sum place, and the meat was a tad dry. If I'm being honest, I'd rather have a $2.50 pork bun from a standard dim sum place.Calf's Brain Cream (in tube) with Blinis & Caviar: If you've never had this, this is lovely. Â It's lighter than foie gras, and once you get over the mental block of eating "brains", it's a surprisingly delicate dish. Remember to eat this with your pinky out.Rosu (Ribeye): when in doubt, you can't go wrong with ribeye.Tsurami (Cheeks): anytime you have a chance to enjoy cow cheeks - do not resist.Tan-saki, Tan-suji & Tan-moto (the tongue experience): and what an experience it is, you have to try this at least once. It's interesting to compare texture and flavors of the various parts of the tongue.We ended up sharing a Madagascar Vanilla soft-serve ice cream made in house, the texture was unimpressive, but the flavor kept us reaching for our spoons.Two bottles of yuzu sake on the rocks kept us company throughout the meal. Â Shout out to Adam for being such a darling during the night!

THE BEST BBQ PLACE IN THE US!Again, this is by far the BEST bbq place I have ever been. No joke. The meat quality and the service are amazing. To a point it's my MUST-GO place when ever I'm visiting New York City. (I normally go back to NYC every other month) everyone are so friendly there from the host to the servers to the helpers. I love the vibe there and I became friends with them.Takashi is a hidden gem. The reason I say it is because there are no big sign on the street and he to road construction you won't be able to see it out from the road. The restaurant itself is kinda tiny and they only take reservation for 4-6 people. During the weekends, no parties bigger than 6. This is the rule. So make your reservation ahead. Or you should be prepared to wait for at least an hour. Appetizer: wagyu beef topped with uni and raw beef tartare with quail eggThose two are my MUST ORDER. You can never go wrong with those two.Meat: -A5 Miyazaki beef-think beef tongue (MUST HAVE!!!!)-thin cut beef tongue-Kobe beef-beef belly-beef shoulder -pork bellyI'm from California and I'm definitely spoiled by all those Korean BBQ. But trust me. You can not find anywhere serving the meat quality better than takashi. Not even similar. NO JOKE! A5 Miyazaki is a bomb. The fat spreads out evenly and it just melt in your mouth. Not too oily and it's just get to the point. Limited supplies every single day sometimes they will be out on sunday nights. So good luck kn that. THICK beef tongue: this is another MUST ORDER. Words can't explain how good it is just try it and you will never regret.  The food quality that takashi is providing never disappointed me. Not even once. They provide the best quality of meat so no matter how you cook the meat it still taste amazing in your mouth. I have been bringing my friends to try this place out and EVERY SINGLE ONE loved it. Takashi thank you for being around. I'll visit you again soon!

I dream of the day I can return to Takashi.I had this place bookmarked for years after seeing it on one of Anthony Bourdain's shows (he has so many!)Finally planned a trip out of New York and this was at the top of my reservations list.It was easy to make a reservation for a party of 6 for a Saturday night online. We arrived and our table was waiting for us. It is rather cramped but then again, it is a tiny but cozy restaurant. They started us with kimchi and bean sprouts, which were delicious, but cost $2 each to refill...(sucks!)We looked over the menu and asked our waitress for recommendations. She pointed us in the right direction and the food arrived quickly. The game changers were the A5 waygu with gold and the uni. DROOOOOOLPretty pricey but worth the visit!

I finally had a chance to come back to Takashi. I went a few years specifically for the niku-uni (raw chuck flap with uni & fresh wasabi on shiso leaves). But they ran out within an hour of opening. I was super sad but did go back for the midnight ramen. I wasn't tantalized much by it to be honest, but vowed to come back for the niku-uni. Finally had it and it lived up to my expectations. The uni is so fresh and they give you a good amount one each of the 4 pieces. The raw beef is delicious and lightly chewy and goes well with the shiso. I also tried their beef belly and kalbi bbq. They give you a very small amount (compared to regular Korean BBQ), so don't go starving! I also tried the beef schmaltz crostini with truffle oil, which was tasty but nothing spectacular. I did want to point out the great service we had because I read a few reviews about how the servers aren't the friendliest. When I called the restaurant prior to dining there, they said it would be about an hour wait which is expected. I got there and the guy at the door said that they had a no-show and would be able to seat us! The server we had was also so friendly and very attentive. I'll definitely go back to try some of their other appetizers and bites, but the BBQ didn't cut it for me. Maybe because I'm used to big (ger) portions at Korean BBQ places. But loved LOVED the niku-uni!

Cool, hip and dimly lit. Such interesting offerings and unconventional ingredients. Fancy some foie gras with chocolate sauce? What about some uni with raw beef? Each bite is a SURPRISE. The place to BE for quality meats, stellar appetizers and bomb dessert. WHAT TO ORDER:Appetizers1) raw beef with uni - super creamy and indulgent. Haven't seen this dish being offered anywhere else!2) foiegras meatball with chocolate sauce - it comes in a hot skillet, wafting aromas of chocolate with fatty foie gras. Omg. Meats1) harami skirt steak - salt n pepper2) kalbi - marinated3) in between rib meat - charrs nicely with a little bit a chewYou must try cooking the meat in butter and garlic.....!!Dessert-1) soft serve vanilla - the mochi (rice dumpling) is SO good.

Came here for midnight ramen with my girlfriend for our anniversary - was really excited by the prospect of eating my favorite food at midnight! We had Takashi's Original Ramen ($16) and Grandma's Spicy Ramen ($17) and the beef broth was really unique - extraordinarily rich, and you could really taste the beefiness. Usually I prefer my ramen spicy, but I found the spicy paste a bit overwhelming in flavor and saltiness and you lost some of the nuances of the original broth, which was disappointing - I'd recommend maybe only using half (when they serve the bowl, they put the paste on top and you mix it in yourself). After finishing my bowl of spicy ramen, I became extremely thirsty and drank like a gallon of water at home. For Kobe beef, I didn't think the meat was as tender as it could have been. The noodles were decent, but the best thing was actually the crispy intestine cracklings. Overall, it's a fun experience and the food is good, but definitely not the best ramen I've had.

We arrived around 4:45pm and were the first in the line (so lucky!)Since it is our first time there, we ordered all the favorites from our yelpers.Niu-Uni: A MUST. The beef was first grade and the uni was very fresh. The seaweed and leaf were not just for decoration but contributed to the nice flavor instead.Yooke: personally, I think it is the best dish we had in the entire meal. The seasoning is right, the beef is fresh, and the egg made the meat tender and whole the flavor together. Even our son ate a lot of it.Steamed beef shank bun: we didn't like it. The shank was too dry and tasted kind of bland. We understand that they would need to have at least one dish for kids but it was just not working for us.US Kobe Kalbi: it is our favorite meat for the grill. It was tender, juicy and just melt in your mouth. We ended up getting a second order.Filet mignon with garlic butter dip: we are normally not a filet mignon fan as we prefer fatty/juicy/more flavor cuts, but this dish did not disappoint. By following their instruction, the filet mignon was actually quite juicy! I also love their garlic butter dip. We kept it for the whole meal.Thick tongue: my husband has been looking for thick cut beef tongue in NYC for a long time and was glad to find it here. It is always our preference to have thick cut beef tongue over the thin ones as you can enjoy the texture and flavor.Harami: this was our less favorite dish for the grill. The meat was too chewy for our taste and the marinate was not helping - the garlic sauce didn't go well with the meat for some reason.We gave the restaurant a 4 Star because of the Shank Bun and Harami, but I can see we go back to try other more adventurous dishes!!

We had the following:niku-uni/chuck flat topped with uni***grilled tetchan/daechang, mino, and akasen***and yooke//thinly sliced chuck eye tartare topped with a raw quail egg yolk, seaweed, and lemon***All were delicious and yakiniku (grilled meat) items were well-cooked. Disappointed with their late night ramen. Many reviews claimed it was the best ramen they had. I still prefer Totto and Ipuddo.Why? The broth was way too garlicky and after mixing in the spicy paste, it just tasted like the paste, very one dimensional. Their Grandma's spicy ramen only comes with a small piece of beef, which was on the bland side as well.Now that I've knocked them off my ramen list, I know I won't be back.

So. Delicious. This place has turned me from a Kbbq fan to a Jbbq fan!!!Definitely order the filet mignon and the Kobe skirt steak. I would go back just for these two alone. We also got the uni and beef appetizer which was yummy. As well as the tartare. The Kobe ribeye was good too but overshadowed by the rest in my opinion. The atmosphere was fun and casual without feeling sloppy. Would absolutely return. I'd be interested in coming to try the Midnight Ramen too! (:

The quality of the meat is top notch here. Takashi is one of the best yakiniku restaurants I've been to outside of Japan. They don't accept reservations for small parties less than 4 people so we went at 5:30 p.m. to line up before they opened. There was probably 4 parties ahead of us. The restaurant is pretty small so it's best to go early. We came once on a Saturday night around 7:30 p.m. and they told us the wait was 2-3 hours. We ordered 2 appetizers and 3 meat dishes to share between the 2 of us and we were pretty full after that. We could have eaten more but didn't want to push our limits. Yooke- a dish that's often offered in Japanese yakiniku restaurants. It's beef tartare with a raw egg on top. Loved it!Niku Uni- this was by far my fav dish of the night. It's beef sashimi topped with uni on shiso and seaweed. Best combination ever! But then again uni is one of my fav things in the world. Both the beef and uni were really fresh.

You got a fair amount of money, want a new bbq experience, and lots of flavors? Then give Takashi a shot! If you're a foodie (or at least opened to trying something new), try to book the cow experience menu a week or two ahead of time. I learned that sweetbread is delicious. Portions are small. Quality is high. Presentation of food is good. Decor is cozy and intimate. This is not a place for you to enjoy the standard BBQ. Would recommend coming for special occasions, lest your wallet get drained quick.

Expect to spend a lot of $$$ for high quality of meat! Its been so long that I want to try out this place! Finally me and my bf had a chance to go and we waited about 5 minutes to get a table. The place is not that big and it looks simple and cute inside. I got raspberry soju martini to try their drinks and honestly I didn't really like it. Its too sweet with alcohol. I expect some more flavor in it. For appetizer we got the niku-uni- chuck flap with leaves of seaweed, uni and wasabi. It was good and different. You taste the strong leaves and uni. 4 pieces for 2 people is good. For bbq we got 3 types, kalbi, harami and misuji. Everything was really good and perfect and the serving is small and I eat a lot, so for me and my bf we eat it so fast. Good thing I eat a lot of rice too or else I'll still be hungry and need to order more meat. Its really the best quality of meat so no regret. Its very different from any usual kbbq places. I'm glad to finally try it and I'll save this place for any special occasion.

Super unique bbq restaurant. I came here for my dad's birthday and didn't realize what I was walking into. The have everything that is NOT normal, like intestines, brains, etc. Pretty crazy. My boyfriend wasn't a fan but I thought it was very good, I love trying different foods and this was definitely something intriguing. I ordered the cow's brains, it came out in a tube, and you ate it with some crackers. We also ordered raw wagyu with a piece of leaf forgot what the leaf was called but, super flavorful. We ordered a bunch of other things to bbq, everything was super unique. Would definitely recommend if you consider yourself a food adventurer. They also have midnight ramen, which is pretty interesting, i haven't been but i heard good things about it!

WORTH. THE. WAIT,After not being able to get in our first time in NYC (they only allow reservations for parties 4 or more), my friend and I made a point to get here hella early to grab a seat. Â We got there at 5pm on Thursday and were the first people in line, so needless to say, we were stoked! We ordered three kinds of meat: the Kobe Kalbi, Beef Belly, and the Super-tender Filet Mignon Steak with Garlic Butter Dip. We got both the Kalbi and the Belly marinated in Takashi sauce and it was amazing! I prefer my meat medium-rare to raw plus, so 30 seconds on each side made each piece perfect. Â Such tender meat! Â We ate several plates worth each! Â The star of the meal was the Filet Mignon steak though. We ordered it based on the waiter's recommendation and it was one of the most delicious steaks I have eaten. It comes with a metal pan full of butter and crushed garlic cloves, which you heat on the grill with the meat.  First, you sear the steak bits on the grill, then you finish by cooking them in the butter sauce. It is heavenly! As a lover of garlic, this was everything I could have wanted from steak in garlic butter sauce. Plus, once you finish cooking the steak, you can enjoy the caramelized garlic bits.Overall, I spent $100 on dinner and loved every bit of it! Couldn't recommend this place more!

LOVE LOVE LOVE the midnight ramen. I've gone twice already and I would go back for more. I'm super picky about my ramen and there has not been a place that I love except for this place. I was told to have a drink of sake before the meat and then again after just to taste the difference. There's a completely different taste for both! We ordered the Masumi Okuden Kantsukuri Sake. Give it a try.I have also tried the regular bbq for dinner and it was also very delicious. Â The popular dish is definitely the kobe with uni on top. It just melted in my mouth. I ordered the bbq also which was super yummy.

Holy mother of god the midnight ramen at Takashi is off the charts!!!!!Grandma's Spicy Ramen with Foie Gras: At a hefty ~$36, you can get a bowl of jaw-dropping, lip-smacking, finger-licking beef ramen with melt-in-your-mouth beef belly, crispy intestines, soft boiled egg, and foie gras that you'll be dreaming about for weeks.I know eating late night foods is not healthy for our bodies, but it seems like mental health trumps physical health this time! I am SO happy I can die with no regrets. Definitely the best bowl of ramen in town!Here's some actual useful insights post-rant:Call beforehand to make a reservation as they can only seat ~20 people at a time; there are usually two waves of customers at 12am and 1amThe broth surprisingly is not the usual salt heavy soup bases you get at other ramen placesIf you can take spicy, go for the Grandma - you won't regret it :)

Takashi is owned by Chef Takashi, a 4th generation Korean immigrant, born in Osaka. Â The restaurant is all about the beef and offers choice cuts of Premium Japanese and American Angus for a yakiniku or a horumon dinner. Â They're only opened for dinners, but we came here for their late-night ramen!Just note that this late-night ramen experience is only held on Fridays and Saturdays, with a 12 AM midnight and a 1 AM seating (technically, it's Saturday morning, 12 AM/1 AM, and Sunday morning 12 AM/1 AM). Â The ramen is made with a 24-hour beef broth, and comes with custom-made noodles, a 20-spiced red paste (Takashi's grandma's receipt), US Kobe braised beef belly (SO SO SO GOOD - super tender and juicy, this had an unbelievable taste to it; it literally melts in your mouth!), crispy small beef intestines (kasu), and half of a soft-boiled egg (organic).We had the Grandma's Spicy Ramen, with the spicy paste on the side, and foregoing any additional toppings (there's foie gras!). Â The beef broth was definitely different - a little greasy and can be an issue for those with sensitive stomachs. Â However, the taste was pretty good! Â The noodles were thin and were okay; the intestines were forgettable, but I can see how some may like this for the added crispy texture (which stays crispy for quite some time!). Â The paste added some spice to it, and I thought it'd be similar to kimchi paste; however, the ramen already came spiced up, and the side of the paste requested was not needed. Â I loved the marinated boiled egg, as the yolk was perfect and creamy. Â The star of the show was the braised beef belly, as it had a perfect amount of fat to it - I'd definitely add more of these babies the next time!!!The good thing is is that Takashi does take reservations in advance, both via phone or via email. Â However, the restaurant is set-up as a communal style, so if you're a single- or a party of 2, you will be seated next to a group of 3 or a couple. Â Service was friendly, but slightly slow in getting our refills and the check. Â Great experience, and I'd love to come back for their yakiniku experience, because this place seems to know their beef!+US Kobe braised beef belly!!! MMMM+late-night ramen 12 AM and 1 AM on Fridays and Saturdays+reservations accepted+dinners only

Oh hell yeah.After I saw an insta of uni on wagyu on shiso on seaweed I knew I had to have it. The reservation was easy to make through Yelp and we were seated promptly once we got there. The uni/wagyu/shiso/seaweed dish was $26 for four pieces which I find to be a very reasonable price. We ended up ordering two and it was everything I dreamed it would be!What I didn't know is that takashi also has tons of grilled meats as well. I definitely felt a little bad about bringing a vegetarian friend with our group of 4...just a little bad =P We tried the US kobe kalbi, the beef belly and the tongue. The kobe kalbi was 100% our favorite, the true definition of melt in your mouth!We also got an order of the tartare because it's basically my favorite thing to eat ever and it was super fresh, flavorful and perfectly enhanced with the quail egg and lemon.I am a very adventurous eater so if you're like me this is the place for you. I will definitely be back to check out some of the more interesting items (Testicargot anyone?)

EDIT: 10/16/17 - RIP Chef Takashi Inoue--------------Let me start off by saying, I really love meat. When you go to a restaurant that only serves cow, it's like angel voices ringing in my head. Because who really wants to order a veggie dish? (Vegetarians and vegans excluded). Oh, but the starters were veggies, and they were fine.Everything at Takashi was prepared beautifully, and all the dishes were so good! I wanted to order more, but everyone was full.K-F-C (Kobe beef tartar, foie gras and caviar on toast) - this was good and actually a decent amount of foie and caviar; probably would not order again due to there being other quality menu itemsStewed beef tendon casserole - hands down the best thing we ate; hearty and flavorful, so much flavor! Sooo good. Everyone at the table wanted more.Steamed beef shank buns with spicy mayo - pass; the flavor was underwhelming compared to the beef tendon casserole, but the meat was tenderFoie gras stuffed meatball with chocolate bbq sauce - the sauce was the star, it was weird and satisfying at the same timeSquid ink rice with miso-marinated sweetbreads - I liked this; it had a slight briny taste and the sweetbreads gave a complementary texture to the riceYooke (chuck eye tartare with raw quail egg) - I think I prefer the Korean way with the Asian pears and more, but you could definitely taste the high quality of the meat here; not bad, not greatNiku-uni (chuck flap topped with uni on top of shiso) - we all agreed that this one might have been a bit overhyped for us; it was good, but not "omg I have to get a billion of these" good. Uni and the meat was top notch though for sure, but we thought the shiso overpowered everything a bitOn top of the above, we ordered some ribeye, beef belly, and short rib. I liked them all, but my favorite was the short rib.I highly recommend Takashi. Next time I want to do the Cow Experience, ramen and the cow balls/testicles (they're made escargot style with garlic shiso butter). What can I say? I love an adventure!

If you're an adventurous eater, or an offal fan, this definitely deserves a visit. Â I've been here twice, and I think that my experience was dampened by a recent visit to Japan. Â Before I went to Japan, this place blew my mind - after, I still enjoy the food here, but I'm much more cynical about a couple of the dishes. Â With that said, the service was loads of fun and we still had a great meal. We didn't stay for the not so secret "secret" ramen this time around, but if you have a chance to - do it! Â Last time we ate from the standard menu, and then ended up staying for secret ramen, I definitely walked out of Takashi with a second trimester food baby. This time around, we had a reservation for 7 PM, yet we all coincidentally ended up in the area 30 minutes early, walked by the restaurant, and since there were open tables, we were seated immediately.Niku-Uni: chuck flap topped with sea urchin and fresh wasabi. This is just me being picky, I just had uni from Hokkaido the previous week, so I was definitely not impressed with this dish. Â Also, as much as I try, I still just don't love shiso leaves. Â Worth a try if you haven't had it, but I doubt I'd personally order it again.Takashi K-F-C: Kobe beef tartar, whipped Foie gras marinated in white miso and Caviar from Hackleback, served with sake-pickled Japanese cantaloupe and toast. Â If only I could keep this "Miraclewhip" in a giant tub in my fridge. I worried needlessly that the white miso would overwhelm the flavor of foie gras, and be overpowered by the saltiness of the caviar. Â I was wrong, this is decadence in every mouthful. Â Thinly sliced A5 Miyazaki Kalbi with Hokkaido Scallop Sashimi and Spring Garlic chives: the scallop just melted onto the kalbi in our mouths, and this was one of the highlights of the night, though we all agreed that there were too many chives. Do not skip this. We ended up saving the chives on the side of our plates for nibbling throughout the rest of the meal.Super-tender Filet Mignon Steak with Garlic Butter Dip: I'm usually not a filet mignon girl, but anything in garlic and butter will always get me. Â This is worth ordering - unless you're on a first kiss kinda date - we're talking whole cloves of garlic.Bone Marrow and Crawfish Dumplings with Hong Kong-Style Hot Peanut Oil Sauce: I wanted to love this, the dumpling blend was extremely tender, but even with a copious dip into the peanut oil sauce, it leaned towards blandness, which is a shock since I can't rock spicy.Grandmom's Steamed Beef Shank Buns with Spicy Mayo: This was the other dish I was underwhelmed by, and I think that it's just the Asian in me, this was no more remarkable than a typical bun from a dim sum place, and the meat was a tad dry. If I'm being honest, I'd rather have a $2.50 pork bun from a standard dim sum place.Calf's Brain Cream (in tube) with Blinis & Caviar: If you've never had this, this is lovely. Â It's lighter than foie gras, and once you get over the mental block of eating "brains", it's a surprisingly delicate dish. Remember to eat this with your pinky out.Rosu (Ribeye): when in doubt, you can't go wrong with ribeye.Tsurami (Cheeks): anytime you have a chance to enjoy cow cheeks - do not resist.Tan-saki, Tan-suji & Tan-moto (the tongue experience): and what an experience it is, you have to try this at least once. It's interesting to compare texture and flavors of the various parts of the tongue.We ended up sharing a Madagascar Vanilla soft-serve ice cream made in house, the texture was unimpressive, but the flavor kept us reaching for our spoons.Two bottles of yuzu sake on the rocks kept us company throughout the meal. Â Shout out to Adam for being such a darling during the night!

THE BEST BBQ PLACE IN THE US!Again, this is by far the BEST bbq place I have ever been. No joke. The meat quality and the service are amazing. To a point it's my MUST-GO place when ever I'm visiting New York City. (I normally go back to NYC every other month) everyone are so friendly there from the host to the servers to the helpers. I love the vibe there and I became friends with them.Takashi is a hidden gem. The reason I say it is because there are no big sign on the street and he to road construction you won't be able to see it out from the road. The restaurant itself is kinda tiny and they only take reservation for 4-6 people. During the weekends, no parties bigger than 6. This is the rule. So make your reservation ahead. Or you should be prepared to wait for at least an hour. Appetizer: wagyu beef topped with uni and raw beef tartare with quail eggThose two are my MUST ORDER. You can never go wrong with those two.Meat: -A5 Miyazaki beef-think beef tongue (MUST HAVE!!!!)-thin cut beef tongue-Kobe beef-beef belly-beef shoulder -pork bellyI'm from California and I'm definitely spoiled by all those Korean BBQ. But trust me. You can not find anywhere serving the meat quality better than takashi. Not even similar. NO JOKE! A5 Miyazaki is a bomb. The fat spreads out evenly and it just melt in your mouth. Not too oily and it's just get to the point. Limited supplies every single day sometimes they will be out on sunday nights. So good luck kn that. THICK beef tongue: this is another MUST ORDER. Words can't explain how good it is just try it and you will never regret.  The food quality that takashi is providing never disappointed me. Not even once. They provide the best quality of meat so no matter how you cook the meat it still taste amazing in your mouth. I have been bringing my friends to try this place out and EVERY SINGLE ONE loved it. Takashi thank you for being around. I'll visit you again soon!

I dream of the day I can return to Takashi.I had this place bookmarked for years after seeing it on one of Anthony Bourdain's shows (he has so many!)Finally planned a trip out of New York and this was at the top of my reservations list.It was easy to make a reservation for a party of 6 for a Saturday night online. We arrived and our table was waiting for us. It is rather cramped but then again, it is a tiny but cozy restaurant. They started us with kimchi and bean sprouts, which were delicious, but cost $2 each to refill...(sucks!)We looked over the menu and asked our waitress for recommendations. She pointed us in the right direction and the food arrived quickly. The game changers were the A5 waygu with gold and the uni. DROOOOOOLPretty pricey but worth the visit!

I finally had a chance to come back to Takashi. I went a few years specifically for the niku-uni (raw chuck flap with uni & fresh wasabi on shiso leaves). But they ran out within an hour of opening. I was super sad but did go back for the midnight ramen. I wasn't tantalized much by it to be honest, but vowed to come back for the niku-uni. Finally had it and it lived up to my expectations. The uni is so fresh and they give you a good amount one each of the 4 pieces. The raw beef is delicious and lightly chewy and goes well with the shiso. I also tried their beef belly and kalbi bbq. They give you a very small amount (compared to regular Korean BBQ), so don't go starving! I also tried the beef schmaltz crostini with truffle oil, which was tasty but nothing spectacular. I did want to point out the great service we had because I read a few reviews about how the servers aren't the friendliest. When I called the restaurant prior to dining there, they said it would be about an hour wait which is expected. I got there and the guy at the door said that they had a no-show and would be able to seat us! The server we had was also so friendly and very attentive. I'll definitely go back to try some of their other appetizers and bites, but the BBQ didn't cut it for me. Maybe because I'm used to big (ger) portions at Korean BBQ places. But loved LOVED the niku-uni!

great ååãª tongue ï¼ and shoulder ! We love the ã«ã«ã very much! And I think It would be even better if there is a raw egg on the top of the ççèææ¡ãï¼anyway! I would say it's a great restaurant for Japanese taste lover ~

It was a very long wait to experience what celebrity chef restauranteur David Chang claims as one of his fave places. So we did, and grab drinks at the bar across the street where we stuck out like sore thumbs but there were only the same 4 ppl the entire hour.It was yummy. The grilled items were petite and flavorful. The wagyu tartare with urchin was ok. To be honest, I am a huge raw meat and fish fan- every bit as much as I am a sea urchin purist. The 2 superfoods together somehow detracted from one another, if that doesn't sound crazy?I don't know, it's not the amazement people build it up to be, not even a hair. It was good but not great nor amazing.The tartare with raw quail egg however, was better than expected and downright luscious and mouthwateringly delicate. The intestines and sweetbreads and 2nd or 3rd stomach (who knew there were more than 1?!) we ordered were good but so sparing that it took away from the experience. And they give u these tiny, albeit cute Â toddler sized bowls of rice. This place is a definite first date place where people don't intend to eat and just want to push around their food for an hour. Pretty, cute, sorta yummy, pricey for that sorta play, ugh, no- not for true blooded eaters.

I love ramen anything. When I saw this on the menu I knew I had to try it. It did not disappoint! Truly one of the most unique takes on ramen I've ever had! Toasted ramen noodles never tasted so good!

This is by far the best ramen I've ever had, including all the bowls I had in Japan. I would definitely recommend making a reservation for it b/c the store isn't too big, and they only serve this twice a week! I tried the Grandma's Spicy ramen, which comes with noodles, broth, a thick slab of beef belly, crispy beef intestines, and an egg. While the spice paste isn't really spicy, it does add a huge punch of umami flavor. The broth is AMAZING. Ramen broth is usually pork or chicken based, but after trying this beef broth, normal tonkotsu broth just doesn't compare. It has such a deep, rich flavor without all the heaviness that the pork broth has. Plus, I've never actually had beef belly before, and it's SO MUCH better than pork belly. The only cons to this place are that they automatically add a 20% service charge (even for a party of one!!) and you leave with everything smelling like yakiniku (maybe not that bad of a con). I'll be coming back every time I'm in NYC!
The uni in nori is just so special and reasonably priced! Love love love itI recommend going there a little early since sometimes it takes hours to get seats, even for just twoHorumon was nice too

I'm always searching for top notch meat cuts. Japanese BBQ is one of my favorites. Anthony Bourdain had mentioned Takashi in an article and i kept it in my bookmarks knowing he wouldn't disappoint. Â It was a 2 hour wait without a reservation. Luckily they take phone numbers and can text when a table is available. There are plenty of bars in walking distance to help work up your appetite.They recommended a couple appetizers and a couple meat plate orders. We laughed! I was ready to stack plates. The Niku Uni: IG worthy and as tasty as it looks. Melts when you eat it. Red Red Kimchi: Ordered with a bowl of rice. Just enough heat and tang to counter all the meat. Filet Mignon with Garlic Butter: This was one of my favorites. Dip in the butter, quickly cook the filet pieces, drop it back into the butter and eat instantly with a big chunk of garlic. Others i'd recommend: Kobe Kalbi, Rosu, Harami (marinated), Shio Tan.Just prepare to spend some cash! They add up quick.

This restaurant is a must go place for people who love Japanese style bbq. They have a great selection of meat items to choose from. I suggest that you try at least one plate from Kobe beef item and also the beef belly. They are super delicious. And do not forget to reserve a table at least a day before visiting this place.

"I'm eating with Quoc tonight? Better bring an extra $100" - BestieHe's right. One of my friends even accused me of "only the best for Quoc". Ugh, I said my name twice already; I'm such a narcissist. Anywho, despite my occasional luxury cravings, I am a reasonable person. The food is undoubtedly top tier quality. We ordered the 'Cow Experience' (which had to be ordered in advance, but the waiter and chef were kind enough to accommodate us (thank you again)). It's about 5 slices of 16 different edible portions of the cow. Heart, liver, 4th stomach. FOURTH! If I had that many stomachs, I'd be as fat as a cow too! And yes, each piece was rich in flavor. You start to wonder if they have a designated cow in the back on life support for this very purpose. I thank you, coma cow.The service is what you'd expect. Well... it's what I expect you'd to expect: prompt and slightly personal (good personal). So, as you already figured out, the caveat is: it's d**k expensive. Between 5 people, the 'Cow Experience' is $55 each. That's $275, and with 5 slivers per organ, that comes to roughly $3.50 per slice. I told my hair dresser and she really likes the place. The only difference between us is that I'm 100 lbs heavier than her (she'd take that as a compliment if she heard), so the lesson of the day is: maybe I'm broke because I'm a fatass.I HAVE TO mention they do carry the best IPA I've ever had. I don't know what it's called and I might be delusional but it tasted like sakura.

Much like restaurants in Japan, Takashi is a tiny joint with just enough space to seat a several diners sitting elbow to elbow, but oh-so packed with flavor. This isn't your average Asian barbeque spot - they have a real flare for presentation. We were served whipped cow brain in a toothpaste holder, and were presented with a tray of whimsical sake shot glasses to choose from.Delicate dishes such as tartare, pate with caviar, and beef broth preceded the main event: grilled meat. The most memorable appetizer was a bite-sized piece of uni on a bed of wagyu beef, shiso, and nori, which left me wanting ten more.We indulged our inner carnivores and ordered rib-eye, filet mignon, skirt steak, and three types of cow tongue. The meat was all grass fed and high quality, but the kicker was the sauce, from garlic poached in butter to a spicy yuzu sauce. The waiters were fun and chatty, and laughs were flowing as much as the sake. Overall, fantastic food and a fun atmosphere.

Solid four stars for this place. Closest Japanese BBQ I have been to outside of Japan. Definitely fun for a date night, to expose your kid, to eat healthy grilled meats, all in the heart of the west vill. Hypes: - meats. The beef is all we got and it was superb. Both the marination options are flavorful. The beef belly being the softest. The kalbi and the Harami (skirt steak) were very good. Â - scallion salad - perfect dressing, refreshing, filling- ice cream - get the vanilla with no toppings. Caramel is a little too intense and salty. - toto heated toilet in the restroom - always a hit in my book if you have this- awesome hip ambiance. Took me back to Tokyo. Gripes:- you may think it's overpriced, and the quality of MEat may be just average for you, but I think it was worth it - you definitely come out of here smelling like a barbecue and meats so plan on doing this and bring some body spray along, or shower before you go out after.

Great place for authentic Japanese dining! It's an interesting and fun restaurant with delicious Japanese Japanese dishes, grill and BBQ. You cook your own food (Korean BBQ style) on an open grill on your table.For our party of five, we ordered a variety of dishes to share. What we had: * Sea Urchin atop Kobe beef tartar served on seaweed - practically melts in your mouth* Testicargot - cow balls escargot style with garlic butter* Bone marrow beef balls/dumpling - dish came out sizzling! * Kalbi (short rib)* Rosu (ribeye)* Beef Belly* Wagyu beefEverything was delicious and drool worthy. The grilled meats were so tendered and perfectly seasoned - the meat just melts in your mouth. Our table was feeling a little adventurous and ordered the cow balls escargot. It was interesting to say the least. The dish was a strong garlic butter flavor which helps to not remind you that you are eating cow balls. The homemade ice cream is great too.It's a little pricy but worth it!! Great place to eat some Yakiniku Japanese style.

I've been eyeing this restaurant since I've seen it on one of Anthony Bourdain's food travel shows. Being a bit of adventurous foodie (but not as adventurous as Andrew Zimmerman) I want to try a place know for their offal. That is parts of the animal that are not commonly used in dishes.The restaurant is pretty small but has a cozy feel. It has bar seating as well as about roughly about 10 tables for seating. We were sitting near the back area. The walls are decorated with drawings and descriptions of the food they offer.There was a good amount of drinks offered as a selection. I ordered the white peach soju sparkler to drink along with the meal. It had a light clean flavor and was refreshing. Before ordering, we were given three complimentary appetizers of raw cabbage with a sesame dressing drizzled, kimchee and bean sprouts lightly tossed in a soy sauce. For the dinner we ordered the Niku-Uni, testicargot, Â the tongue experience, the marinated is Kobe kalbi short rib and the marinated shibire (sweetbreads). The Niku-Uni was a great start to the meal. It was fresh sea urchin topped on a chuck flap of beef, sesame leaf, nori and a little wasabi. It was served with a side of soy sauce that you folded the Niku-Uni and dipped into it.As each of the meats to be grilled were presented, the waitress was helpful by instructing us how long each item was to be grilled. The tongue experience was an interesting. The tongue was presented in three different cuts (front, middle and back of the tongue). Each cut had a different tenderness to it. I liked the middle cut the best out of the three. On the side we were given two sauces for dipping the meats into. One was a soy sauce and sesame seed mix and the second sauce was a yuzu sauce.The Kobe short rib and sweetbreads were very tender and so flavorful. The waiter told us that the meats can be either seasoned or marinated. He highly recommended to have them marinated for the full flavor and he was right. The short ribs and sweetbreads did not even need the extra sauces. I always heard that sweetbreads taste great if prepared correctly and boy were these great. The testicargot was a bit on the chewy side. It was flavored well, but it wasn't my favorite thing that we tried that night. It was a texture thing that turned me off from it.Service was really good as the waiters were willing to explain anything in the menu and make sure you were enjoying your meal. The check came out with gum to freshen up your breath from the meal. Overall I would return here again to try a few other things on the menu.

Love here! It's all about beef. Japanese BBQ is always on the top of my favorite dishes list. This is a specialized beef grill place where you could find a decadent selection of variety meat. Highly recommend Niku-Uni with urchin.

I came here because of the wonderful reviews and ratings they have. We had tried the beef with uni, they're beef tartar with quail eggs, squid rice and short ribs. They were phenomenal and we're our favorite. We also tried liver sashimi (eaten raw), cow testicles, cow cheeks, cow large intestine and "between the rib" for grilling. These were weird and completely not something we're use to eating. The bill was extremely expensive for the amount of food we ordered and their portion is extremely small. Glad to have tried this restaurant with great service but will not be coming back. I do recommend to try this restaurant if you're looking for something exotic.

This place is super hard to get a reservation but indicate that you want to be contacted if a table opens up. Â We were fortunate to have a 7:30 pm table open up for us. Â We ordered a bunch of things:Takashi KFC - expensive and small but very rich.Niku-Uni - expensive for 4 pieces, tasted alright thought its just hype to be honest.US Kobe Kalbi - very fatty and delicious2 bottles sake - expensiveOverall, the food was good but expensive with very small portions. Â DO NOT COME HUNGRY OR WITH ALL DUDES, you will end up going to a pizzeria afterwards like we did. Â We literally left hungry. Â Nice place for a date if you wish to impress.Service was good and decor of the restaurant is very simplistic and clean.

They had some really interesting options on the menu for the adventurous eater! In my opinion though was really overpriced, and the portions were pretty small.The best thing we had was definitely the beef belly, would really recommend that. Their tartare with quail egg was pretty good too, but it gets a little gross after too much so make sure you have a few people to share this with. The thick slices of beef tongue I did not enjoy, and I usually love tongue! I think the slices were just too thick so you'd get it crisp and starting to burn on the outside, but the middle would still be cold and raw. I personally prefer a thinner cut where the entire slice is nice crisp on the outside with a bit of chewiness. Also had the testicargot...huge regret! My boyfriend and I wouldn't have even finished it if it didn't cost so much! It had a sort of sauce over it but tasted unseasoned otherwise, so the middle was just a bland tasting testicle...not good.Price was also really high for what we ordered and the amount of food. We didn't order any of the crazy slices of beef like the wagyu or Kobe, we got about 5 different dishes in total and it came to $120 for 2 people! We definitely weren't full, we just kind of got sick of eating meat and we had agreed to finish within an hour, that was the only way we could be seated without a long wait. Also it gets a bit uncomfortable with the hot dry heat from the grill blasting in your face.Would not really return again for their grilled meats, but am still interested in their ramen based on the rave reviews!v

The broth and overall flavor of the original ramen is one of the best I have had! Portion size is decent and you get a large slice of pork belly. The crunchy intestine bits were also an interesting addition - I liked it but I can see it not being for everyone. Ramen is $16-17 a bowl.We came for midnight ramen and thought it was a fun idea! They will not let you in until midnight in the dot though - definitely make a reservation as it gets crowded fast. You may also have to share a table if unless you are in a party of four. Overall, a great experience!

Magnificent. We came by, and there was a several hour wait. We went to Employees Only, had drinks and appetizers, and came back. Worth the wait! Adventurous BBQ! There was heart, several stomachs (cows have multiple stomachs), liver, sweetbreads. There was an exhaust system pointed at our grill that seemed to be just decorative. Our waiter was very informative. Don't forget to get the ice cream and rice ball dessert.

Never a disappointment at Takashi!! The wait could be long, but it's TOTALLY worth it. I would definitely recommend the garlic butter dip (comes with the Filet) and the kalbi (literally melts in your mouth).Always a great experience and I think it would be a great way to impress out of towners or first time japanese bbq-ers!

4 and half star.amazing quality beef that melts in your mouth!!! try the wagyu a5. and the the us kobe ribs. i didn't really like the apetizers,so i would suggest ordering more different meats instead of those.a little bit on the pricier side(about 70 bux per person)but worth itwould totally go back and recommend it!

The hype is real. Having read about long lines and wait time, we came here around 5pm on a Friday night and people were already waiting outside. For two people we tried the test-cargot (6 pieces of cow balls escargot style), tongue experience, Â the kobe galbi and sweetbread. My FAVE was the kobe galbi. They give you dipping sauces on the side but it was melt in your mouth oh so flavorful good.Also, I didn't know what sweetbread was and decided to look it up after I ate it. We grilled it to a crisp at the suggestion of our server and it was delish. I didn't think I'd enjoy eating a thymus so much.Service was also awesome. Our server was really helpful in helping us decide what we wanted based on what kind of texture we enjoyed.

This review is long overdue. But Takashi is personally one of my favorite restaurants and is a must whenever I touch down in NY. This is one of those places I crave for from 3000 miles away (I live in CA). The food and meats are always great and Lisa always takes care of us. Meats are high quality and I'm addicted to the butter with cloves of garlic that they have.

Wow this place was amazing. I have been keeping an eye for Takashi a few months ago when I was planning my New York trip. So happy that I got to try it! Doors open at 5:30PM and a line was already forming. My boyfriend and I got there around 5PM and was 2nd in line. They do have limited of tables and if you have a party of 4+ then you can reserve one. I love the environment of the restaurant, very fun and romantic.We ordered:Niku-Uni: DELICIOUS! You can't go wrong with Kobe beef topped with uni with a shiso leaf. One thing I knocked off a star for was the beef was a bit to frozen therefore, there was not much flavor.Takashi's K-F-C: Steak tartar was amazing! It had so much flavor. the pickles and the quail it brought it to life.Testicargot: Cow balls, don't be scared to try this. It was VERY good, just like escargot Pork Belly: Very fatty and marinated well for BBQChef Special: They had a few livers, hearts and other goodies, portions are pretty small and more on the pricey side, but was marinated well and was delicious still!Overall, great experience and definitely lives up to its hype! I recommend giving this place a try when you are in NY!

I came here for the late night ramen, which they start serving after midnight.The restaurant is small, which made for a cozy and intimate atmosphere. This is my first time trying beef broth ramen so I don't have anything else to compare it to but it was amazing. The original beef broth ramen had US Kobe braised beef belly, crispy intestines, dried Japanese seaweed and an organic soft boiled egg. The crispy intestines were a wow factor as I'm not usually a fan of organs cooked Asian style. The broth was hearty and flavorful and the beef belly melted in my mouth. An egg in a bowl of ramen always makes me happy but I wish they gave us one whole egg instead of a half.Overall, the experience was very good. The staff were friendly and we were able to make a reservation, which is a plus. I'd like to come here again and try their dinner menu even though the prices are steep.
Waitress sooo nice. It's great service. I tried Calf's brains. It's awesome. Beef is very soft. You should try with Sake.

Takashi has been on my list for a very long time. When it came time to pick a restaurant for my birthday dinner, I knew exactly where I was going to go! We had reservations for 4 people (they actually only allow reservations for 4+ people) and was seated right away. At 6:30pm, all the tables were full and most of the counter spots were taken as well. They take your jackets and store them in closets so they don't smell like barbequed meat, which I thought was very nice. We opted to start with a few shared appetizers and then move onto the yakiniku. We got the Instagram-famous Niku-Uni. I really enjoyed each bite (spoiler, I had 2). The uni was really fresh and creamy, and all the flavors meshed really well together. We also decided to be adventurous and try the Testicargot, or cow balls cooked escargot-style with garlic shiso butter. I've had bull penis as well as turkey balls before and neither of them was a good experience, so I wasn't expecting to enjoy this one either. It was actually quite pleasant! To be fair, the cow balls were smothered in the garlic shiso butter sauce so you couldn't really tell what you were eating. But, I did enjoy the texture and taste a lot more. We also had the Stewed Beef Tendon Casserole. The beef tendon was very tender and the stew was extremely flavorful and fragrant. I kind of wish the dish was a little bit bigger because I wanted more beef tendon! We sampled a variety of meats during the yakiniku phase of our dinner. We ended up trying:- Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Kobe Kalbi, or short rib ($26)- Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Kobe Ribeye ($26)- Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Beef Belly ($20)- Â  Â  Â  Â  Â The Tongue Experience ($25) with Tan-saki, Tan-suji, and Tan-moto- Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Sirloin All of the meats we ordered were really good, but I think our favorite of the night was the Kobe Ribeye, which we ended up placing a second order. Everything tasted really fresh and a lot of the meats practically melted in our mouths (except for the tongue, of course). They only have one kind of dessert here - Homemade Madagascar Vanilla Soft Serve, which you can add a variety of toppings. I went with the, "I'll have it with the works", which has every single topping and your choice of a syrup. I opted for the green tea syrup, which helped to cut the sweetness of the ice cream. It was really, really good and made me think of my time in Japan last year where the soft serve is definitely better than it is here. Service was attentive and they changed our grill a few times during dinner, which helped prevent the meat from sticking.

Takashi - A culinary diversity & curiosity of NYCI am writing this review after having been here twice for dinner. I do not rate price level or ambiente, but strictly the quality & flavor of the food as well as the quality of the service.Overall I love Takashi for its uniqueness in their offer. Takashi is no ordinary Japanese/Korean table BBQ, but the upscale version of it with a very interesting twist on the menu.Food - 8/10Service - 8/10Below some details on the above.The seating at Takashi creates comfort & informality while not being too informal. At the same time, the tables are rather small and the seating is rather squeezed. At times the smoke of the table grills gets intense. Overall, Takashi probably has less than 8 tables (x4 people) and a bar counter to dine on.It has to be mentioned that Takashi is basically three restaurant models in one. The upscale dining option is the full menu of Japanese/Korean table BBQ. On certain days they offer Ramen, which they have been praised for as well. Lastly, they also offer a traditional Japanese/Korean table BBQ menu.What's special about Takashi? The types of meat they offer: From A5 Kobe with 18K gold leaves, over foie-gras infused bonemarrow-meatballs, to tubed calf-brain with caviar. And those are only some of the interesting options on the menu. There's much more to discover here, Takashi doesn't let any type of meat go to waste and instead creates an incredible experience of unique flavors with a luxurious twist.The food I ate here was in all cases amazingly flavorful. Although the traditional options like rib-eye, galbi and pork are great too, I strongly recommend to step out of your comfort zone here and try the unusual.

Went for midnight ramen with a reservation. Options were straightforward: you either get the spicy or non spicy ramen for ~$16 plus tax (you can add extra meat, additional egg, etc for extra). Opted for the spicy ramen but the non spicy version offered a slightly better opportunity to appreciate the complex, rich broth by itself. Very flavorful broth, nice noodles, and the beef slices were melt in your mouth good. I'd like to come back during regular hours for the full menu and to enjoy grilling beef and offal tableside.

Such a great experience! The food and the service were both great :) We had a table of 6 and ordered the Bone Marrow and Crawfish Dumplings, Filet with Garlic Butter (my personal fav), Kobe Short Rib, Kobe Steak, the Tongue Experience, Niku-Uni, and Testicargot. The filet was seriously delicious!! I think my expectations were too high for the uni after reading reviews on here, it wasn't my favorite. This was my first time eating cow testicles, so the texture was definitely something to get used to, but the flavor was good!! Our waitress was amazing and had great suggestions. We loved the Sake she suggested for us as well :) I would definitely recommend trying this place (preferably with 4-6 friends)!

I was here 3 years ago but it was an unforgettable night! The food is very yummy and fresh! The only downside is that it is awfully pricey as well, would recommend couples and friends to come here for gatherings or celebrations!

I put my name down for a table, and the hostess gave a bs estimate saying it would take approximately two hours. However, I never received contact after receiving a confirmation text and waiting for two plus hours. In fact, I'm still waiting. It's been five hours. Very disappointing and unprofessional.

Love it love it today just moody for Japanese bbq ... didn't waste my time to wait for one and half hrs the meats is super juicy and tender... the hot sake is expensive that's why I give 4 stars but everything is great!!
Still a huge fan of Takashi. Recently tried the A5 beef, and it was as soft, fatty, and delicious as one would imagine.I love this place. It's so good.
Best Yakiniku (BBQ) place in the city!

Definitely the most unique Japanese restaurant in NYC. Menu is not for people with weak stomachs. Very eclectic menu with items you don't really find in most Japanese restaurants. Overall, everything was very good but not spectacular. If prices weren't as expensive, I'd say it's worth it but it's more of a one-time experience kind of deal. Bill came out to almost $200 for 2 people but I wasn't that full and I don't really eat much so that says something. Wait time is ridiculous as well. Expect minimum of 1 hour. People even line up before the restaurant opens. Calf's brain cream was a pleasant taste in the mouth with caviar. Nice presentation with the tube of cream. Foie gras Kobe burger was very tasty. Sweet but slightly salty was a good balance. Testicargot was very differrent in a good way. Flavoring from the usual preparation of escargot went well together with the balls. Nice buttery and savory flavor to it. Niku-Uni was very subtle but flavorful at the same time. Chef's selection and beef belly was a great combination of BBQ selections as well!

Long story short. So our group of four came here without a reservation, but fortunately there were two separate spots with two seats each opened up; our waitress Sonora actually promised us to check on whether the two table would like to combine so that our group could sit, but SHE DIDNT, and she just told us to come back tomorrow. We were waited outside for half an hour and were just turned away as our waitress did not check?! Very pissed!This is just a piece of advice for those who would like to try their midnight ramen - just remember to make reservation. As for me, I will not come back. Felt like eating is more about having fun and apparently, I would not be able to enjoy myself any more given this bad memory.

Decided to give this place another try. Maybe I just didn't have an appetite the last time I was here because this time was absolutely amazing! The service was great and we were able to get a reservation easily.We ordered the usual; beef tongue, niku-uni, beef belly, short ribs, Kobe kalbi, scallion salad, large intestine, edamame etc. BUT my family and I were feeling adventurous last night so we decided to get the calf's brain with caviar, fourth stomach, heart, and testicargot (cow balls lol). And can I just say that everything was delicious regardless of how weird it was LOL! The testicargot was a little chewy for my taste, but overall it's something to try once in your life. I will definitely make this restaurant a priority every time I visit New York!

If you're in the mood for good quality Japanese BBQ, the size of your Â wallet somehow doesn't matter to you that day, and you'd like an early dinner, Takashi is the place for you. Takashi has been bookmarked on my list for awhile due to my desire to try the oh so photographable uni over beef. Spoiler alert, it wasn't as amazing as I thought it would be. The leaf served with this dish (under the beef) overpowered everything; the taste of the beef was undetectable and even the uni taste was hidden. We also ordered the tartar appetizer along with the US Kobe short ribs and beef belly for the grill. Both were succulent and delicious as the marinade was sweet. I actually preferred the beef belly more, while my friend preferred the short ribs. The short ribs were a bit chewy though. Highly recommend you order both! My absolute favorite dish of the night was the tartar! It was so flavorful! Each bite left me wanting more and more. Â Yes, prices are high and portions are small, but it's worth splurging for once.

Came here without a reservation. Â Found out just how busy this place can get. Â When we signed up there was a 3-hour wait because of all the reservations (keep in mind this was a Sunday night). Â So we were about to leave, but a table was available for an hour before the next reservation arrived! Â I wouldn't say to bank on this, but it was a lucky opportunity. Â By the way, it only takes a party of 4 to place a reservation, so it's probably worth it to do so if you can. Â My party only had 3 of us, so a walk in was our only choice. Â Anyways, we were served super quickly, I think because they needed the table for the next party. Â But that was totally fine, it was great to have each dish come out one after another. Â I love the level of variety they have here, with both raw and cooked beef! Â The Niku-uni is a must. Â Though a lot of people may not be used to the taste of shiso leaf more than anything. Â But the mix of raw beef and uni was fantastic. Â Another big highlight was the beef shank buns. Â Kind of their take on Peking duck, but with beef! Â Really tasty with the spicy mayo sauce. Â Really enjoyed dining here, and for the lucky opportunity to be seated as a walk in. Â The service is excellent and super helpful. Â Great spot to grab a beer and some beef. Â Take the opportunity to be adventurous here as they offer some great food you won't come across very often.

I was SO excited to try Takashi. I've tried to do a walk in on three separate occasions only to be informed of a 2 hour wait. My thoughts, "Daaaang, this place has gotta be good."Anyway, one early weekday evening, we were able to get a bar seat, finally. Our server was really great at helping us navigate the menu, helped us figure out portions, and recommended things to order. The interior has whimsical drawings and scribblings along the wall around the cuisine served there--with a special attention to hormone yaki. PROS:Creative menu: Fusion of many different Japanese and Korean snackies that tempt your curiosity. Check out their menu. If you are down to eat, you will ooh and aah.Service: really prompt and efficientPresentation is good, even for the cook at the table foodsAn array of meat cuts with explanations. We had a three versions of tongue. SO fun to pay attention to the textures. Also a bit visceral. CONS:I imagine some of these creations require some labor but be prepared to spend some to leave full.
