(Also depends on your budget, I speak from the perspective of having a middle class salary ;) ) No shade to the restaurant as I'm sure rents are cray in this hood and the food is definitely good quality. Bar seating, when you include the inset grill, is a little cramped. But, hey, it's NY.Overall, if you're gonna go, be prepared to spend a bit to leave full, but rest assured, the food will be good. I recommend a reservation if you are more than 2 people.

Delicious meal! Some favorites: Niku-uni, squid ink rice with miso marinated sweetbread, A5 beef, shoulder, between the ribs, cheek, and outside skirt. Honestly, I enjoyed everything except the foie gras with chocolate sauce - I love foie gras, but this dish didn't quite do it for me and I didn't feel as though it matched well with the chocolate.The service was excellent. Our hostess treated us to a free round of drinks while we were waiting for our table, because we waited an extra 30 minutes after our reservation (without us having to complain about it).The only problem was that they ran out of quite a few things on the specials board by the time we ordered. Would recommend making an earlier reservation (mine was for 7:30).

After not getting a chance to try kobe beef when I was in japan, i had to come to Takashi after seeing the great reviews! This place takes reservations but only if youre a party of 4 or more. Strongly suggest a reservation as there was a lot of people waiting when i was there and the place isnt that big. Originally my party wanted to do the Holy Cow experience but they no longer offer it :(Between the 4 of us, for appetizers we got the Niku-Uni, Yooke (Beef tartare), and Testicargot ( cow balls escargot style). Niku-uni and Yooke were AMAZING. never did i think i was gonna eat raw meat but they were so delicious! Definitely a must try if you come here. The Testicargot was okay. Wasn't blown away. For meats we got the Rosu rib eye ($26), Kobe beef belly ($20), Kalbi Kobe short rib ($26), Filet mignon with garlic butter ($30) and the chef's selection ($36). All of them were soooo good!! The garlic butter was great to dip any of the meats in. Though you don't get much meat, eac meat were marinated very well and you could tell they were quality cuts. The only one i didnt like was the stomach that came with the chef's selection. The texture was not there for me and i felt like i was chewing foreverrrr. The prices are pretty steep compared to other japanese bbq places like gyukaku but the quality is definitely better! Definitely worth a try!

This is for the midnight ramen only- this is a one of a kind ramen with crispy intestines and optional foie gras. My bf and I usually get the added foie gras with it even if it's expensive because it's soooo good but very rich, so the small size is good enough. This place is definitely worth a try especially if you are a risk taker with foods since a lot of people gets grossed out when there's intestines involved. Just keep in mind, you need to make a reservation for it and the ramen starts at 12am (midnight) only. ;-)
Uni, foie gras stuffed meatball, bone marrow and crawfish dumplings. How can you go wrong? Adventurous cuisine. Cooking your beef on the table's grill adds to the experience.
The food is great here. But be warned, do not come hungry because you will be served very little food. I still need to try out the ramen on friday/saturday at 12am

PROS:Takashi is an excellent place for those who want "Adventurous Eating" with brains and ballsGreat service -- friendly, quick, helpfulThe BBQ was good overallCONS: Too pricey for grill-it-yourself-Asian-BBQ, esp now that Kang Ho Dong Baekjeong offers a high quality alternative in K-townSmall portion sizes, so I left feeling like I could eat a burger somewhere elseNo reservations so waiting outside in the current December cold is a distinct possibility RECOMMENDATION:Try it once if you're in the mood to eat oddball bits of cow and feel like dropping c$60 on that experience-------------------------------FOODNiku Uni - My favorite dish of the night. Â It's a thin slice of chuck flap topped with sea urchin on top of a shiso leaf. Â You add wasabi and dip it into soy sauce, then eat it in a single bite. Â As an uni lover, I could have eaten the whole serving (4 pieces) myselfRamen Quesadilla - This dish was DRENCHED in sauces then topped with seaweed shavings and bonito. Â I have no idea what exactly the ramen quesadilla tasted like because it was basically a delivery system of sauce + shavings. Â Do not recommend.Calf's Brain Cream (in tube) - It tastes really similar to butter, but I couldn't get away from this psychological 'ick' factor that I'm eating brains. Â While I feel like I deserve an "Adventurous Eating" badge, I'm also ok giving the badge back because I didn't really enjoy this dish knowing it was brains, plus I never want to eat brains again. Â Thankfully I was with someone who is ALL about eating weird things; he downed the whole thing. Â Personally, I'd rather just eat butter.Testicargot (cow balls escargot style with garlic shiso butter) - YES I ATE BALLS. Â [insert balls jokes]So after we got all the balls jokes out of the way....what do cow balls taste like? Â Honestly, I have no idea because this dish was also DRENCHED in some kind sauce. Â I'm surprised to see the menu description of garlic shiso butter because it looked a lot like pesto. Â The overuse of sauce is a cop-out to hide the fact that the main component is probably tasteless and bland (like the quesadilla). Â For testicargot, the balls were also probably tasteless....but even the sauce couldn't hide the fact that they have a super chewy texture, which also made me feel icky, psychologically speaking.BBQ: Kalbi (short rib), Nakaochi Kalbi (between-the-rib), Beef Belly, Tsurami (cheek)We ended up getting a 2nd order of both Kalbis because while all the BBQ portions are pretty small, the Kalbis were on the bigger side. Â Plus they were tasty and we were all still hungry. Â Between the 4 of us, we only had 1-3 pieces each, depending on the dish.

Pretty amazing spot. The caviar foie gras toast was my favorite with a close second the Â uni Kobe beef! The wait staff was very nice and all the selected meats where delicious. Don't leave with out a Japanese ice cream Sunday!

My boyfriend and I visited last night (Tuesday, around 8pm) for my birthday. My boyfriend chose this spot because of Anthony Bourdain's NYC Layover episode. We were told the wait would be around 45 minutes, but we were seated within 15-20 minutes. We did notice that it started getting more packed around 9-9:30 though. Note: They only take reservation for parties of 4+ so that's why we had to wait.Takashi was one of the food experiences I have ever had. Although it is pricey, it is definitely worth the price tag. This place is not afraid to experiment and use different cuts of meat that only adventurous foodies will thoroughly enjoy.Real quick, the dressing in the starter salad is AMAZING. The salad may not look like much, but the dressing is A+++.Sake: Our server recommended the Soto one. It was very crisp, refreshing, and smooth. The perfect pairing to our food.Niku-Uni $26 (chuck flap topped with sea urchin and fresh wasabi): I usually do not like uni, but the combination of seaweed, shisho leaf, raw beef, and uni compliment each other so well. The uni is not too overwhelming, and the chewiness of the beef meshes really well with the uni texture. I think this is a must-try because you don't see this pairing anywhere else.Squid Ink Rice & Miso-Marinted Sweetbreads $20 (with Spicy Yuzu Aioli, served on a magnolia leaf): O M G. This dish was the #2 highlight of the evening. The waiter preps this for you by placing it on the grill for a few minutes to let it sizzle and warm up. The rice is sticky and fluffy. The sweetbreads is really tender and creamy. The spicy yuzu aioli sauce adds the perfect finishing touch to the dish. It was so good I wanted another order of it. This is a dish that everyone needs to order.The grilled meats has two simple marinate options: 1. seasoned with salt, garlic and sesame oil; 2. marinated in Takashi's sauce. Our waiter helped us with the marinate options based on the meats that we ordered. He will also let you know how many minutes to grill each type of meat (on each side). We followed his exact instructions and pulled out our phones to time everything.Kalbi (Kobe cut): MELT IN YOUR MOUTH. This was our favorite of the evening! This was seasoned with salt, garlic, and sesame oil with no dipping sauce needed. Honestly, you can never go wrong with kalbi at any BBQ place. The only difference is how fresh the meat is, and Takashi did not skimp on this part.Tan-saki, Tan-suji & Tan-moto (the tongue experience): This was very enjoyable. You get three different cuts of the tonuge (saki, suji, and moto). I only know the cuts based on time since we forgot to ask him. My favorite is the 30 second one, followed by 45, then 1 minute. The 1 minute per side one was a little too chewy for my liking. Horumon-Moriawase (chef's selection): This includes heart, live, 1st stomach, 4th stomach, and sweetbreads. The heart and the sweetbreads were our favorite cuts.Overall, it was an amazing experience, and we will definitely be visiting again because there are so many other things to try. We kept looking around at other tables, which was a bad idea because we were so tempted to order everything we saw. Next time we come, we will be trying out different dishes.
Food is amazing. Kobe beef and uni appetizer where great appetizers! I would love to return.

Very solid yaki niku place that is ostensibly part korean (not apparent from anything other than the kimchi you get when you sit down) with great and interesting cuts. Definitely try the "tongue experience" which is three different cuts of beef tongue with different textures and cooking times and the various stomachs you can order (they all taste different!)The best non BBQ dish was this short rib stew that might have been a special. The heavily instagrammed niku-uni dish was pretty disappointing with the near frozen piece of beef adding little in terms of taste and serving primarily as food clickbait.

This review is purely based on their late night ramen sessionYou have to make a reservation in order to get their delicious ramen otherwise, you got zero chance by just showing up.Location:West village is the host for Takashi. I heard all those great things about Takashi but I have not yet had the chance to visit until my friend told me that she booked two seats for late night ramen. I am soon surprised.This place is small, but still aims to host lots of people. Party of two will have to join the other party of two to make one table, and party of five like us have to squeeze in two a small square table for a quick eat of ramenFood: their late-night ramen session only has two choices: spicy ramen or traditional ramen. And you have several choices of toppingsI had traditional ramen The meat is juicy! The soup is delicious! The noodles is too chewy. I almost gonna hit for another bowl but it's very fulfill after the first one. Service: very busy. They also have all kinds of wine, sake and plum winePrice: it's bit pricy thoOverall: a very good experience.

I believe this is the best Japanese BBQ place for beef-lovers in the town! The Niku-Uni should be a 'must-order'. It was a great joy to taste the collision of different flavors in your mouth. The beef was melted with just a few bites, and the sea urchin was so fresh that a little bit of sweetness perfectly balanced the rawness of beef with the unique scent of seaweed and herbal leaf. We also had the beef brain (in a home-made tube). With the rich and slightly sweet taste of Caviar ozzed out in the mouth, the creamy brain sauce made the blinis taste like a cake. They also have the A5 grand wagyu beef, which might be a seasonal. And the kalbi, rosu, shio-tan (beef tongue) are my reasons to be back. The meat they served are just so fresh to cook, without a single taste and scent of rawness. And they even have the beef's first stomach, second stomach, fourth stomach, beef heart and beef liver to barbeque. We were not brave enough to try those, but it could be very attractive for beef lovers. It's a little bit expensive and the place is small, good Japanese style decoration and LONG waiting time!

Best place for late night ramen. You have to make reservations though and they only serve for an hour. That broth is super delicious and ask a spicy everything person I would actually recommend trying the regular first to appreciate the broth

We just had dinner here and the food is so good. But when we back home I found my shopping bag is left here. So I call this restaurant and make sure my bag is still here. The waitress Jackie answered the phone and didn't pay much attention to what I said. I described very clearly about my shopping bag and where we sit. She said she'll call back about fifteen minutes. Yeah, it's ok for her to check it for 15 minutes. I think it's very simple to check it's just right under the bench. The only things she need to do is just look down there. But I said yes and then wait for her. After 20 minutes, she didn't call back. So I call her back and she didn't answer it. After more 10 minutes I call her back and yes she answered it. She just forgot that there is one customer waiting for her call back and thought we just some other ones need make reservation. GOOD!!!!! Her brain is not so clearly and I have no choice to drive 40 minutes back to this restaurant. When I walk right to this restaurant I slightly look down under the branch and my bag is there! SO FUNNY!!!!!! Â That's it, really funny. BTW, the Japanese waitress is so nice and I really like her.

I love Takashi. If you're less than 4 people, it can be a long wait...but it's definitely worthwhile. The presentation of the food is incredible, the smells, flavors, and types of meat are things I haven't found other places. It's a small restaurant so it feels really personal and cozy inside. Waitstaff is amazing. I've never had a bad server or experience here. I've tried the chef selection which definitely made for an interesting meal..recommended if you're feeling adventurous. Do not bring a vegetarian here...they will not be able to eat anything ! If you can't manage to snag a table for dinner, make a reservation for their midnight ramen on Friday or Saturday nights to have one of the most delicious bowls of ramen you'll ever taste.
I love their midnight beef ramen. Although its a BBQ place but the beef ramen is so good and I would visit just for that.

Love the meat here. The spices were just right and you dont need to to grill it for too long. Pretty dim inside and decent seating. Place dont take reservation so the wait was quite long. Overall it was worth the wait
The filet mignon in garlic butter - nothing short of a religious experience! Perfect.

I saw this restaurant at one of Anthony Bourdain's shows and he recommended to try this place out if you're looking for an authentic yakiniku experience in New York. This place delivers! We tried their squid inked rice with miso marinated sweetbread for appetizer and we ordered different cuts/types of meats such as beef belly and beef tongue and everything was great! I also like the fact that they give you a recommendation on how long each type of meat should be cooked for. Â I also like their beer selections (mostly Japanese beers, which is my favorite kind of beer) and I found my new favorite beer - the Yo-Ho Wednesday Cat. Service is exceptional I must say. We went their without reservation as they only take reservation for parties of 3 people and up and we were told there is a 2 hr wait. We stayed at the restaurant to wait and the host, after 30 minutes, gave us a table! Place is small though and the noise level could be really high. Also, tables are a bit too small and it gets really hot when you get close to the grill. Overall it was a great experience and the food is excellent!

This review is specifically for the midnight beef ramen. Haven't had a chance to try the japanese bbq.After seeing an eater article about ramen popup on my facebook feed, the nucleus accumbens Â  part of my brain suddenly lit up. Beef ramen? Sounds unique. Only serves it twice a week? Must be special. Only serve it twice a week and only at 12 am or 1 am? They must be crazy.Since it just so happened to be a friday night, I called up an old friend and decided to try our luck and get two seats as a walk in. Luckily they had two seats for us at the 1 am slot. We kill sometime at a local bar till they called us and off we went. We both got the traditional beef ramen w/ some spicy sauce on the side. Being most accustomed to the traditional shoyu and miso broths, I didn't know what to expect with the beef one. Boy, was it delicious! The broth was super flavorful and the beef belly, super tender. One of the best bowls of ramen in the city, hands down.

Dining at Takashi is a lesson in patience, discipline, and moderation. First, you must make a reservation (only parties of 4 or more can make reservations), unless you're cool with waiting a couple hours. The first time we tried to come here, one of our friends flaked at the last minute and they had to cancel our reservation (even though all three of us were there already!). Then, once you're seated, you have to get over your fear of the unknown and let go of, "I don't eat tongue or innards." Well, guess what? They have a tube of brain mousse and it's delicious, so get on that. The portion is small but everything is delicious... you'll easily spend $40/person if you eat like a bird, but more realistically, you'll spend about $70-80/person (including a drink). They also serve midnight ramen on Fridays and Saturdays, but don't think about sliding from dinner into ramen, because ramen requires a separate reservation. Then, you have to grill the meat yourself, and there are all sorts of rules ("Don't flip the meat too much, you'll waste the juice" plus all these different grill time requirements for the different cuts). Also note that your clothes and hair will smell like grilled meat after a meal here: a full shower + shampoo + laundry will be required. But, the meat is totally worth all these idiosyncrasies if you're a carnivore like me. The filet mignon in garlic butter sauce is melt-in-your-mouth tender. The thinly sliced beef shoulder is delicious, tender, and flavorful. Each cut of meat has a different character to it. The only thing I probably wouldn't order again was the uni with raw steak, because the uni overpowered all the other things. It's a treat and I wish I could try the ramen along with dinner!

Grilled meat in any capacity can be a wonderful thing and when done right, it is one of life's great pleasures (#1). In the case of Takashi, Yakinuku guru Takashi Inoue has made his mark in the West Village by showcasing a style of Japanese cuisine that often gets overlooked; becoming one of the most notable and progressive (not to mention delicious) Asian businesses in all of Manhattan and perhaps the most sought after Japanese BBQ spot in NYC.The price point is high, as this is no ordinary WV dining spot. Some would come here for special occasions, many for tourism fan foodie'ism, and many more just because they can afford it. While the portions are expectedly teeny tiny, I can vouch for their quality: Everything will be tasty. Everything will be executed well. Above all, everything is extremely fresh.A love of red meat is a virtual prerequisite, though texture is key for palatial reasons. Amongst the grilled meats, the Kalbi ($26) is almost always a sure thing as well as the Rosu ($26), a delectable ribeye cut. Anyone who is a fan of tongue will surely enjoy the Tan-saki, Tan-suji & Tan-Moto ($25) which has been dubbed "The tongue experience." While I haven't experienced much of the intestine or stomach bits, I can vouch for the ultimate option: the Horumon-Moriawase ($30) which is the Chef's Selection. No one can go wrong with this.To the more adventurous side, the raw meats are limited in selection but rich in flavor. The Namagimo ($16) is a delightful surprise, liver was never my strong suit but that's all negated apparently when its marinated in sesame oil and given a dash of rock salt. The Gyutoro-Tamaki ($18) is a raw beef handroll; a chuck flap with some nori and a light garnish of wasabi that screams wonderful with every bite. The most popular dish, the Niku-Uni ($26) might just be the highlight of anyone's meal here. A piece of delicious wagyu chuck on a shisho leaf, nori seaweed bed and topped with ultra fresh uni makes for one mouth-watering bite. It is a foodgasm not to be ignored and as Bourdain once said after an eyes rolled back experience: "If you don't like this, we can never be friends." Well said.Other non-traditional items but equally palate potent is a list of seasonal specials that Takashi rotates year round. The infamous KFC ($38), consists of Kobe beef tartare, Foie Gras marinated in white miso, and Caviar from Hackleback is served with a sake-pickled Japanese cantaloupe and toast. It is one of the most expensive dishes in the house for a reason: it's mind blowingly delicious. Honorable mentions include the Squid Ink Rice & Miso Marinated Sweetbreads ($20), Bone Marrow and Crawfish Dumplings ($16), and the Bilini + Caviar combo of a Calf's Brain Cream ($28) served in a tube like some edible science experiment.And yet, there is still a wait with reservations on any given night, tight yet limited seating, and small grill table setup just enough for a small group to enjoy a hodgepodge of fine meat inspired plates. There are only so many places like this in NYC, but Takashi earns its stripes through a myriad of meat dishes that boggle the mind and tantalize our taste buds.________(#1) Sorry vegan friends. If it helps, I really love hummus.

My friend came to visit me two weekends ago. He was SUPER adamant about coming here for dinner. I was like, "I mean, we're having dinner REALLY late. Are you sure you wanna go here?" "YES. We HAVE to. I tried coming here last year and they were closed. We have to go."Fine. I gave in. Honestly, I didn't know what this restaurant was, but DAMN, I'm SO happy that he brought me there. We got there around 8:30 or so, and they told us that it was going to be a 2 hour wait. (In my head, "Damn. Good thing we had lunch at 4 PM.") We ended up going to The Garret to grab a drink, and luckily enough - in half an hour, we got a seat! We downed our drinks and ran over. Our bodies were ready.We ordered the following:1) NIKU-UNI: I had to eat this. Like.. HAD to. I've a sucker for uni. It was SO damn good. I would totally suggest to get this if you're looking for something amazeballs.2) FOIE GRAS STUFFED MINI KOBE BURGER: Chocolate sauce? We were hesitant. But DAMNNNNNN - that was some good stuff. Again - we went all YOLO and just had to get it.3) HORUMON-MORIAWASE: Chef's choice. I don't remember what it contained except for the heart, first stomach, and second stomach. If you're having a hard time deciding what to get -- I would suggest for this.3) BEEF BELLY: WHAT IS THIS. OMG. I remember my friend and I were just moaning over this slab of meat. We even saved two slices at the end just so that we could savor every moment.4) TSURAMI (CHEEK): I could've probably skipped this part of the meal. It was good, but wasn't that amazing.I think we ordered something else, but it escapes me.Alcohol was kinda on the pricey side. We ordered a kettle of mageolli for $45 (however, it was QUITE a lot of alochol. I would suggest not to get this and just get a glass each).Overall, service was impeccable, food was amazing. Glad my friend pushed me to come here with him.

I waited a whole month before writing and honestly the vivid memories I have of the meal have not diminished... what an experience... we sat at the bar and ordered a selection of plates, some offal, tartare and plenty of meat to grill... the beer was cold and refreshing the staff were on point... what more could one want from an evening meal?! if you are looking for a Japanese meal that is beyond the norm...make Takashi your first stop!
Uni and raw beef not fresh.Both girls felt sick and had serious stomachache after we went home that night. Admittedly taste good, but quality shouldn't be comprised OK?

Normally it takes me a long time to write a review but I have to say Takashi is one of the most transcendent restaurants that I have ever been to and I had to have it fresh in my mind when I wrote about it. After hearing about Takashi from Anthony Bourdain's NYC Layover episode, I had to have it. My cousin and I finally made a trip to this restaurant for his birthday. It was a Sunday night. We had planned to have an early dinner at 5pm but since they don't take reservations for two we waited as walk-ins for two hours and was eventually seated at the bar. I know some people will balk at the time, but everything about this restaurant was definitely worth it. Since it was a special occasion, we decided to order everything that we wanted without a care for price:Niku Uni - After seeing this dish on Layover, this was one of the things that we had to have. One of the most unique experiences I've ever had in my life. The Shiso leaf and the seaweed gently wrapped the chuck flap and briny uni. It seemed as the chuck was not a primary flavor component but was included for heightening the texture of the Uni. A MUST ORDERTesticargo - The next dish was a riff on a classic escargot dish but instead used beef testicles. One of the more adventurous menu items, the dish was delicious. The shiso garlic butter was fondly reminiscent of an Italian pesto and definitely made the dish.Takashi's KFC - Easily the most decadent dish that I have ever ordered in my life. Layered in a caviar tin was a Kobe tartar, whipped Foie gras, and Caviar. Although it was lavish in every sense of the word, it was not too overwhelming. I could use without the pickled cantaloupe. I would have liked the toast with the KFC alone. Tongue Experience - With the grilled items we started with the Tongue Experience. The order included different sections of the tongue as a sampler. There was the top tongue, middle and bottom tongue. Each had a different texture and cooking time. The unique dipping sauce was great and make sure you get some lemon juice on it too. Horumon-Moriawase - Next we ordered the chefs choice which included heart, first stomach, liver, tripe and sweetbreads. The heart and liver were lightly coating your mouth with succulent umami flavor. The tripe and second stomach was a nice textural balance, not too chewy but had a great snap. The sweetbreads was something on another level. It had all the flavor of beef but had a softer puddling like texture. A MUST ORDERBeef Belly - Seeing this order so many times on Yelp and rated so highly, we ordered this cut of beef. Incredible marbling on this unique cut. I had to look it up so I can attempt to secure it for my own summer bbqs. The beef belly at Takashi's is the perfect example of a perfect cut of steak. Squid Ink Rice & Miso-Marinated Sweetbreads - We finished our meal with a something a bit carby. I haven't had squid ink rice before and it was perfect introduction for me. The rice was slightly sticky and still pretty fluffy. What made the dish was the Spicy Yuzu Aioli. It definitely tied everything together. Starter Salad?: I have to give a particular mention to the lettuce salad that they give when you sit down. Although it looks like a standard cheap dish, nothing about it is normal. Their homemade miso dressing is exemplary and I would love to have it at home.The overall experience here was amazing. I loved the service here, the waitress explained each appetizer that we ordered and individual cooking times for each cut of beef. Being seated at a bar seat, we got to converse with the chefs and watched as they assemble each unique dish. We ordered most of what we saw. Although it was rather expensive, we loved our food and would have no problem shelling out the money for this kind of experience. I look forward to coming back here for the cow experience (you need at least 4 people and a reservation). They give you gum at the end, a great palate cleanser!

So glad I finally got to try this place on my recent visit to NY after having it bookmarked for years! We ordered the following to start: Niku-Uni (chuck flap topped with sea urchin and fresh wasabi)Yooke (beef chuck eye tartare in special sauce with quail egg) And then per our server's recommendations, the following for the grill:Rosu (ribeye)Beef BellyShio-Tan (tongue)Keep in mind it's pricey because the portions are so small. Unless you're willing to drop a lot of $$, you'll most likely have to eat a 2nd dinner. Most of our group was hungry again by 10PM and needed to hit up another restaurant. The space is also really small so be prepared to sit in close quarters with fellow diners. All in all, everything we tried was SO GOOD -- like melt in your mouth foodgasm good. I came here on a relatively full stomach after a late lunch so I KNOW it wasn't just the hunger thinking for me. If I didn't go with a group, I honestly would have ordered more (esp. of the Niku-Uni and Rosu) but I had to stop myself and be conscientious about racking up the bill for everyone else. Next time I go back, you can bet I'm going to go all out (sorry fiancÃ©e) until I can satisfy my little heart and huge stomach's desire!

The best Japanese BBQ place I had so far. Service was amazing as the waitress was prompt in serving each dish . So wait time is minimal between each dish. All the items we ordered needed help from waitress to mix, BBQ and prepare. All the services were great! The food quality of course is outstanding as well. Would definitely come back again when back in town!

If you can get yourself a table and are a fan of Korean BBQ - put this on your list. It was my very first time trying it and between the service, the experience, and the taste I would 100% make an effort to go out of my way and visit again.

Really enjoyed the meal here. Service was excellent and really made the experience navigating the menu that much easier Drinks list isn't extensive. Stick wth sake. Had the beef cheeks, thick tongue, heart, ribeye and belly. The last item would melt in your mouth. I would return again and again. Just make sure your dining companions are somewhat adventurous.

Came here for dinner to end my NYC trip with the "cow experience" and it definitely did not disappoint. We were running a little bit late and they held the reservation for us. Our waitress Yula was an absolute DARLING. After we settled in and perused the menu we ordered 3 appetizers. 1. Niku-Uni: Uni topped raw beef: AMAZING. The perfect bite to start of a perfect meal. Uni was fresh and was the beef and the wasabi just sealed the deal flavor wise. Highly recommend!2. Gyutoro-temaki Sushi: the chuck rolled sushi. Surprisingly really tasty. 3. Beef Schmaltz w/ truffle oil crostini: A nice little bite, not to salty and not overwhelmed with truffle oil.They quickly put out kimchi (perfectly pickled!) and the bean sprouts. Both are refillable btw. The 18 cuts of beef came out quickly and our waitress came by and told us what each cut was each time we made it down a row as well as how long to cook. We went with the salted meat instead of the soy marinade which she graciously brought out to us on the side to dip with. Least favorite part was the liver. Meh. I don't like liver to begin with so that's just me. Oxtail was a bit tough for me to eat due to toughness. The other cuts were all more or less fantastic. You can't really go wrong with beef. Unfortunately, Yula informed us that we had ordered the last "experience" as they're no longer offering this :( Wish they did so I could keep recommending it to friends who are heading to NY. All in the bill was less than $300 for 4 people with 2 bottles of soju.

It was a fun and satisfying experience filled with japanese/korean yumminess.We were a group of four and were able to share and try a lot of new things.Testicargot - yep exactly what it is - testis posed as escargot smothered is garlic shiso butter. The balls were chewy and don't really taste like much, but the garlic shiso butter is what hit the spot. It did remind me a lot of escargot, but the texture was just oddly interesting.YookeThe tartare was visually appealing and surprisingly yummy. The chuck tartare was seasoned well and chopped perfectly. The egg mush and seaweed mix was an interesting touch.The BBQ items - Nakaochi Kalbi (between the rib) was marinated in the house sauce and was nicely marbleized. The beef belly was a surprise - simple, good fattiness and full of garlic flavor Although it was good, I didn't feel like it was worth the expensive price. I would also recommend grilling about 15 seconds less than the recommended to get that medium rare tenderness.We also got the last 15oz MEGA Spare ribs - slow cooked for five hours then flambeed In bourbon and barbecue sauce. It was pricey but it was so worth it. The whole preparation was also a show - flambeeing, chopping and serving - all so delicious.The Ramen quesadillas okonomiyaki was probably a big highlight of the night. It was ramen pancake filled with beef tendons and aged cheese and shiso leaf. Everything just worked so well together and after you grilled them slightly, the crunchiness was amazing. I really enjoyed this dish.The homemade vanilla ice cream was rich and yummy. The gold flakes did nothing to the flavor though but was aesthetically appealing.This is certainly a good restaurant to try, but will definitely make a dent in your wallet.

Omg! Second time in Korean japanese restaurant and was an wonderful experience. The squid ink rice with sweatbreads and the skirt steak ufff. Is a new experience cooking your food in your own style! Service was good and very gentle! A little expensive but it totally deserved. I definitely come back

This review is for the midnight ramen.Possibly my favorite bowl in the city (I always get the regular bowl, extra beef, kaedama if I'm feeling up to it). Could it be the beef broth, which is much rarer than its pork and chicken cousins in this ramen-saturated city? Maybe it's the extreme garlic flavor (I'm a huge garlic head). Or the fried intestines, which added extra texture and umami to the bowl. Or maybe it's because this place only serves ramen at midnight and 1AM, so I'm starving by the time I get there, having had a light dinner in anticipation.Whatever it is, I love it and can't wait to go back. Dreaming about those tender beef pieces already.

This experience was disappointing considering it was my third time at this restaurant. This time we tried the BBQ, which is what they are known for and found the meat to be of poor quality. Considering the cost, cut, and appearance, I expected meat that will melt in my mouth and flavors that will blow me away. Instead we had chewy beef tongue (one of us just gave up chewing) and rib eye that was tough & chewy. The meat was well marbled, but chewy! Flavors were mediocre at best. Considering each item was at least $20-25 for 5-6 small slices, I expected more. Sadly this is restaurant is crossed off my top favorites. Uni with Kobe appetizer is still delicious though. That is worth trying. The rest, save your money.

This place is very busy and crowded. I had to wait 1-2 hours before being offered a seat. They sat me next to a patron who was literally a few inches away from me. Aside from the standard greeting, the patron was not very talkative. The grill, which was located above me, was very hot and it was uncomfortable seating there. The only other option was to walk out. Most of the items on the menu were not ready to eat and you had to cook them yourself. To me that defeats the whole purpose of going out to eat. Mind as well just stay at home and cook food yourself. Save a lot of $$$. I ended up ordering all the items that you did not have to cook yourself.Calf's Brain Cream (in tube) with Blinis & Caviar: That was a blast! I enjoy brain as food and this was really nicely prepared. Tasted very rich and satisfying. If you never tried calf's brain before, definitely try it. Yolo. 5/5 Testicargot (Cow Balls Escargot Style): Another winner. Interesting taste. You really have to try it to experience it. 5/5Squid Ink Rice & Miso-Marinated Sweetbreads: They had to cook it right in front me on the grill. Come on. The grill was already freaking hot! My legs felt like I was tanning on a beach. This was rather on the salty side and not enjoyable. Sweetbreads were not that great. They were actually overly done, which is never a good thing. 2/5Bone Marrow and Crawfish Dumplings: It was good but rather expensive for the small portion. 3/5Beef Shank: It was alright. 2.5/5The food was not that bad, but the experience, as a whole, was a fail. My waiter spoke in fluent Japanese (he was not Japanese himself). I left a generous tip but won't be coming back.See photos below.

Came here for thanksgiving dinner as this was one of the few spots without a special prix fixed menu. Niku-Uni is their signature dish. I thought it was worth a try but probably wouldn't pay the steep price for it again. The Kobe Kalbi was amazing. We ended up ordering a second plate for the 4 people. Very tender and great flavor. The beef belly was good and very fatty. We also got the regular beef tongue and beef cheek. The marinate for the cheek was good but the meat itself can be kind of a let down having eaten the Kalbi in the same meal. Overall we got 5 grilled dishes and 1 app for 4 of us and while we were full we weren't stuffed. It's a small place but the service is pretty fast and friendly.
Great place for BBQ and small groups!Met my friends that were visiting NYC.I'll definitely be back!

TAKASHI is---- amazing. There's nothing one can write or say that fully encapsulate the awesomeness of Takashi, except that everyone who has been will tell you: You must visit Takashi when you're in New York. Yes, the prices are higher than most Japanese/Korean yakiniku restaurants. However, the quality and vast range of beef cuts and offal speak for themselves. I have had a great many, excellent Korean and Japanese BBQ in LA, but, Takashi is a whole another world. It's not just grilled meat. It's an appreciation for the cow in its purest, most authentic, unadulterated form. Imagine a butcher who loves his craft and displays passion for all things cow, from meat to 4 types of stomach, and other delicious offals. Even if you are not a offal connoisseur, I dare you to step out of your comfort zone and prepare to be amazed. Â As you open the doors to the restaurant, your senses will be heightened by Takashi's signature aroma of high quality beef and offal, sizzling at the highest temperature, to utter perfection. You'll leave the restaurant wanting to keep the aromas with you, for as long as you can, I promise. For the grilled meat selection, I have never felt wronged by going with my servers suggestions. They really have a passion for food and know what is good. My favorites so far have been: rosu (ribeye), nakaochi kalbi (between-the-rib), shoulder, BEEF BELLY, second stomach and tsurami (cheeks). Hatus (heart) was extremely interesting. It tasted as it is, a extremely lean muscle, but still very tender to the bite. Although the heart and soul of Takashi is their grill. You cannot skip their amazing appetizers. I highly suggest ordering: niku-uni (shiso leaf enveloping a slice of raw beef and sea urchin), yooke (beef tartar with quail egg and their special sauce), calf's brain cream in tube (just do it), bone marrow and crawfish dumplings. I've had the testicargot and foie gras stuffed mini kobe burger, both were interesting but I wouldn't get it again because they tasted alright. I had big hopes for the testicles, but was left disappointed because it kind of tastes like large fish eyes. Last thing I have to say is that if you haven't already, definitely make a reservation for their late night ramen- served 12am and 1am (by reservation only) on Fridays and Saturdays. My first time having their ramen was when they had just introduced it in early 2014. It was amazing...rich beef broth with beef belly. Absolutely divine. If you're into ramen, I highly recommend calling them to make a reservation (no seating wo a reserv.!) There are 2 options: Grandma spicy and original. I like both, and would recommend trying both, for sure. I've kept this secret to myself for nearly 2 years, and now sharing it with the yelp community. Hopefully that gives you a sense of how much their ramen means to me! Last thing is: make a reservation online. it's fast and easy, will definitely save you a lot of waiting time on a weekday night. Forget about walking in for a seating during the weekend. Takashi is always bustling! As mentioned in previous reviews, their Japanese toilet is AWESOME.

I came here with a couple of friends, it was recommended by someone who said it appeared on the Anthony Bourdain show. I was a bit skeptical at first but ended up having a great experience both because of the quality of the food and the service. The place is not huge but was able to accommodate a group of 9 people, reservations are a must, otherwise you're looking at a 45min+ wait time. Appetizer: *Niku Uni-Chuck flap topped with sea urchin and fresh wasabi We decided to pick this as our "raw" appetizer, and immediately wanted to order anotha one. The taste is amazing, as someone else had mentioned, it literally melts in your mouth. The seasoning and sauce all blend well together, add a touch of wasabi and dip it in soy sauce- eat it using your hand. This is a must, you won't regret it. *Grandma's steamed beef shan This was our 'cooked' appetizer. Beef that is well seasoned, with a touch of spicy mayo on top in a white bun-another great tasting dish. This was recommended by the waitress, and I'm very happy we ended up ordering it Entree/Grill-Kalbi-short rib Â -Rosu rib eye Â -Beef belly The above three are another definite must. Just a minute for each side on the grill- it'll come out similar to medium to medium well. Kalbi just add lemon, that and the spices are enough to make this a delicious combination. Rosu, 45 seconds on each side, dip in sesame sauce and you'll be really happy. Beef belly too tasted amazing with the sesame sauce. Finally we ordered mignon steak, dip it in butter, then 45sec-1 min on each side then dip in butter for 30 seconds. The meat was tender, almost tasted like a marshmallow; amongst the best steaks I've had. Highly highly recommended Tikachi is not the cheapest place but definitely worth it, the food is great, service is above average and you'll leave very satisfied with the food

Ok,the wait time was 2 hours, early on a Saturday evening. Decided to wait (only ended up being one hour) and it was completely worth the wait. The food is super fresh and service is friendly and helpful - so don't worry if you've never done the Korean BBQ thing. I was so stuffed I didn't try the ice cream but I will most definitely be back.

I don't always give 5 Stars but, Takashi definitely deserves them ALL. Kobi beef absolutely melts in your mouth. Wait staff is very helpful, attentive and friendly. The Beef Schmaltz Crostini appetizer wasawwwwwwww-some.

came here for the midnight ramen - SO GOODHavent tried the regular BBQ food but definitely will be back 1. Grandmas spicy ramen - spicy paste, crispy intestines and broth were amazing 2. Foie gras addition - good seared foie gras but not necessary for the ramen (gets kind of soggy) and not necessarily worth $14 for ramen to be good (better as side dish at another restaurant)

This review is for the late night ramen only. I made reservations a week before, not wanting to risk walking in. We were still waiting on one more friend, but they sat us anyway which was great. He took a little while to arrive, but they never pushed or hurried us, which I really appreciated. We all decided to get the original ramen. Below is a breakdown of what I thought of it: -Beef broth: Very flavorful and rich but the garlic was a bit overpowering. I would have liked to taste more beef flavor.-Noodles: I don't typically like straight noodles, but I thought that they worked really well with the broth and had a good texture. -Braised beef belly: They were pretty generous with the amount of beef. I got some pieces that melted in my mouth and some that didn't, but overall it was very tender. -Crispy small intestines: I've had intestines that have tasted stinky before, but they do them well here. It helps a lot that they are fresh and thoroughly fried. I liked them more as a side to the ramen than actually in the ramen itself. (If you ask for them on the side, you seem to get more)-Soft-boiled egg: Nicely done. I wish we had a whole egg instead of half, but at least we got some egg. Â I don't know if I'll come back again just because it's a bit out of the way for me and the timing is a little inconvenient, but it was a good experience. The ramen is good and the restaurant has a nice feel to it. I'm glad that I got to check off another good ramen place on my list.
The foods was delicious but pricey. The waitress was nice and helpful. We ordered 5 dishes for 6 young adults, so we did not expect to have a big belly when we leave. It worths the trip.

Came here with my family for my mom's birthday. We made a reservation for 5:30 and surprisingly, there was already people waiting for the place to be open beforehand. (I don't know if they take walk-ins though.) We reserved for a party of 6 but one person couldn't make it which they were fine about. Maybe it was better off that way because the tables were pretty tight on space. The seats by the wall were just one bench line, but even if there is a bit of space to sit, the table space isn't that wide. My sister sat between me and her boyfriend and I felt like we were rubbing elbows throughout the dinner. My parents sat across from us on a bench meant for 3, but thankfully we only had 2 people sitting there because it would have felt Â quite tight. For starters we ordered the Niku uni ($26) which was chuck flap topped with sea urchin on top of a piece of seaweed. There was also wasabi and soy sauce for extra flavor. I felt like I had high hopes for this dish, but it wasn't as great as I hoped. Maybe because the uni didn't quite taste very fresh to me, so it was a bit of a let down. The other appetizer we got to try was the bone marrow and crawfish dumpling ($16) which was served with a Hong Kong style hot peanut oil sauce. This was actually quite good. I don't think I necessarily tasted the crawfish, but I did taste the bone marrow in it. I wish there was more flavor in the sauce though because looking at it, I thought it would have a little kick, but there wasn't much. (I liked that our waitress asked if we wanted to order enough for everyone to have a piece because the dish only came with 2.)As for the grilled meats, we order the Kobe Kalbi ($26), Harami ($22), beef belly ($22) and shio-tan/tongue ($17). We also ordered 4 bowls of rice with it. The quality of meat is definitely good. They also tell you how long to cook each meat for that's recommended by them, but if you prefer yours more cooked, then you can adjust the time. You don't get a lot of meat in each dish sadly, but each one tasted delicious. My sister was skeptical about the tongue, but she actually enjoyed it after trying it. I think the Harami or beef belly might be my favorite only because I really enjoy fatty meats and the melt in your mouth texture. I would definitely recommend trying this place out, but I don't think it's best to bring people who eat a lot or are super hunger unless you plan to empty your wallet. Our meal came out to about $215 and having 2 large men in our table, I was pretty sure they were not full from the meal. As for the service, it was ok, but nothing too great. When we got to the grilling part, not even half way into it, they had to stop it and add water to the grill. It took some time for it to warm back up and we weren't sure when it was ready. We just felt around and when it seemed pretty warm, we started grilling again. Then someone that worked there walked by said it was good to go. (Would have been nice if they were a little more attentive.) Other than that it was, everything was good. I wish I did read the fine print though because when I paid 20% gratuity was added for party of 5 or more. Sadly I was careless and didn't read the receipt either and tipped again. Next time, I definitely need to look at everything before paying. :(
Went here after watching Anothony Bourdain herald about it on tv. And he was so right. Great place in New York to eat. Very good vibe and the food is spectacular. Def get the Uni and wagyu

Came here for dinner with friends recently. It's a bit similar to Korean bbq but has more variety in cuts of meat and other innards. Marinated very well we enjoyed most of the meats. Only one we shouldn't have ordered was the oxtail. Grilling oxtail is just not a good idea. Oxtail needs to be braised and not grilled. When grilled it's tends to be tough and because oxtail contains some tendon the tendon is hard to get thru as well. Dessert soft serve was great! Service was great. Our server was super knowledgeable on the different cuts and made recommendations. Prices were on the higher side but we didn't mind as we liked most of what we had. Overall a good spot.

Hands down Takashi is one of the best barbecue places I have eaten at. I have tried multiple Korean Barbecue places in LA and nothing tops Takashi. You must order the Niku-Uni, which is wagyu beef topped with Uni wrapped in seaweed and lettuce. After your first order, I promise you that you'll want another. Now if you're just like me coming into Takashi to order the Cow Experience, the assortment of different beef cuts, make sure you call ahead for a reservation and have at least a party of four. Sadly, we didn't know and were a party of two. So instead of the cow experience, we ordered the Kobe Beef Kalbi, Beef Belly, and Nakaochi (between the rib meat) which were all fantastic. What's nice about the Nakaochi is that it isn't the traditional marinated meat, but seasoned with garlic and lemon instead. Overall, the service was amazing and our server Lisa was extremely friendly and helpful.

So, I had a great experience here and it was all due to our server, Lisa! Honestly, I had a bit to drink that night maybe at the table or before, so my memory is a bit fuzzy. But, I know I had one of my friends text me Lisa's name because she was so awesome and friendly! Sit in her section if you can.As for the food, we ordered quite a bit but I... only remember this tasty squishy thing but if you ask Lisa she'll probably recommend you the good stuff cause I definitely let her take the wheel that night too!

This is more of a 3.5 than a 4 but because of its quality, I'm rounding up.We ordered the chocolate meatball (sounds strange but undeniably tasty), uni on raw chuck (disappointed because I was expecting more flavor instead of chewy meat), beef belly (tough and very chewy), ribeye (melt in your mouth tender), tongue (regardless of where you go, it will always look like a slice of spam to me. Haha. But it wasn't bad).Overall, the food was good but it wasn't great. The ribeye and meatball were awesome. It's quite expensive so it's definitely a "special occasion" place. But service was friendly. Only parties of 4 or more can place a reservation.

My review is for the ramen only.Midnight ramen at Takashi. The hype is real. The midnight ramen here is legit and worth venturing to in the West Village. It's only available Friday + Saturday nights and by reservation at midnight + 1am. It's an intimate setting and perfect for date night or cap off a night of drinking. Â They also take walk-ins, but I recommend just making a reservation.We both got the Takashi Original (only two options to choose from). Â It was made with 100% beef broth and topped with US Kobe beef braised belly, crispy intestines, dried Japanese seaweed and organic soft boiled egg. The noodles were al dente and straight. Â It was pretty good even though I don't like straight noodles. Â It had a nice bite to it. Â The broth was delicious and had a garlicky beef salty taste. Â It had a lot of ingredients in the broth so that gave it a lot flavor which was awesome. Â The beef was a thick cut. Â It was very fatty and flavorful. Â It was also tender like steak so if you like your steak like that, you will like this. Â My favorite part was the crispy intestines. Â It tasted like pork rinds and was absolutely delicious. Â The egg was good and was cooked well, but the egg was not runny and too well done.I would definitely give this place a try if you're a ramen lover.
Go with the sashimi and sushi deluxe over just the sushi deluxe, it is way more bang for your buck or you can be like me and live with regret.

Had a dinner with my cousin and two brothers here. I'm not gonna lie, based off their menu, I was a little skeptical about dining at this restaurant. I wasn't sure this was gonna be something I would enjoy. I definitely am not a Korean BBQ expert as I rarely eat this but after this dinner, you better believe it's gonna be part of my dinner ideas.They give you some kimchi and other little small dishes to start that are tasty. We ordered the saki and they have a large selection of different saki glasses to choose from to your liking. We started with the tartare that comes with an egg on top which they mix right at your table. The tartare was delicious and I recommended to get as your starter. The other starter was the famous niki-Uni. It's over beef but the uni is somewhat overpowering in a good way of you like uni. We ordered three different types of beef for our entrees. The ribeye, the filet and one other I can't remember. Each meat has different instructions on how to cook, and what to dip it in. It was all very tasty.For dessert we ordered the one with green tea sauce and a caramel. I prefer the caramel even though the green tea is definitely the more popular. Can't really go wrong with either so why not true both?!I definitely want to come back to try the cow experience. Definitely more on the wild side, but if Anthony Bourdain approves, then ms too.

First off, Takashi is the size of one of my closets. Probably about two dozen seats- no reservations for three people or less. So we got there at 6 on a Sunday and had a 90 minute wait. The service is great, everyone was very friendly. The food is pricey for small portions- and much of that consists of a few ounces of a variety of cow parts that you have to cook yourself. So they have a good thing going for themselves here- laughing all the way to the bank, I bet. Some of the appetizers are out there- and that is a compliment- I had a problem narrowing it down to the four that me and the wife shared- bone marrow and crawfish dumplings, foie gras- stuffed mini burger with chocolate sauce, cow balls served escargot-style, and raw beef with sea urchin and shisho leaf. All quite good. For the 'grill your own cow parts" section of our meal, I ordered the chef's selection of liver, heart, sweetbreads and first and third stomach -yes you have a choice of three of the four stomachs of a bovine creature- they don't have the fourth for some reason. I guess even Takashi has limitations on what they will feed their customers. I also ordered cow aorta because, what the hell!. It was...chewy. Lots of beer needed to get that down.

I've been wanting to try this place for ages, and finally made my way to NY to sit down and chow down. The service was Impeccable. Everyone I was with loved the food and it was presented beautifully. Will be coming back again.

A trendy spot for some quality Asian BBQ, definitely give this spot a try. Prices may seem a bit steep, it is worth it for the quality of cuts and ingredients you get to enjoy. Make sure to secure a reservation beforehand if you are coming a larger party. Do order their Niku-Uni and Squid Ink Rice - they are superbly unforgettable.Late night bonus: ramen!

What an unique gem in West Village! Â I tried coming here 2 times (unsuccessfully) prior to our visit. Â The first time, Takashi was closed and the second time, there was a 3.5 hour wait time at 830 pm. Â We learned our lesson and made a reservation. Â When we first walked in, I was delightfully greeted by an entertaining, educational, and cute mural on spanning across 2 walls. Â The mural educated patrons on how to cook and the benefits of horumon (discarded goods aka "grilled guts"). Takashi is a Korean - Japanese bbq joint, serving raw and grilled meat - rib eye to the various different stomachs of cow.If you are an adventurous eater, Takashi will definitely be a treat! They had calf's brain cream and testicles on the menu!!!! For those a bit more conservative, the menu may be a bit limited but delicious nonetheless. Â  We tried the yooke (beef tartare), niku-uni (chuck flap with sea urchin), and several grilled options (shoulder, beef belly, one of the stomachs, and ox tail). Â Everything was fantastic and marinated well. The marinade flavors complemented the variety of meats served. Our party was mixed with both the adventurous and the conservative; so, it was a bit difficult for us to choose what to eat. It might be helpful to go with a group or with someone who eats similarly as yourself. Â The service was great! The waitress was very nice and helpful in making suggestions. Â The only reason why I couldn't give a full five stars was portion size vs price point. Â The portions are on the smaller side and the food is definitely not cheap. I'm wasn't sure I wanted to drop over 20 dollars per plate when trying new things. Â Overall, I would most definitely recommend Takashi to my daring friends who want to try something new in the city. Â Note: Takashi also serves ramen, which My husband and I heard was delicious. Â Unfortunately, ramen is a late night menu item and only available after midnight on Fridays and Saturdays.

What can I say....glorified Korean restaurant. Left with a bigger bill, less food, same small, more attidue about being loud when honestly we spent 600+ dollars (your welcome) and the food wasnt that good at all. Mayne you shouldnt confuse yourself with a cladsy restaurant. Keep it simple stupids. If I wanted korean bbq id.go to ktown for better food without the bs.
Best BBQ I've tried. I thought it was an exaggeration when someone said 'Meat melted in my mouth', but it's so true.

I love Takashi!But they are too popular, always have to wait to enjoy the deliciousness.Needless to say the meat is fresh and tender, their appetizers are good as well.A must try spot in Manhattan!And you can pick your own sake cup :D

Wow, this place is great! I went in with my friends. The staff is great and service was fast. The lines are long though so make sure to call ahead for a reservation. We had a wait a while to get seated - this place is very popular. We had Niku-Uni, Kalbi and Rosu. Everything was great and amazing to the palette. Would definitely come back.

1. table only 2hour limited for us. 2. waitress came every minute while we were eating and asked "are you still hungry? want to order more?"She made me crazy and i didn't even finish my beef on grill!!! i couldn't enjoy my meal at all.3. extra small cabbage charged $2.004. no ramen noodles for weekend.5. no credit card from chase. LOLshe said their system is old. "maybe only for this week? " i don't know what does this mean. 6. Not worth 200.00 for two. Â won't go again!7. if you want to have kalbi BBQ, go to Korean restaurant instead. This is so fake kalbi.

Mind blowing experience. Â Their meat was just amazing. Â I was like OMG, I am not a meat lover, Â but the meat served by them is so juicy and tender, Â I wish I could eat more. Â My favorite is beef belly. It is a pricey place, Â we (5 girls) ordered about 7 dishes (all come in small portion) and the bill is about $220. Â Will probably come back only if I want to eat MEAT.

I came here for midnight ramen. I arrived 15 mins prior, but they told me they were 15 mins behind. Kind of annoying since we made reservations. We were forced to walk around the neighborhood for half an hour, but not much seemed to be open. Although we were the first ones to check in, they called people in at a different order, possibly by who reserved first. They only have two kinds of ramen. Beef or spicy beef. I chose beef. I've never had beef ramen before and it was pretty good. The broth tasted of beef, but it wasn't heavy, like I would have expected. It was a flavorful, yet light broth. Would definitely consider coming back.

Midnight Ramen Review!I made a Friday night reservation on Monday at 5 pm, which is when they start accepting emails for the week's reservations. They do accept walk-ins now, so depending on how quickly people eat that night, you could get lucky.This was honestly the best ramen I've had in the city (and I've eaten at almost all the other well-known ones). My friend got the Takashi's Original and I got Grandma's Spicy Ramen. The original has a really flavorful but clean taste and the spicy one has a nice kick to it. The only thing I didn't like about Grandma's Spicy Ramen was that it was pretty oily, other than that, it was delicious. Seating is a little awkward cause the grill is right in front of you and not covered.Service is super friendly.

Hands down the best and most memorable meal I've had on my visit to New York. I came here for my boyfriend's birthday. We arrived around 6 and there was a 45 minute wait. Not bad! The hostess took our number down and we headed to a nearby bar for some cocktails as we waited. An extra tip, make your way to Hudson Clearwater for some tasty drinks (def won't be disappointed). Anyways, we ended up getting called back earlier than the 45 min wait - WIN since we were so hungry. Our sever was great and super attentive. We ordered the testicargot and the uni-kuni (I don't remember the name) to start off with. The testicargot is exactly what it sounds like, testicles escargot style. The sauce was on point but the testicles were too hard and chewy for my taste. We just wanted to try it. We ordered a number of things but I won't get too into it. BUT for sure, get the beef belly. I've had a lot of beef belly in my day but not like this. It literally melted in your mouth. Everything I got I would definitely get again and it was well worth the wait.

I've been here twice for a birthday dinner and their special ramen late night weekend special. I can't tell you how amazing this place is. It's a Japanese tapas style of menu, so you get to taste a little bit of everything on the menu. The signature must try dish is the Niku-Uni (Raw Kobe beef topped with Uni)! Also, if you want to sample a little bit of everything the Horumon (Chef's selection of meats) is the way to go! The customer service was on-point and always provided information of everything on the menu and how long to cook different types of meats.The final coup-de-grace was the ice cream, which is their soft served Madagascar Vanilla, topped with "the works." Their toppings and your sauce of choice perfectly complemented the best soft serve I have ever had! For a group of 4 people, the bill came to about $210 including tip, which ain't too shabby either! Â Overall, this is probably THE Japanese BBQ place to go to in NYC, and definitely call and make reservations ahead of time (groups of 4 or more) to minimize the wait.

We came for the cow experience. Have been looking forward to it for a long time and finally made it! Logistics: need to make reservation 24h in advance if you want to order cow experience. $45 per person and everyone needs to participate. Reservation is only available for group more 4 people.Cow experience: 16 pieces from 16 different part of the cow, including the tongue, stomach, shoulder, intestine, Kobe etc. Basically you get one pie of everything on their menu except the artery of the cow. Each piece has a unique texture. All pieces are covered with garlic and oil. Nothing marinated. Dessert: they only have one dessert, that is the vanilla ice cream. Very rich and cream. Green Tea sauce was great! Full of match flavor. We also ordered the Uni and meatball in chocolate BBQ sauce as appetizers. The uni was fresh and sweet. The meat ball has very interesting mixed salty and sweet taste. In general, definitely an unique and fun experience. A good option if you have friends visiting NYC. The quality of the beef is definitely great but it is on the pricier side. Gyu-kaku would be a cheaper alternative for Japanese BBQ on daily basis.

NIKU-UNIniku uni. niku uniiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiii!!!!!! I kept seeing pictures of these pieces of uni on top of beef on top of shiso leaf on top of nori. So I had to get them. They were good! But so little. I can eat 50 of them. Also got Chef's selection -- there was cow's stomach #2, stomach #3, liver... etc.... This place reminds me of Gyu-Kaku except smaller and more expensive (I spent $96). We ordered a lot of random meats. My makgeoli with yuzu and yuzu spritzer were yuzulicious. And like every other Asian BBQ place, you and every article of clothing will smell like barbecue and meat. Just sayin'. They take reservations!
The heart, liver and stomach is tasty. Don't like the beef tartare and takashi KFC...The portion is way too small. Won't be back for bbq, but will try midnight ramen next time

I love this bbq joint!!! Their midnight ramen special is just beyond amazing!! My boyfriend always gets the spicy ramen and I mix it up between the original and spicy ramen depending on what I'm in the mood for. Both of them are equally delicious! The waiters are very friendly and attentive. The ambience is very hip and casual. Had a great experience overall!

This place isn't for everyone price wide, but if you want to have some serious piece of meat, this is the place to go in town.Takashi is not some mid-level Korean BBQ, it's more like a very delicate high-end joint. You just have to go as early as possible, otherwise the wait list will stack up so quick that you'll miss the perfect time to enjoy the food.The place was very cozy with a bit of style, all the ingredients that we ordered was very fresh and carefully-chosed. All the staff member were friendly and the service is good, might because of the time we came in (beginning of the dinner service)If you come by NYC, definitely check this place out.I recommend the Uni-beef appetizers, the home-made icecream and the bone marrow.
I get delivery from this place. Solid sushi and probably the best for delivery within a reasonable price point.

This place is absolutely worth the hype. By far one of the best restaurants in the city. Arrive early since the place is tiny and can get crowded quickly, they don't take reservations for couples so beware. We had the specials of the day and whatever our server suggested that night and walked out of there super happy and satisfied!
The food and the service were just okay considering the price. When we tried to ask the waitress a question about our order, she said "Jesus Christ" twice.

One of the best Food experiences I've had!!(minus the 3hr wait, but totally worth it.) it's been weeks since I had the most recommended Niku-Uni and I can still taste it in my mouth!!!. The seaweed, shiso leaf, raw beef, and uni (sea urchin) compliments each other perfectly and they just melts in your mouth. I'm a big fan of Uni and beef sashimi (and everything raw actually) I was literally loosing my mind over how good this tasted. It is THE BEST thing I ever had, whoever invented this dish deserves a giant trophy. The Yooke is also amazing, which is grounded raw beef mixed with a raw quail egg. They also have an option for Kobe beef which is much more expensive. TBH the apps were SO AMAZING that I didn't really care about the grill afterwards Â (which was pretty good as well, def recommend the beef belly). The dessert (I got the choose-all toppings option, because you just have to) was a nice finish to the superb meal. I highly recommend this place, but be prepared to wait 2hr+ or go on a weekday!

Takashi has really impressed my taste buds! I've always been a fan of Japanese and Korean Barbeque, but I felt like they had an assortment of high end raw meats, a twist on the meat dishes with other elements (like the Kobe toppd with Uni), and just straight up yummy peculiar cuts (like tongue, cheek, etc.).The restaurant was much smaller than anticipated and because they don't take reservations for small groups, my gf Lana and I were quoted a 90 mins wait around 7:30PM on a weeknight. Indeed- it took a full 90 mins so we left and came back and fortunately they did text us with an update leading up to the time so that was helpful.Everything was nicely presented, original, and straight-up delicious. Yes, it's pricey- but the quality of the meat and cuts as well as the taste is of utmost excellence. I loved the Kobe + Uni, Tartare with Quail Egg, and tongue the best!4 Stars because service was friendly but somewhat fickle, and the whole ordeal in the long-wait makes it a really big time commitment out of someones night as it requires several hours. I wish they took reservations and if so I'd frequent this place more often!Be prepared to pay $60+ per person. More with alcohol.

doesn't take reservations for less than a group of 4. Went in 15 minutes before it opened on a friday night and I got seated right away. Score!!!  bone marrow dumplings (probably one of my favorite things in the menu) -- it came out and the waitress poured a hot and sizzling sauce over it. It was such a surprise and so deliciousramen quesadilla--- waitress grills it right in front of you and then garnishes it with sauce and furikake. Â this was good, but inside is tuna, and I'm not a huge fan of tuna so it wasn't my favorite. the infamous Uni and kobe-- first off this dish is so beautiful-- the uni was so fresh, however I felt like the raw kobe beef was not that tender and the consistency was a bit chewy and tough. Beef belly- was not that memorable. The Kalbi was very good- especially in the Takashi marinade. If you order meat- get everything in the Takashi marinade- it is so tasty.Lastly the homemade madagascar vanilla soft serve with the "works" It comes with different sauces that you can choose from, and we chose the green tea. They put it in a little cannister where you can drizzle it all over your ice cream. The ice cream was so flavorful and creamy and a great ending to our meal. Overall some of the items are a hit or miss and this place and it is pricey. However I give it 3 stars because this place is so theatrical. Â The Â waitress worked really hard and it was so fun to watch the food come out. Everything we ordered was aesthetically appeasing.

4.25 to be exact. Â This is a review for their midnight ramen offerings.To give a little background upon getting an opportunity to try their midnight ramen, this is offered Friday and Saturday nights from 12am to 2am. Â  Reservations are required and can be made that week by e-mailing them at ramen@takashinyc.com the Monday prior beginning at 5pm. Â They would have seating at 12am and 1am available. Â I had a 12am reservation with a few friends and upon getting there it took us a little while to get seated because they were finishing up for the night of their regular food offerings. Â Once I got seated, I was handed the menu and my experience started. Â They offer only one actual bowl of ramen, with a spicy and non-spicy option. Â It is custom-made thin noodles with a beef-based broth, braised beef belly, crispy small intestines, slice of seaweed, and a soft boiled egg. Â The spicy option (called Grandma's Spicy) has a spicy red paste added to this bowl. Â In addition, if you are a baller, you can also add Foie Gras (!) to your ramen for $14. Â I opted not to get the Fio Gras and tried the Grandma's Spicy Ramen.My verdict? This bowl of ramen was one of the best ramen bowls I have had in the NYC area. Â The noodles tasted awesome, the broth was very flavorful and not overwhelming, and the beef belly was tender and delicious! Â For me, the crispy small intestines only add the idea of eating something crispy in the ramen, as they did not contribute to any type of flavor for me. Â I could live without the cripsy small intestines in here and have the same verdict on taste. Â  Even though this ramen is only offered at two nights a week at midnight, I would recommend any ramen-lover to venture out and try this bowl of ramen at least once. Â I know it is an inconvenient time to eat (unless you love to party late) but I personally would definitely come back here for their ramen. Â Do not forget what I mentioned about reserving though! This is a must to get in and try the ramen! Â Maybe next time I come here I will add the Foie Gras... Decisions... Decisions..
Hands done the best fucking ramen in NYC! I gained 15 pounds around my belly last couple of years due to eating it!
High end Japanese BBQ. But I didn't find this is much better than normal gyukaku. The ambient is neat though.

Everything is so good! Beef is so sexy! I recommend beer with BBQ stuff. Sake with raw beef appetizers. For BBQ the beef belly is must have! Appetizers I think the buns are good but not special enough so I will say go for beef tartare and the uni. Ice cream at the end is something to cool you down and ends your dinner at the perfect note. Loved everything about it.

I haven't come back in a while since my latest late night ramen adventure. I realize I have been missing out on so much. This place continues to impress me beyond words. My taste buds have not been satiated in a very long time. absolutely AMAZING. Greatest fusion of korean and japanese flavors I ever encountered. The chef absolutely knows what he is doing. I have paid more at restaurants that I don't even think are 1/10th as good as this place. It is a must come for foodies everywhere. As a party of 2, we had a wait of 1 hour. We walked around while we waited and came without expecting how amazing this place is. This restaurant literally made my day 10 times better. Start: -complimentary kimchi, crunchy home grown cabbage with miso dressing, bean sproutsGrill/ready to eat: Â -beef tartare - with lemon juice squeezed and a quail egg mixed with scallions-the uni (yuuke) - with uni and shizo leaves on top of roasted seaweed -the Tongue experience with special ponzo and sesame dipping saucesThe above was so good that later on we ended up ordering the chef's selection of offals (which included marinated liver, heart, sweetbreads and inner/outer stomach)Drinks: - yuzu soju spritzer (pretty strong flavors)-makkeoli (white peach flavor, fruity and fragrant)Dessert -they only have 1 on the menu which is vanilla ice cream(it sort of tasted like it had ground sesame in it too) with choices of toppings and sauce. It also comes with a bit of edible gold on top. I loved the green tea sauce (if you taste it by itself you can taste the grounded matcha tea leaves). amazingly well done. They had the choice of special topping of halva which adds a bit of crunchiness to the ice cream. so good. For the indecisive ones out there, they also have a choice with all the toppings Definitely not for vegetarians or for anyone allergic to sesame seeds or dislike garlic flavor. Otherwise, i would recommend this place to anyone who is in, around, or planning on visiting NYC. This palce is definitely worth the wait.

This place is amazing! The only thing I don't like about this place is the fact that they don't take reservations for 1-3 people and that there's a line, almost always. Niku-uni is a MUST if you love uni as much as I do. I also had Takashi's KFC (Kobe beef tartare, foie gras, and caviar). You can bbq unusual or different parts that aren't offered in the usual K-town bbq spots. Everything tasted really fresh and I liked how the marinade wasn't too overpowering.

yes yes YAS to this place. just yes.it is a little pricey, but what isn't in the city. all the meat orders that we ordered were super flavorful, we didn't try any of the weirder meats. my favorites were the beef tongue and tartare. we also ordered this one meat, can't remember what, but the waiter came over and cooked it for us and sliced it into pieces for us to eat.love the service here and i love the smell.

This place is really small and intimate but trendy. The waiter was extremely helpful and recommended most of our dishes. It's fun that they let you cook the meat - usually the waiter cooks the meat at most kbbq places. Everything we ordered was absolutely delicious:- Squid Ink Rice: served on a banana leaf and was left on the grill to sizzle.- Filet Mignon: came with an amazing garlic butter sauce that was placed on the grill to cook the meat. We killed every last bit of the sauce!- Beef Tartare: a lot of great flavors. It comes with a quail egg and the waiter mixes it in for you- Beef Belly: my favorite meat of the night! So fatty and delicious.- Niku Uni: very unique bite of seaweed, raw chuck, and UniPortions are quite small and the price point is high. The bill came out to about $110 per person but the food was worth it! Overall, great dining experience but should probably be reserved for more special occasions.

I love the concept of Takashi. Basically any, literally any, part of a cow (including testicles) are available for your consumption. All sorts of meats/cuts you may or may not have had much experience with can be sought out here. The marinades are great and the flavors are brought out well. Kitchen food is also pretty delicious and unique.The space is small, but the decor and venue are nice. The grill and vents are clean, and service is impeccable. My only concern is that I'm not so sure some of the plates are worth the price point. Nevertheless, it's a great experience.

We visited Takashi on a Wednesday evening at 7pm and put our names on the wait list after being told there was a 2 hour wait. We then went across the street to have drinks and wait it out but promptly received a call 8 minutes later notifying us that our table was ready. Not sure if this was an unusually quick seating, a tourist-repellant tactic, or some combination of the two, but we were sitting in front of our personal Takashi Japanese grill station with sake and soju in surprisingly short order.The ambience is casual with lots of smoke and a Japanese grill at each table. Our waiter was informative & speedy and he had an Australian accent.To start we had the grandmom's steamed beef shank buns (4 stars) and the bone marrow + crawfish dumplings (3.5 stars). Both excellent. For our mains we ordered the filet mignon special (5 stars) and the chef's special (5 stars - a bit adventurous and includes beef heart, liver, 1st and 4th stomachs, and sweetbreads) which was delicious and made us feel like we got the full experience. The filet comes with a mini skillet with butter and garlic cloves to simmer the filet mignon cubes in after searing them on the grill, but we basically dipped everything in it and ate the caramelized garlic cloves like candy. We ended with the sole dessert option of soft serve ice cream + toppings (3 stars), which was a tasty finish. All in all a tasty and filling dinner (4+ stars), and perfect for a celebration or small group outing.
