One of my favorite restaurants on my NYC trip. Â I'm already biased because I love anything yakiniku- or Korean bbq-like but the food here was truly exceptional. Â I was a dummy and didn't do enough research beforehand to know that you need to reserve the $35/person Whole Cow Experience where you get 16 cuts of meat. Â All the items on the menu are pricey here so it's definitely something to consider unless you have specific meats you do or do not want to eat.I ended up trying the angus beef, beef belly, tongue, liver, first stomach, second stomach, sweetbreads, and cheek. I loved everything, especially the meats there were marinated. Â The server will tell you the optimal cooking time for each meat and you should trust him/her on that. Â The meat comes out perfectly tender and safe (I'm assuming) for your stomach.Before you order, you get complimentary kimchi, salad with miso dressing, and bean sprouts. Â However, if you want an additional dish of kimchi, it's $2. Â A bit much in my opinion. Â The service is great and they changed our metal tray like 5x? Â It was barely building up and it would be swapped out without question.It's intimate here and I wouldn't come with more than 4 people. Â If you're really into AYCE places, this isn't for you because you're eating here to converse with friends and drink. Â The meat may not necessarily fill you up unless you're willing to fork out the cash.
Great service from Reece. The food was excellent. Great atmosphere! If you're in New york try this place, call for reservations.

I made a reservation for party of 4, but two people ended up not showing up. I called again to let them know and they were able to work something out for me. I simply came after seeing their "raw beef uni" dish online and I am only in town for one night. I was glad to be able to eat here. Food came fairly quickly and btw their logo isn't super noticeable from the outside. I enjoyed the uni dish and I also ordered a beef tongue to cook. It was very tasty and the last thing I got was their home made ice cream with salted caramel sauce and rice flour dumplings. Oh, they also sprinkled gold flakes on top of it. The girls were nicer than my waiter, but whatever... I still had a decent time. 56 bucks for 3 dishes isn't too bad.

Dare I say this is a fancier version of Gyu-Kaku! It essentially is. Over-priced for what you get.Most of the meats you get are marinated so you dont get the taste of the supposed high quality beef. Also, beef is the only bbq option.

Came here for the midnight ramen, left completely satisfied.Apparently this place is normally a yakiniku (Japanese BBQ) place in the day. On Friday and Saturday nights from 12AM to 2AM, it turns to a cute little ramen joint. the reservation process is pretty simple: the Monday ahead of when you want to visit, you email them at 5PM to get a reservation (full details here: takashinyc.com/reservatiâ¦)My friend and I snagged a reservation for 12AM a couple Fridays ago. The restaurant is very small and intimate and I can see how it would be hard to get in here during regular hours without a reservation. We got seated quickly, but we also happened to be one of only maybe two other parties there at the time.The menu is extremely simple, which I actually really appreciated. There are only two options: original, or spicy. I opted for the original since, well, I can't eat anything beyond mildly spicy for the life of me, while my friend ordered the spicy (since she's a champ and eats hot peppers in her sleep, pretty much). The prices are steep, $16 and $17 for the original and spicy, respectively, but the portion sizes are large, the food is good, and you're really paying more for the experience than anything.Service was fast and our bowls of ramen came out quickly. I didn't expect the ramen to be as good as it is, to be honest. The broth is a beef broth, and normally the bowl comes with one large piece of kobe braised beef belly, intestines (I kindly asked for no intestines), and an egg. Extra toppings are pretty much all of those, foie gras ($14 for this extra topping!!!), and you have the option to kae dama for an additional $4.The beef broth was fantastic. It was very light and flavorful, not thick and buttery like it is at Ippudo and sometimes, even Totto. The noodles were cooked to perection with just the right amount of chewiness.What really won my heart though, was the piece of braised beef. This place sure does know how to cook a good piece of beef, which is expected given it's a yakiniku joint during the day. The braised beef belly was so tender and juicy, and marinated / seasoned to perfection. Literally when I bit into it, I could taste the burst of flavor in my mouth.I wouldn't come here too frequently just because 1) I don't think I could afford dishing out $16 for a bowl of ramen too often and 2) my waistline can't afford to keep having a huge bowl of ramen at midnight. I food coma-ed pretty hard after the ramen.A good experience though for those in the area, as the food is extremely high quality.

While waiting in line at the other really famous ramen restaurant in East Village my friend talked about this yakiniku place that serves ramen late at night for only 2 hours a night twice a week. 10/10 the most hipster bougie thing I've ever heard but I had to have it. Reservations were made for the next night at 1AM. All I could think about was how is it even feasible to operate for 4 hours a week, regardless I HAD to have it. Arriving it seemingly looked like a low key restaurant, really dimmed, and unsuspecting of the glory that was set to unfold. Grandma's spicy ramen ($17) ordered and contemplation of whether or not I'm an idiot for eating a $17 bowl of ramen. Oh man, it was definitely justified, especially after the other place in East Village. Best ramen I've had ever? No. Best in America? Call Good Morning America because I've found a gem in this saturated pool of ramen restaurants. The broth is made of beef bones from their day job restaurant, garlic (lots), ginger, and some other spices. Hold your chapstick because the soup will moisturize your lips with its glistening fatty horumon broth but keep your mouthwash close by, you'll need a lot of it to get the garlic out. It's like eating a extra marbleized piece of beef lightly seared melting away in your mouth with a moderately spicy nutty finish. The perfect al dente bite of their noodles will make any noodle fan come to tears. Take a bite of beef belly that'll just continue the buttery experience or have some of the bacon like crispy fried intestines giving you the texture crunch. Its hard to hate on hipsters when you realize you are one because you loved the thrill and experience from Takashi after way dark.

Wow.. Just Wow.. Had an incredible dinner here last night. Every dish we ordered was fantastic, including the free appetizer we didn't order. This is meat lover's paradise so expect the proverbial meat coma after this.We had the chuck tartar, spring sukiyak, red red kimchi, Niku-Uni (talk about the perfect bite of food), the beef belly, the between-the-rib beef, the steamed beef shank bun. Everything was incredibly tasty and very high quality ingredients.We wrapped up with the one dessert on the menu - The Homemade Madagascar Vanilla Ice Cream with the works.. Again, WOW.. if you're going to have one dessert, it better be good, and this is fantastic.Like I said, Wow is the word.. Be prepared to spend some money, it's not a cheap place, but you don't feel cheated because the quantity and quality is fantastic.

Strict seating rules, cramped but trendy place. Smoking hot, good cut of meat, a variety of choices, including beef organs. Tried beef and uni as appetizer, creamy and minerality from uni paired with chewy and sweetness from beef laid a heavy foundation for the whole meal. Beef shoulder loin was great, other cuts good too. Masculine space, guess the smoky and carnival style keeps a lot ladies away. Overall an enjoyable place good for small group of friends.

What we ate:Beef Belly Filet Mignon with Garlic Butter (forgot name on menu)Why its great:The waiter we had was amazing, I think his name was Reese. Big props to him, the menu is a little crazy at first, I've never really thought about precisely what part of the animal I was truly eating. He helped us navigate around the menu and recommended some great stuff. You get to try a variety of new things and its so fun to have almost your own personal kitchen right in front of you. Everything is absolutely delicious and it was definitely some of the best meat I have ever had. One of the best nights of my life. Why it wasn't so great:Okay so the only reason this is not getting a 5 star review is because the wait is LONG (two hours+). My boyfriend and I traveled around the city trying to get into another restaurant and we could not so we ended up here for a two-hour wait (well worth it though for reasons above). It is also a pretty small place and kind of weird seating/cramped. Side-note: Their bathroom is also pretty weird (one bathroom, one toilet) and small, tucked away at the side and the door is huge. Overall:Delicious, for meat-eaters, great service, I have been salivating for beef belly again! The atmosphere is very casual and cool, you can .also see chefs preparing meats if you sit near their table.

I made reservations for a group of 4 which I highly recommend doing before you visit with a group. Food was delicious, must get the Niku-Uni and the Takashi's K-F-C was soooo delicious. It's a pricey place but the quality it up there. Definitely will come back for a special occasion.

We got Takashi Midnight ramen.Got there at 1130 and was seated pretty promptly. Â This is my 4th coming back it seems the crazy hype is a bit done. Walk ins are totally possible. Â We did book a reservation at 12 for 8. Â There aren't much options just spicy or non spicy. Â I love the spicy and the crunchy intestines ! Â  My friend got extra kobe beef belly, you could get extra noodles but one bowl is pretty filling. Â The egg is just right everytime i've visted. Â I say its a great choice to try once in awhile.

I tried this place on my recent visit to NY. It's a little pricey but worth it. We ordered Yooke and Niku-uni and for the grill tongue and U.S. Kobe Marbled Chuck-flat Steak. The food is fantastic, service is wonderful, and there is such a nice atmosphere.

Food was incredible. Only complaint is that portions are small and price is higher than most places, but the quality and taste of the food gives them 5 stars! Also, definitely check out their bathroom

High quality, delicious meats. The dessert was also a knock out. Yes, it's pricey. But you are for sure getting what you paid for. I'd recommend the Kobe short rib, tsurami, and beef belly. And if you like sea urchin, or feeling adventurous if you haven't had it, get yourself the Niku-uni!

A bit overpriced for the hype, in my opinion. Â I've had my fair share of Japanese BBQ, and I would say that I enjoyed all of the meat selections we ordered. Â  The SHORT RIB and RIB EYE were both juicy, flavorful, and melted in my mouth. Â The HARAMI and TONGUE were also delicious, but nothing too memorable. The feel that the NIKU-UNI is overhyped. Â It is visually appealing, and how does the description not sound appetizing? Â The Kobe beef used was pretty chewy-- I expected this to be more tender. Â The uni was okay-- it didn't taste fresh (you can see the purple vein). Â Overpriced for the quality, nothing spectacular. The SPICY PICKLED CUCUMBERS was a nice side to go along with the meats. Â I'm usually fan of pickled veggies to be more fermented. Â This one tasted fresher, so it didn't taste as pickled. The BONE MARROW and CRAWFISH DUMPLINGS were good too, but not something I would order again. Â This tasted like a Canto-style dumpling, except made with bone marrow. Â This was served on top of a hollowed out bone, so this looked pretty cool. Â I'm not sure if I could really taste the bone marrow-- this was pretty oily. Overall, I would come here again for the meat, but I would try some other appetizers the next time I visit.
Took the family here and everyone had a great time. Â The Kobe beef literally melts in your mouth. Â Make sure you get the ice cream dessert and ask for the works.
so great ;) after watching Samurai Gourmet, we had a craving for grilled meat and cold beer. This was beyond great. Â Wait can be tremendous but it is well worth it.

Holy crap. Believe the hype. It's really really good. Â Helps that Anthony Bourdain was dining right next to us. The niku-uni is an amazing flavor blast. Â The meatballs were awesome and it just goes on. Mimi our server was awesome as well. Â Yes. It's expensive but it's worth it. Â Coming again and again to this place

Not worth the hype or money. Terrible reservation policy too! They won't take reservations for parties of 1-3 and you'll need to walk in and wait. I came with my boyfriend and had to wait 1 and half hour when we were told it was only an hour wait. What else was two girls that came into the resturant after we left our name on the list said they had a reservation. They got seated for a party of 3 before we did.... How is it possible that they got a reservation?Another thing was we placed orders for ramen quesadilla as part of the appetizers. After our 3rd appetizer was presented, the server came to let us know that the last order of the ramen quesadilla was given to another table..... We turned around 10 minutes later and saw that the order went to the table that came after us.... I really understand how they pace orders... Like this whole experience just didn't seem fair....As for the food, sure the quality of the beef was really good but is it really worth $40 for two slices of beef that's just grilled? Not really... I guess ur just paying for the service n quality. All the appetizers were pretty mediocre. Their crawlfish dumplings tasted like ur avg pork ball in a dimsum restaurant. The niku uni was good but tbh nothing special... Just uni on beef. At the end we ordered the dessert with all the toppings.... The rice dumplings were probably frozen because when I bit into it, it was like solid hard core... I guess with all the positive reviews they received here i expected more but i don't think i will be returning. You can easily find something just as good and better for the amount they are charging you.

I never head of Takashi until Bourdain recommended it on his show, The Layover. I immediately went as I love Korean barbecue. I went tonight (Friday night) and had to wait roughly 45-50 minutes for two people. When we were seated, our waiter came right over to us and was very informative/thorough with explaining the menu. To start, we got the beef tartare and the the pork buns. The beef tartare was delicious- it comes with a quail egg, which the waiter mixes in for you. The pork buns were different than I've had, but were also great. They bring out the bun and meat separately and let you construct it on your own- spicy mayo included. For our entree, we got a special- beef and foie gras. It was absolutely delicious. We also got the Kobe short rib-- which is served with a raw egg yolk to dip in. Yum. The great thing about this restaurant is that you can tell the beef is of great quality. I will definitely be back again. If you have room- get the ice cream. I got mine with salted caramel and it was great. Lastly- good sake list! **Beware, the grill gets very hot, so you may leave without your eye brows, but it's 100% worth it.
Love this place, sukiyaki fois gras is to die for. Prices can add up quickly but the meats are better than any ktown BBQ I've been to.

I really wanted to like this place because of their niku - uni but I find this place to be overhyped and overpriced. I was still hungry after I left and for two people our bill was 140 bucks.. We had niku uni, beef tartare, beef tongue sampler, matcha maekolli, nakokochi kalbi and fish bone dumpling with bone marrow. The uni and beef was fighting with eachother because both are great things on its own, it was overwhelming in flavor. The beef tartar I liked surprisingly even though it was raw beef. They mix it with a quail egg. Matcha maekolli was a rip off for a cup it was 12 bucks and there was no matcha flavor.. Neither was there much alcohol. The kalbi and tongue sampler was okay, small portions though... The fish bone dumpling was almost a hazard, I nearly choked on a bone... I wanted to keep the bone marrow and doggy bag it but the server said they need it?!?! And he refused to give it to me... I didn't know they reused bones for future dishes.. And I thought I paid for the bone since its in my dish ??? Overall, I'm not interested in coming back not only are you not allowed to make reservations ( unless it's a party of four or more ) you have to go in person to put your name down, the wait is usually 45 mins up to 2 hours.. Overpriced, overhyped, disappointed.
I guess if you like offal you'd love this place. I don't and even though their food is good, portions were very small for the price. Now the guts that used to get thrown away can be monetized!

Takashi is currently my #1 restaurant in Manhattan. Â It is not only an experience, but it has some of the best food I have had! Â If you can muster up and do Midnight Ramen one night, i highly recommend making a reservation! But for the normal dinner, some of the courses I recommend include: - Ramen Quesadilla (do the 1/2) as you don't want to eat to much as the meat is so good- Foie Gras - Kobe Beef Â PROS:- Great ambience - Servers are amazing! Â Friendly, helpful, and know exactly what to do- Quality meat- Text you when table is ready CONS:- it can be a long wait (but you can always get a drink somewhere else + they text you)- Price (not the cheapest meal) Â You should expect to pay around $150 - $200 for two people- very warm in there

Came for the midnight ramen and I would have to say that this was probably the best ramen ive ever had. It was a bit pricy so I think id only come for extreme cravings, but it was definitely worth the first try. The broth was very flavorful, yet light. Although I was initially hesitant at eating the intestines, it was delightfully crunchy and delicious. I definitely suggest getting extra if you can.

AMAZING!! Freakishly expensive at first glance, but once you taste it, it's worth every penny. I don't remember our servers name, but she was beautiful, bright eyed Vietnamese lady who was so friendly and made our Takashi experience exceptional. We had the Uni on the rare beef which my husband absolutely loved and my fave was the beef with the scallions and foie gras and wrapped up and melts in my mouth. Also had the premium beef tongue which was so tender and the rib with the caramel bourbon sauce. We loved ALL of it. No highchairs for our babies but they loved the food so much and enjoyed watching the food cooking on the grill that I don't remember it being a hassle
Another strong showing! Tried the A5 for the first time and it doesn't disappoint although it's pricey!

Very Cool & Very relaxing!I'm looking forward to returning and for better or worse everything was either good or great. Â And, that all important service side of the experience was so there that I think the lovely waitress would join our family. Also, one of those very cool unique touches that a bottle order of sake gives way to a tray of sake cups presented in order for each person to chose. The menu is quite large but you certainly can not go wrong with any steak choice. There is no rush although one cannot help but notice other folks waiting and I personally would always go with at least 4 or more with a reservation. Also, the more people in your group allows for a good excuse to order more choices adding to the experience .

I wrote this review in 2014 and for got to post. **********4.5 stars. The reason I didn't give 5 starts is that I felt it was too expensive and I need to order a lot to be full. However, their meat was the best meat I ever had in the US. They have interesting original menu like Foie Gras Stuffed Mini Kobe Burger with Chocolate BBQ Sauce. It comes on iron plate, and they pour chocolate over it and makes sizzling sound. Who thought pour chocolate over a meat ball? I never had something like this, and it was actually good. I came here because my boyfriend came to this place before for his business dinner and he was so excited to tell about Foie Gras Stuffed Mini Kobe Burger with Chocolate BBQ Sauce and their meat. Yes, their meat was excellent. Even intestine was great. However, I felt the portion of menu was small. I will be back if it is business dinner but I will hesitate to go back there if I have to pay by myself. They seems to be Japanese owned restaurant, but I thought how they serve rice was not right. They packed as much rice as possible to a bowl. This can be a good point for whom eat rice a lot, but I like rice softly served. Squeezed rice is NG for Japanese serving manner.

My expectations were really high and it didn't live up to the hype surrounding it. Â Typical wait is around 1-2 hours here as there are only 5 tables and 6 seats at the bar. Â I started with the famous Niku-Uni which was just ok as the uni was not that fresh. Â I also tried the calf's brain cream in a tube with caviar and it tasted like cheese and was ok but not something I would order again. Â The grilled meats was the best part and I could taste the difference as most of the meats were kobe beef. Â My favorite cuts were the kalbi, rosu and shio-tan (tongue). Â The beef belly wasn't bad either. Â Don't come here hungry though because unlike korean bbq, there is no rice or carbs with the meat and each order comes with only 5 slices so even after dropping over $200, I wasn't full. Â The service was great and the kobe beef quality is awesome but not sure I would want to wait 2 hours and leave a place still hungry.

He had Grandma's Spicy Ramen w/ extra nori and the added foie gras. So this joint only serves ramen after midnight, when the dinner service ends. The ramen comes out looking really intimidating but eats really smooth. I want to start off by saying this bowl isn't so much "spicy" in the sweat your ass off sense; it's more "spicy" as in - BAM! - flavor explosion. This is a rare (for the ramen world) beef broth that is seasoned, well-balanced, and easy to slurp. It reminds me of a super intense bowl of pho with wheat noodles instead of rice noodles. Â Speaking of noodles: they do a thinner version than most other ramen-yas, and they do it really damn well with a great bite. The beef belly was delicious and leaner than the usual pork char siu I'm used to. Intestine is not something I would normally jump at the chance of eating, but the fried intestines they add are super crispy and add some crunch to the ramen experience. By the end of the bowl, I was trying to fish out every last bit! The soft-boiled egg has a much firmer yolk than I prefer. The foie gras - while being an interesting (and expensive, at $14) add on - didn't really add much to the bowl. I love foie but I'd pass the next time. I give Takashi's late-night ramen service 2 YUMS. Despite the overdone egg, this is one damn good bowl of ramen and a great change of pace from the chicken and pork ramen that dominate the scene.

I have gotten the midnight ramen several times and its always delicious. I had always emailed the Monday before but it states on their website that they're now doing walk ins and you can call for a table! I always get the original ramen. I like it more than the spicy ramen because you can taste more of the beef broth. The beef is melt in your mouth good and so delicious. I have also tried the foie gras add in and it works with the ramen! The ramen comes with a soft boiled egg and crispy intestines. Don't worry, they hardly look like intestines and have no real flavor. This place is definitely worth it!

Absolutely love this everything beef place. You would pay a lot for different body parts of a cow but it's so worth it. Cow tongue is my ultimate favorite, definitely need to try that for the Japanese bbq, it won't disappoint you. If you want to treat your half (who loves meat) to a fancy date, take him/her there! He will love you forever! ;) the service is always friendly, attentive and cultural. Review on takashi's LATE NIGHT RAMEN (Fridays and Saturdays 12-2am only) -- tried their ramen twice. This is only possible by email reservation (check website). They only have two kinds of ramen: the original and grandma's spicy ramen, but you can add a lot of extra toppings to it. A very notable side is the foie gras ($14 additional). You get this big piece of perfection. The foie gras melts on your tongue no matter how you eat it. Not kidding. I would say their ramen is #1 on my ramen list. What brings this one out from other ramen is that it is made with 100% beef broth. Beef FTW!!!

If the boy and I were reborn as a restaurant, it would probably be this one.Asian style off cuts marinated delicately and served simple, without any froufrou things to distract you from the deliciousness of organ meat.This place doesn't just put offal on the menu because it's "in", and it doesn't shy away from it to appease the more unadventurous general public. It is unapologetic in its love of typically discarded cuts, and displays this in giant chalk drawings all along the restaurant walls. They don't hide their grilling meats in thick marinades and sauces; instead, each kind cut of meat can be marinated two very simple ways, and you grill it yourself (there are instructions on the chalk board if you're a newbie).Here was our (the boy and I) selection:TesticargotThe uni raw chuck shiso seaweed biteAll of the stomachs (raw/parboiled)Liver (raw and cooked)AortaSweet breads... I think that's it.And a bottle of sake.I was in pure raw beef heaven. You ask me or the boy how we want our steaks and the answer is usually "just walk it through a warm room".Everything was unbelievable. Deliciousness and texture at every turn. Here are my words of wisdom: Be adventurousDon't go with picky eatersI will return.

meat loverssssssss take note! this is my 2nd time here and it's been awhile that i've been wanting to come back.this place is rather unique and different in my opinion much better than gyukaku or other chain japanese bbq places. from the ambience to the food and restaurant decor i like everything about it. esp the cute wall arts with cartoons and funny comics related to the food! our waitress / server were all very attentive and friendly, so we had a great time here! not to mention i accidentally broke a glass in the beg of the meal. they serve all types of meat...any parts of a cow that you can think of. yes any parts pretty much. they have quite a big selections of meat and interesting dishes to order from, so i have to come back again to try different stuff!but so far my 2 experience here has been greatttt and i will def return!for dinner last night party of 4 we got a few types of meat to try. my personal fave would be the pork belly that comes with gold flakes. the portions are a bit on the small side and bit pricey but they are def quality meats out here!for appetizer we started off with the chocolate sizzling meatball. it only came as one but omg the sauce was so good. i never thought meat would go well with chocolate and it just blends perfectly.overall i had a great experience and would def come back for more and maybe next time try their special body parts!

Five stars for the ramen at midnight on Fridays and Saturdays. I've been here a couple times and every time it tastes so good. The crispy intestines and the beef belly are delicious. The egg is cooked to perfection. My favorite is the original ramen. The foie gras tastes a little weird to me in this ramen and I wasn't a fan of the spicy one. This is definitely the best ramen in NYC hands down. My only gripe is that you have to wait a while before getting your ramen.

Wow. Just wow. I don't even know where to start. No, I do. The steak tartare is to DIE for. The tongue combo is really nice, and the table next to mine got brain served in a tube. I've also heard the late night ramen is really great and I need to try it sometime. But all in all, this place is a bit pricey, but it's so worth it. Top quality stuff, right here

I got the Niku-Uni (chuck flap topped with sea urchin-uni). LOVE LOVE LOVE!!! The uni is super fresh, just melts in your mouth. I added a touch of wasabi and soy sauce before taking a bite of the wrap. DELICIOUS- kind of pricey , 4 pieces for 24.For the bbq I got the tongue and beef belly. The beef tongue was really good- chewy and reminds me of brisket because you gotta take a couple of bites to bite through but it's really good!!! The beef belly was the best meat!!! Melts in your mouth!!!! I'm still thinking about this bbq. The beef tongue came with 6-8 pieces, as did the beef belly. They only take reservations for 4 or more. I came here on a Saturday at 5:30pm (right when it opened) and got seated really quickly. I recommend coming here when it opens. At 6pm there was a line.Service is friendly and food is high quality! Love this place, one of my favs in NYC.

Holy Cow - the ramen is friggin amazing. I arrived here around 1AM on Friday night/Saturday morning for a spontaneous ramen session. We were a party of two and got seated immediately at a communal table. Takashi serves 1 ramen (original and spicy) at $16/$17. One can add more toppings and they range up to $14(?) for uni. It's on the higher end for ramen but it's so delicious I can overlook the price. The food came within 5 minutes of ordering. We got the original and spicy. The broth was amazing for the original and the spicy paste added an extra kick (recommend if you like spice). The meat was sooo tender and melted in my mouth! However, my favorite part was definitely the crunchy pork skin. Super unique and adds another dimension to the texture. Chewy noodles, tender/juicy meat and crunchy pork skin! Such awesome combination. The broth was delicious too, not super salty like many ramen joints (I like milder flavors). Seriously what more can you ask for!DEF recommend to everyone.
Tried the BBQ, testicolars & Kobe uni. Â It was all ok, expected better for the price. Â It was overall below my expectations.

3.5 stars.I came here on a Saturday at around 6pm without a reservation - the wait turned out to be about 2 hours long for two people. We waited at a wine bar around the place (Lelabar is amazing! Cozy, romantic ambiance and $8 wine specials during happy hours - highly recommended to anybody who ends up having to wait for a long time like we did), so it wasn't too bad after all. When we finally got seated by the counter, we started with the famous niku-uni for appetizer - it was delicious, but the shiso flavor was too strong and overpowering that I couldn't get as much of the uni/raw meat taste as I wanted. For the grill, we got the beef belly, kalbi, tongue, cheek and sweetbread. They were all excellent, although the cheek was too rough and chewy for my taste. So overall, it was a delicious and filling meal. But I still have reservations about whether this place warrants such ridiculous wait time and hefty price tag. While they offer a great selection of different kinds of meat and it's fun to grill your own meat with friends, I don't think cheaper, more accessible yakiniku venues in the city like Gyu-kaku are much inferior considering the value (both time and money!). If you insist on checking this place out, however, make sure to come early (maybe 10-15 minutes before they open) or place a reservation for groups bigger than 4!

Holy mooooo, do The Cow Experience! I say as a whole, it was a 4.5, but I thought The Cow Experience was a 5. I thought the apps were just OK, I was kinda expecting the apps to be mind blowing but they weren't. If I am not mistaken, I think you have to pre-order The Cow Experience in advance. The restaurant itself is on the small side and the seating is kinda cramped, I do, however, love the open kitchen in the middle of the dining room. Also, there are no signs out front, I think it's the second restaurant from the corner. The staff was Japanese and I appreciate how they were able to guide us throughout the dinning experience. For the Cow Experience, you have the option to go with a salt or a soy garlic marinade for the beef cuts and we chose the soy garlic. I thought the soy garlic was great, it really added a ton of flavor. And overall, I think the thinner cuts came out better than the thicker pieces and the meal is a nice way to try different cuts of the cow but in terms of being full, it was almost to the point of being full with the bowl of rice.The food:Niku-Uni- U.S. Kobe chuck flap served on seaweed and Shiso topped with raw sea urchin and fresh wasabi. This was the first dish that made me want to visit the restaurant and the dish seems rather drool-worthy but it wasn't very flavorful. I thought the Uni with shiso would be one of those dishes you expect to be amazing but all I tasted was the shiso, the Uni was kinda lost and the beef wasn't really pronounced. It's worth a try for yourself, but I wouldn't get this again. yelp.com/user_local_photâ¦Testicargot- cow balls escargot style with garlic shiso butter. I think this is kinda something you order for the shock factor. And when it comes to testicles, you kinda have to dress it up in a way so it is familiar for people to try. For me, the testicles kinda had a firm squid or firm scallop feel and kinda had a less intense organ-y taste, but the garlic shiso butter was a bit too aggressive, it felt like I was eating an intense pesto. This dish was OK. yelp.com/user_local_photâ¦Grandmom's steamed beef shank buns with spicy mayo- I thought this was a little underwhelming, it is basically jumping on the steamed bun bandwagon but instead of pork belly, they use beef shank. The meat was OK, but I felt like it was too sweet and should have been more unctuous, I also felt the order was overpriced. It was two buns for $16.The Cow Experience- 16 of their finest cuts from top to tail. It's 4-6 ppl and it's $35 per. The picture was an order for 5 people. It's a grill your own food thing, so there is this raging hot grill in front of you and the waitress tells you how long to cook each item. The staff also does a great job swapping out the grills for new ones to make sure the burned stuff doesn't affect the flavor of the food. Also, the food will make you stink, so beware. yelp.com/user_local_photâ¦Shio-Tan- This was the tongue and it was perfection, it was so thin, juicy and perfect. You cook it for a minute on each side.Shibire- This was the sweetbreads and you cook this one the longest at 5 minutes a side but it was great. It had a nice outer char and a nice creamy interior. So good. Hatsu- This was the heart and it was super lean, thin and had such a clean beefy flavor. You cook this one a minute on each side and it was perfect. Â Kalbi- This was the Kobe short rib and it was as excellent as it looked. The beef was so well marbled and had so much flavor from the beef to the marinade. This you cook 2 mins a side. Angus short rib- This and the Kalbi were similar but the Kalbi was more red in color and the Angus was a tad darker but both were excellent. Cook 2 mins a side.Tripe- There were a total of four stomach pieces and honestly, I really don't remember which was which but the tripe was the obvious one. It cooks pretty long at 2-3 minutes a side and it had good flavor but was a tad chewy. This was pretty good.Kimo- This was the liver and it is not you, it's me. I am not a fan of liver of any kind, except pate but that doesn't count, the beef liver is off putting and is really strong. Kinda had to pinch my nose and chew.Oxtail- I love oxtail since it is so tender and fatty, but only when it is cooked a long time in some type of stew. Oxtail is not ideal for a grill since the meat is really chewy. The flavor was good but the chewiness killed it for me.

I just love this place, though I wish that they took reservation. It was supposed to be a 3-hour-wait for us on a Friday night, but some people who were before us on the list didn't show up when they called, so we got to eat after an hour and a half. Everything that the waiter recommended us to order was just blissful. There's nothing that I can complain about. The bill was huge, but totally worth it.

This is what a five star restaurant looks like. It's tiny and only takes reservations for large parties so come early. Arrived at 6 pm on a Friday night and the wait was already 45 minutes. So worth it. Try to sit at the bar if you can! Great views of the masterful chefs at work.You can make this meal into what you want. You can play it safe and have some of the best kalbi or pork belly you've ever tasted. Or you can live on the wild side and go for the stomach, intestines, tongue, heart, throat, liver, aorta, or pancreas. We hovered somewhere in the middle.....To begin, we had some fabulous appetizers.1. Bone marrow and crawfish dumplings - rich, hearty, superb2. Uni and beef on shiso leaf and seaweed - best uni I've had, incredibly fresh and creamy 3. Squid ink risotto with sweetbreads - my favorite dish of the entire night. Like nothing I've tried before, the sweetbreads were perfectly cooked and melted in your mouthNext, the meats which we grilled ourselves right on the table:1. Heart - this was our wild card dish of the night. We pushed ourselves to try something Â out of our comfort zone. It was surprisingly good. Wouldn't have guessed it was heart at all2. Belly - fatty and awesome, obviously, like all good pork belly3. Cheek - oh, sweet, sweet cheek, so tender and leanWe also couldn't resist getting the homemade soft serve vanilla ice cream with the works - Mochi balls, red beans, powder, gold leaf bits and salted caramel. This salted caramel was on its own level. It had a smokey, bitter taste that made this dessert extremely unique and complex.Service was fantastic Â although our dishes were cleared away too quickly at times. Don't miss the bathrooms before you go. Oh Takashi, I love you!

I fell in loveeee with this place and I will definitely be back to eat here when I travel to this part of the country. The calf brain with caviar may have been my favorite order. The ice cream with matcha was out of this world.

I loved it very minute there... I can't even describe the best dish... Each one was better than the next. Mimi the server is to die for . I loved her! She was soooo helpful, kind, and made this place the best experience. Will definitely be going back and asking for Mimi :)

Takashi gets 5 stars because you MUST try this place at least once. I would eat here every week if my wallet and waistline allowed it. All of the meats that we ordered tasted incredibly fresh. My favorite was the filet mignon special, which you would sear on the grill and then poach in garlic butter (really, melted butter in a sardine can with 20 cloves of garlic in it) for 30 seconds. Other favorites were the kalbi and the beef belly (the latter my least favorite, because of the chewy texture. But the others I was with said it was their favorite, because it was so juicy).The prepared appetizers were completely surprising and unique. Loved the Yooke (beef tartare with quail egg), and the squid ink rice with sweetbreads was completely delicious and totally unexpected! The Grandmom's Steamed Beef Buns were so good that they have ruined all future steamed buns for me. (Sorry, Ippudo chicken bun, but you have been dethroned.)The alcohol list is also impressive - pricey, but a nice mix of hard-to-find Japanese beer, sake, whiskey and plum wine. We ordered a pot of makkeoli (Korean rice wine), which was one of the better ones I have tasted in NYC.Attentive service rounds out the 5-stars, although they had some trouble finding our coats on the way out. Agree with previous reviewers that space is tight, so stick with groups of 4 or fewer.We might be more adventurous re: trying new cow parts on our next visit, but you really don't have to do that for a delicious meal. Come eat here! (But vegetarians beware - this place is not for you!)

Very fancy Japanese-style Korean BBQ. It is a nightclubby kind of area, so the clientele can be a bit douchey. But the food is for real. I highly recommend the whole cow experience, though it can take a very long time to prefer owing to it containing little grillable morsels of just about every edible part of the cow. It costs about $35 pp.So... Do not come here especially hungry or especially impatient.At night, they turn into a 'secret ramen' joint that is all the rage right now, for which you must make reservations weeks in advance.Come here on an expense account or after winning lottery to fully enjoy.

I was really looking forward to this place and came in at 10:20pm. But the restaurant had a sign of closed hanging at the door though the hours show it opens until 11pm on Thursday. I asked the people working there and they told me the restaurant closed early at a not-busy-day. Disappointed.

Definitely worth the wait. Small place and gets crowded, so get there early and put your name down on the wait list or make a reservation for 4 or more. Came here with my sister for a late birthday dinner. Everything we had was delicious. Must haves:Niku-Uni, practically melts in your mouthThe squid ink rice with sweetbreads, so creamyThe beef special 1, wagyu beef enough saidOverall, we would definitely come again to try other things on the menu.
One must in NYC. It is a bit overpriced but the experience worth it. Recommended to open minded foodies looking to try new experiences.
Their beef belly and beef sushi are so soft and tasty. I'm a beef lover and Takashi make me very happy but a dish is so small. You have to order a lot until you feel full.Long line on the weekend.

You have to really watch your wallet when you eat here! The prices add up very quickly and it gets to be as expensive as a fancy sushi place. That said, this place is really for people who are really really into meat, everything is so so meaty. There isn't enough veggies, sides or other types of items to cut the grease, oil, and heaviness of so much meat. Might I add, most of the meat is either raw or only supposed to be slightly cooked (the heat of the grill while hot does not cook quickly).One of the dishes I liked best was the little amount of kimchi they brought out as a complimentary side. The complimentary soybean sprouts and plate of cabagge with slightly sweet mild orange colored dressing was so-so. I liked the niku-uni because the uni taste dominated the dish. It was topped on a slice of raw beef, which was easily chewed in the mouth, reminded me of fresh sashimi, and didn't have much flavor. The shiso leaf and nori also went well with this combo.Of the meats, I liked the pork belly the best, it was the flavor I enjoyed the most. I also enjoyed grilling the filet minon and letting it sit in the small garlic, butter bath before eating it. I liked eating the soft sweet garlic along with the meat.The other meats like the beef shoulder, beef tongue were all good quality but after awhile, the same seasonings of either sesame oil, sesame seeds, and salt or the takashi marinate, it all started to be about the same flavor, just different textures depending on the cut of the meat.I really enjoyed the dessert of homemade vanilla ice cream, the flavor of the real madagascar vanilla beans really came through, it was delightful. The shiratama balls were soft and had a wonderful chewy texture. I think I would come back just for the dessert. The meat is too overpriced and best suited for those who like it on the raw to mildly cooked side. For this type of yakiniku, I would rather stick with the gyukaku chain (it's less meat-a-whelming and less sticker shock.)

My sister brought me here for midnight ramen (we had the 1am reservation). They seated us promptly even before 1am which was great! There are only 2 choices, beef or spicy beef. I did beef and my oh my the broth for the ramen was delicious!! I wish I could just bring the broth home and use it with my own noodles. I would definitely recommend others to make it to midnight ramen.

Decided to come here for dinner and waited for 2 hours and 30 minutes because reservations for 2 can not be done unless there's 4 people or above. The wait time was pretty annoying but I did come here knowingly it would be a long wait due to previous reviews. The food was pretty good but maybe not something I would go back for unless I have 3 hour free time lingering around. We ordered the wagyu beef, prime kobe and some of the other special cuts. The meat was all tender and flavorful. The server was really nice and offered to cook most of the meat for us. He also recommended us to try the heart and the liver. The heart was pretty good but the liver was disgusting. It was mushy even after it was grilled. Before you leave, you must try the ice cream with The green tea matcha sauce! The bill turned out to be $237 for 2 people, which wasn't that bad. It was overall a good experience but would be better if the wait time was not so long.

On an episode of his former Travel Channel series, "The Layover", Anthony Bourdain was having such a culinary orgasm grilling his meat here that I'm pretty certain I bookmarked it then and there for a future trip east. That was nearly three years ago, and it was kind of a pain to get in here. On my first attempt, I was looking for a late meal around 11PM, but they were technically closed even though the Yelp listing says they are open until 2AM on the weekends. That's because they have a midnight ramen sitting, and you need to make a reservation in advance for that. Say what? I tried coming a couple of evenings later, this time close to when they opened for dinner. Success. I thought I'd be shunted to the counter, but no, I got my own table for four and more importantly, my own grill. Score.It's only one of seven tables in the place and quite a set-up with a huge grated grill with a big heating element and a huge light and vent right at forehead level. The menu was comprehensively appetizing meld of Korean barbecue with Japanese sensibilities. The style is called yakiniku, and Chef Takashi Inouye is very, very thorough in his coverage of the cow. Cow balls anyone? There are parts that would require some experience with a cadaver to know what you're ordering, for example, what's the difference between the first and fourth stomachs? The cheery waitress allowed me time to consider my options by placing a bowl of their Cabbage Salad with miso dressing and a side of seasoned bean sprouts (photo: bit.ly/1pNHtRl) along with their Red Red Kimchi (photo: bit.ly/1qB9nBH). I did know I needed to try one certain indulgence, the $24 Niku-Uni.It was a quartet of raw chuck flaps, beautifully marbled, with fresh sea urchin scooped on top sitting on shiso leaves and seaweed squares (photo: bit.ly/1rXS5mK). Yes, I said it was $24 but absolutely perfect mouthfuls of joy, an unexpected twist on surf-n-turf. The other tantalizing treat was the $16 Bone Marrow and Crawfish Dumplings (photo: bit.ly/1rXS5mK). They sit in the actual bones which the waitress is quick to point out is not edible. She then put on quite a production pouring the Hot Peanut Oil over them and setting them a-sizzle in a furious frenzy. Quite delicious although more meatball than dumpling. No complaints. So I was already down forty bucks, and the meat had not arrived yet. The dishes were cleared and the grill fired up. Time for the carnivery. First up was the $20 US Kobe Beef Belly.Bathing in Takashi's special marinade topped with sesame seeds and scallions, the fresh beef belly was sliced into strips ready for the grill (photo: bit.ly/1nV54Tv). It takes very little time to cook the meat, which I did dexterously with a set of tongs (photo: bit.ly/1m7HpKU). When the beef was ready, I dipped the pieces into a sesame oil dipping sauce that enhanced the flavor. Delicious as I was pounding the rice. Me want mo' meat. So I timidly ordered the $16 Cheek (Tsurami) this time with a marinade of salt, garlic and sesame oil (photo: bit.ly/WSkHAZ). A bit chewier in texture but still quite tasty and I'm finally feeling the capacity point but not before the waitress dropped off the dessert card for my perusal. There was just one dessert, a $6 Homemade Madagascar Vanilla Soft Serve Ice Cream with all sorts of topping and syrup options. Instead of pretending I was going to save calories by going with it plain, I went with the flat $10 "I'll have it with the works" option which allowed me to try all three toppings available - rice-flour dumplings, black sesame and soybean flour, and sweet beans - plus a syrup. I went with the salted caramel even though the green tea or the raw wild strawberry sauce would have worked in a pinch as well (photo: bit.ly/UGGKsT). It was fine but probably the east impressive part of the meal since it was just a sundae with a touch of Japanese exotica to make it compatible with the yakiniku. Quite a meal thanks to Chef Takashi focus on offal, not awful, not by a long shot. How can I come back and not try the Tongue Experience?FOOD - 5 stars...the fresh meats and innards and distinctive flavors make the Korean-style Japanese barbecue soar above other yakiniku housesAMBIANCE - 4 stars...not that spacious but I can't complain about a table to myself with my very own grillSERVICE - 4 stars...excellent waitress never rushed me despite a growing queue of hungry hipsters, the host was kinda tense thoughTOTAL - 5 stars...superb execution and fresh meats and offal make this an understandable Bourdain favorite

This place is the best Japanes bbq ive ever had.Im originally from LA and I think this place trumps any place ive tried in LA.My favorite item we ordered on the menu was the Â kobe with uni, yooke, & rib eye.The food just melts in your mouth.So juicy and tender.I want to go back soon!

The food is amazing. Â I usually am not a fan of steak tartar, but their version of it was delicious. Â All the different cuts of beef are delicious. Â Tips:- if you are a party of 4-6 make reservations- if you are a party of 2 -- plan to come early - or wait in line. Â - the setting is warm with the grill right in front of you-- dress accordingly - the beef belly is a must

Visited on a Wednesday evening and the wait was about 15 minutes so not bad at all. The food was great but I especially enjoyed the ambiance of the restaurant and the unique experience of cooking the meat!

I was turned onto Takashi because it was listed on a bunch of best-of ramen lists. I guess I should've done more research because they only do ramen from midnight to 2am Friday and Saturday. Oh well.We put in our names at around 7pm and were quoted an hour and a half wait. There were literally people lining out the door, even so early. It actually ended up being an hour wait instead, which wasn't so bad. Tons of bars around to wait.So, to our surprise (and due to my lack of preparation), we had a yakiniku meal instead of ramen. You know the deal - you order cuts of meat and they bring it out raw, and you cook it on the grill.We ordered the chef's selection - two types of cow stomach, sweetbreads, and heart. We also ordered the Kobe outside skirt.As a starter, we had the beef schmaltz crostini and the bone marrow/crawfish dumplings. Â The crostini was okay, but I could've done without it. The dumplings, however, were super interesting. They bring them out on a plate, and then pour boiling oil over it to finish cooking it at your table. They were more like Asian-style meatballs than dumplings though. And at $16 for three, they were some pretty pricey meatballs. Really good though.As for the yaki, the portions weren't huge, but it filled the three of us up thanks to the appetizers. The skirt steak was probably the best. If you haven't had cow stomach before, it's chewy. Really chewy. Wasn't the biggest fan of that. The sweetbreads were delicious (it's an acquired taste).Overall, the yaki is a bit pricey (the chef's selection was $30 and the Kobe skirt was $18). But it's a fun experience, and it's definitely a great idea for the winter.Oh, almost left out the most important thing - they have a bidet!

I have tried going to Takeshi (without reservations) about 5 times now. Â Finally the wait was only an hour (on a Thursday night), so I decided to wait it out. Â Boy, was I glad I did. Â I can see why this place is always so busy. Â Almost everything about this place is amazing. The service was fast, friendly, and efficient. Â The food was delicious. Â And who doesn't like to cook their own food over a table top grill? Â Everything we tried was melt in your mouth tender and delicious. Â The bone marrow and crawfish dumplings were amazing. Fatty, tender, delicious. The chuck flap topped with sea urchin and fresh wasabi was equally delicious. For the grill we got kalbi, between the rib, and cheeks. Â All were flavorful, tender, and delicious. Â The kalbi was probably my favorite. Â Overall this place is on point with their food and service. Â I would say my biggest gripe with the place is the price. Â Total price for food with 2 beers was about $100/person with tax and tip. Â This is high quality food and a premium restaurant, but a bit on the expensive side. Â You will also leave the place smelling like grill meats! Â I didn't mind, but I could see some people might. Â If you don't care about price and want some delicious grills meats, definitely try out Takeshi.

I was really excited to here on a recent double date, knowing that this place was and is a favorite of Anthony Bourdain's. Sadly, Takashi fell short of the hype. As great as the food had tasted, I still get over how much we spent for meat. 8-10 pieces of well cut BEEF BELLY, at $20/order? Â It's not like you were able to get full off of one order of meat either. I will say that my first experience eating TESTICARGOT (Cow Balls) was actually quite pleasant. We all went home satisfied but not stuffed. The service is great, i highly appreciated how long the different cuts of meat needed to be on the grill. The food was good, but definitely not worth the value. The wine list, was more affordable than the food.TOPS:- Beef Belly - great marbled color- Testicargot - the shiso garlic butter is really good- Kalbi - House-smoked beef pancetta- SweetbreadsFLOPS:- Niku-Uni - The shiso leaf was overpowering- Bakudan - nothing more than rolls of rice in seaweed

Very good, just don't take the 10.30 pm reservation cause Â they close at 11.... we got rushed through dinner and had to put in our orders really fast, which left us hungry cause the portions are tiny, which is fine I just wish I knew so I would have ordered more. We had 3 apps and 4 cuts between 4 people. The apps were amazingly delicate and delicious, the cuts were good but similar to a quality k-town experience where you actually get an adult sized portion. Don't order the oxtail cut, it is basically just bone, it was very hard to eat, the beef belly is the way to go. Also, like a lot of BBQ places, get ready to wash your clothes right after u leave.....

After seeing so many IG/ snapchat posts on their Niku-Uni, I finally had the chance to come here and snapchat it. My friend who was visiting NY and I came here on a Wednesday evening and we had to wait about an hour to be seated. The size of the restaurant is relatively cozy and a bit dim. We ordered the Niku-Uni (of course), beef tongue samplers, and some kind of short-ribs of beef samplers (can't remember the exact name) and they were all pretty good. The bill came out to be around $180PROS:- Great ambience / service (server made sure we grilled each kind of meat with the correct grill time so we dont under/ over cook the meat) - Unique selection of food to try- Good quality meatCONS:- Long wait- Price - Not everyone will find the menu appealing Overall I had a great experience and I would recommend people to try it at least once. Will I ever comeback? Sure, if someone else is treating me.
This place is an adventure. Food was amazing and service was topsGet a reservation as line was out the door and justly so...one of the few places I would wait in line to eat at!

My boyfriend and I came here early on a Friday evening and we only had about a 25min wait. The service was wonderful, our server was extremely friendly and made great recommendations. We had a carafe of sake and got to chose from an assortment of cute sake cups to drink from. We ordered the brain paste and raw liver to start. The raw liver had a great taste from the marinade but I didn't particularly like the texture, though my boyfriend enjoyed it. The brain paste was delicious and came with caviar and little crÃªpes. For our main course we had the sweetbread and beef cheeks to grill ourselves. Both were delicious and tasted great with the sauce provided. We also had the ice cream for dessert. The sesame topping and green tea sauce were excellent additions and it came with some gold flakes too. Overall everything was excellent and there are many unique items on the menu to try.

Have been coming to Takashi for 5 years now. Â  Always love this place. Â  Tonight tried the filet mignon with garlic butter for the first time. Â  It was awesome! Â  We used all the garlic with the rice too. Â  The garlic melted in the mouth after being cooked in the hot pot of butter. Â  The meat was so tender and delicious with the garlic butter.

Spent a night here for a girlfriend's birthday, four of us didn't eat much, we were eager to get out for a second meal down the block. The must try's were very delicious, we ordered the uni on raw beef, burger steak with caramelized chocolate sauce, meat ball on bone marrow with sizzling chilly sauce, beef tongue, kobe beef, etc. It was expensive, tasty, with a great lounge ambience, for a few bites each though. If my girlfriends didn't call for a second spot, I would have ordered more BBQ meat. The staff was very nice, we sat at an individual BBQ table, the tables are constructed around a central kitchen where they create appetizers and cold plates. Very interesting set up. I think it's great for a date night if you are not worried about getting that charcoal smell on your hair and clothes.

If you like quality beef, this will be your new favorite place. Â It's yakiniku, which is basically the Japanese version of KBBQ, where you cook raw meat on the grill right in front of you. Â The waiter was extremely attentive, explaining their menu options, and the 4 of us ordered some appetizers and a variety of meats on the menu (their special filet mignon with garlic butter, beef cheek, prime rib, and kalbi, the short rib). Â Highlights:Wagyu Beef Tartare with quail egg: CREAMY AND MELTS IN YOUR MOUTH, highly recommend*Dinner special* filet mignon with garlic butter: cubes of beef that you marinate with a dish of garlic butter before you place it on the grill, probably my favorite meat of the nightSoju spritzer: tasty and easy to drink alcoholic beverage that compliments the mealWe finished off the meal with some vanilla ice cream topped with rice balls and black sesame flakes and green tea sauce which was just the right amount of sweetness to finish off the night of juicy, savory, meat.

This is my kind of place. Â I love different cuts of meat. Â You are served uber fresh meat to grill yourself which I dig. Â The service was attentive and friendly. Â I took my friend d for her birthday and we had appetizers and a bunch of different kinds of cuts of meat. Â All were excellent. Â I'll keep my recommendations sort of mainstream, try the ribeye, short rib, tongue, cheek and beef belly. Â If you're more adventurous, there are options for you my friends. Â Any appetizer you order will make you happy, trust. Â It's expensive but worth it. Â Cool place for drinks and light bites as well. Â I'll return for sure.

Came here late on a Saturday night for their Ramen. I've never had a beef broth ramen before and it was fantastic. Noodles were perfectly cooked and everything had a fresh delicious taste. Prices are reasonable and portion size is perfect. This place is worthy of its reputation for sure.I didnt eat any of the other food because late night they only serve ramen but i saw others eating the raws they offer that had been there for dinner prior and it looks awesome. I love how you get to cook everything yourself.Sake menu was extensive and i thought it was awesome you get to pick your own glass to drink from. Fun idea.

Came here to celebrate my bf's bday. We're meat lovers so we ordered all BEEF! First, of course the Niki-Uni, if the girl didn't ask me if I want dessert menu or not, definitely will order the second one! Then the Kobe short ribs, shoulders, belly, 6oz beef,and I forgot what else~ LOL  I love this place, period!

Came for the midnight ramen. It was pretty disappointing. The staff rushes you for sure. We weren't even offered a drink menu and someone came to take our order almost immediately after we were seated.There's a choice of the regular or spicy. I had the regular and it was exactly that, just regular. The noodles were thin and too soft and overcooked. The broth was ok but the garlic was overpowering. The pork was tough and chewy. It also comes with an egg and seaweed. Simple, but it missed the mark.The ramen was ok, but at that price ($17), it should be amazing. The pricing is a turn off for me.
Nice selection of app & high quality selection of unique cuts of meat, but pricey & small portions.: 8 calendars

If you're like me, you'll wake up in the middle of the night and ask, "Where can I get the whole cow experience?"You know, like eat every part of the cow?You know, a place where you can proudly point out to your friends that you prefer the delicate nuances of the third cow stomach over the fourth stomach? Â A place where you can get Uni wrapped in 'Murican Kobe wrapped in Japanese Shiso wrapped in K'rean Nori? Â Takashi, duh!Lets be honest. Â We like eating here because we probably watched too many damn tv shows of certain tv hosts globetrotting the world eating all sorts of food that we have no idea what they taste like. Â We have this unscratched curiosity that asks ourselves, "I wonder what calf brain tastes like? Â Is it as creamy as they describe?" Â If you're a food lemming and sellout such as myself who unashamedly embraces their inner herd, you'll love this. Â Or if you just like eating delicious bits of grilled beef, you'll love this too.Be sure to try the large beef intestines or as I like to call it, cow bubblegum. Â It takes around three minutes to chew thoroughly so the extra time allows you to close your eyes and meditate on the fact that you're appreciating every part of the cow. Â You'll feel enlightened beyond your squeamish friends, guaranteed.

Worth the hour and a half wait, although in the future I will gather a party of 4 to reserve a table. Every dish was extremely fresh and tasty. The niki-uni was filled with delicious flavors, pop it whole in your mouth but beware that the creaminess of the uni will melt miraculously with the aroma of fresh wasabi and shiso leaf combining together with a fresh raw chunk of beef. Sex in my mouth. I also tried the bone marrow crawfish dumplings which were delish and washed everything down with plum wine on the rocks. The meat dishes were fairly small in portion but oh so fresh and tasty. The beef tongue was very well marinated which was a plus. I love scallions so we also got a side scallion salad, I liked it but didn't love it. Maybe it was just too overpowering in scallion flavor, but duh it's a scallion salad.

Wow. So as promised I came back for the BBQ. when you first walk in to the restaurant, it's a meat attack of your senses. the smell of meat grilling greets you, the tables overcrowded with delicious meats waiting for their turn on the grill and the sound of the meat sizzling excites you. We did two appetizers, the niku uni and the yooke. Amazeballs. The uni comes on top of a raw slice of beef, shiso leaf, and then a piece of seaweed. Roll it up and savor cause it's good. The creaminess of the uni and the soft texture of the beef would be enough for me, but then add the shiso leaf for another layer of flavor.. Well worth the high price tag. The yooke was a beef chuck tartare mixed with a raw quail egg and shiso leaf. Again just absolutely divine. It's just an elegant way to showcase the freshness and add flavor elements that really complement the meat.On the grill we had the tongue experience, the shoulder loin, cheeks, and beef belly. By far the beef belly was the best. You can't beat the fattiness of it. Next favorite would be the shoulder loin for the marinade which was more like a traditional Korean kalbi. Cheeks and tongue would tie and both had great texture. We also tried the rice balls which weren't as amazing as the meat but I think you need something plain to go with all the meats so no complaints here. Next time I'll be back for the whole cow experience!! (they only do one a day and it's a tasting of meats from the tip to tail of the cow, call ahead to reserve)

The first time I tried to come, the wait was 2 hours so I didnt make it... This time I arrived when it opened at 530 and was the first seated, I was really excited. (They dont take reservations for 2) Â However, given the high zagat and yelp rating, I wasnt impressed with the food. Â While the concept of combining raw kobe beef and uni is very creative, the tastes didnt complement each other... I would have preferred each on their own more. Â The tartar was also just okay, nothing special. Â The kobe beef kalbi was very good but the portions were small. You get about 6-8 very small thin slices for about $28. If you enjoy very small portions then go for the bbq here. Â Otherwise, youre better off at a korean bbq restaurant for the bbq or a sushi restaurant for the uni.

First impression is everything they say, but this place didn't give that impression until you take your first bite of their ribeye! It was amazing. Just melts in your mouth and the bone marrow was also great! Service was good, atmosphere was also nice. A little dimmed inside but they do coat check so you don't smell after you eat! That's pretty neat!

I came here for the midnight ramen. The ramen is very unique in that the broth is made from kobe beef. Understandably the broth was very oily due to the nature of kobe beef but nonetheless it was delicious. The menu choice was very simple with 2 choices. Note that ramen only starts at midnight on certain days and you will most likely need a reservation.

I was excited to try this place after being enlightened by The Layover. My brother and I even tried to emulate the Niku-Uni dish with ingredients brought from our local Korean market. This restaurant is smaller in size with 10 table grills available, so it will require some planning to make sure you'll get your opportunity to enjoy the great food here. Fortunately I was able to get my reservation online and was seated promptly and without any difficulty. There is a little bit for everyone at this restaurant, whether you are a meat lover, enjoy seafood, or a curious adventurer. My friends and I decided to share the Yooke, Niku-Uni, Beef Belly, and the Kalbi. I thoroughly enjoyed every dish. Yooke - Chuck Eye Beef Tartare in Special SauceFollowed by your server bringing the plate, they will crack the quails egg over the raw marinated beef and begin to mix it all together. The result is a delicious, savory, and sweet combination. I really, really enjoyed this one and may have been my MVP in tonights lineup. Niku-Uni - Raw Chuck slices topped with Sea Urchin and Wasabi, wrapped in seaweed and perilla A must try dish. I do not believe you will see this dish anywhere else. Absolutely delicious and an interesting combination. Â Beef BellyThese are some of the thicker cuts of beef belly that I have tried. Sauced and seasoned with garlic, salt and garlic oil. You can not go wrong with this if you are on the fence between any choices in the grilled categoryKalbi - Short RibSauced and seasoned with garlic, salt and garlic oil as well. You can never go wrong with kalbi!On top of all of the delicious food we were able to enjoy, our server was attentive and courteous enough to answer all of our questions with genuine concern and interest in our dining experience. I can not wait to be back in NY to try this restaurant again. THANK YOU TAKASHI! YOU TAUGHT ME HOW TO LOVE AGAIN
the niku-uni is amazing!!! we had two servings of it and tons of BBQ. the rosu was my favorite.

Things to order here:Beef cheeksYooke (beef tartare with quail egg)Niku uni (chuck flap topped with sea urchin)You can't go wrong if you order any of these three (unless you don't eat raw food)We tried to be experimental and ordered the testicargot (cow balls)... But meehh just taste like a chewy textured meatball drenched in garlic sauce.

Wow. Sometimes you have dinner, and sometimes you have a dinner experience. This was an experience, and it surpassed my already high expectations. A group of four of us came here, and supposedly, were the first people to book the cow experience. For those of you who haven't heard of this, the cow experience is 16 different parts of the cow, at $30 per person, with only three of them available each night. We started off with the following:Calf brain cream - this was a first for me, and I'm glad I gave it a shot. The brain is actually served in a squeeze tube, and smeared on bilinis with caviar. The brains were creamy, and wits flavor similar to liver. With the caviar, it was a harmonious and decedent bite. Get over the fear of brains and order this. Niku-uni - this one didn't quite hit the mark for me. I love uni, and e uni was a top quality part, but the chuck flap itself was not tender, and I found myself chewing it for a while after the rest of the components were gone. Skip this guy. Squid ink rice and sweet breads - this is kinda like a Japanese risotto I guess. I'm a sucker for risotto, a sucker for squid ink, and a sucker for sweetbreads, so needless to say, I loved this. My only comment here is that serving it on a leaf isn't really the best vehicle for delivery, but I'll give it a pass because it was such a good dish. The cow experience. Book this right now because it's just awesome. I can't recall all 16 pieces, but some of them included tongue, cheek, meat between the ribs, tail, heart, liver, sweetbreads, first, second, and fourth stomach, belly, short ribs, and intestines. My favorites by far were the second stomach and intestines. The second stomach is so tender and flavorful, and the intestines charred and fatty. I think we ended up ordering extras of both after. Also, all pieces were in the takashi marinate, and it's perfect. You need no other sauces or flavors. The service here deserves its own commentary. Our glasses were never empty for long, our reminders about cooking time were readily given, and here's when they went above and beyond: one of us had the unfortunate piece of sweetbread (which is pretty slimy and blobby when raw) fall through the cracks of the grill. When we told our waiter, he immediately got us another, no questions asked, no extra charge. Between the uniqueness of the cow experience, the deliciousness of the meats, and the outstanding service, this place is a must and absolutely deserving of five stars.
Yum, yum, yum, yum. (But be warned, you won't leave stuffed--but so worth the experience.)

What a fun spot. Went here for dinner the other night. It's a bit on the expensive side, and we had to wait about an hour before we could be seated, but otherwise it was great. * They take down your name and number which I always appreciate- so we just went to a bar around the corner and had a few drinks while we waited. And, they promptly called us when our table was almost ready, giving us enough time to walk back over. * It's a fun experience. Definitely recommended for a date. Small space, but it's cool to be able to grill your own food. * The food is crazy delicious. We ordered a lot. We had a few of the ~grill your own meat~ dishes (I forget which ones but they were amazing- I think the spare rib was one of them), along with the kimchi appetizer, the bone marrow dumplings, and the ice cream. Also a bottle of soju. * Service was great. Our waitress was very attentive and friendly. Food came out pretty quickly. You also get to watch them prepare a lot of the dishes right in front of you which I always enjoy.

Well this was a total Anthony Bourdain ate here so I have to eat here move.The place is small but with a great Hybrid Japanese/Korean look to it. We really came to try the UNI with Beef Sashimi on a shiso leaf. which was excellent!The actually grilling experience was soso Â though. We ordered several cuts of beef including tongue. Having had Korean BBQ several times in Korean I was very underwhelmed with flavor and portion size. The seasoning was bland and not very noteworthy but it was a fun experience. what I did not like was that the 20% tip was added for our 5 people group and it was not very obvious written on final check either. You lose a star to me with auto gratuity especially for groups that truly are not large and the service was quite spotty while the restaurant was not even half full.

*Review for the regular dining hours*After watching an old episode of Anthony Bourdain, we had the craving to try the menu during it's regular hours of dining. The free apps were a nice treat. The uni negri is great. I'm not the biggest fan of the shoji leaf but the fresh uni on beautiful raw marbleized meat was delicious. The testcargo or just cow balls prepared like escargot was insanely good. The butter lemon pesto like sauce was lick off the plate good. For our meats, we ordered the tongue experience which was good but wish we stuck with the regular cow tongue. Some cuts were chewier than others. The cheek was tender and smooth. The Kobe short rib was like butter melting in your mouth. Not too far from the Hidagyu we ate in Japan. Loved the dining experience here. Excited to come back and try the other stuff.

Truly, as good as it gets. This place was an amazingly well executed riff on the theme that left all us all wanting a lot more. We had a business dinner here which was really fun and interactive. Guy's who have never thought about eating organs and glands were digging in and having opinions on which numerical cow stomach was better. The manager (Australian dude) was one of the best servers I have ever had the pleasure of having.

This review is just for the late night ramen: Every Friday and Saturday night, Takashi takes reservations for late night ramen at midnight and 1 am. Aka a GREAT option for munchies after going out. The ambience of the place is hip-intimate but not too crowded. The ramen itself is very unique: the broth is very thick but hearty with lots of meat and some crunchy chunks for added flavoring. I definitely enjoyed the experience, but personally prefer more traditional ramen. This place is excellent though if you're looking for a more unique twist on ramen!

Food is really good. Premium quality BBQ. Besides meats, Â intestines are delicious as well. The Friday and Saturday only late-night ramen is superb. The only drawback is that the place can get a little over crowded, especially the seating space.

Holy moly this place was amazing. Everything was such high quality with amazing flavors. I recommend the Squid ink rice with sweatbreads, Yooke, Niku Uni, and grilled tongue. This place is too pricey to recommend coming here if you're craving BBQ but I would absolutely recommend you come here for the specials and other dishes with some light BBQ.

Absolutely unique and amazing experience. Very interesting concept and had the opportunity to try things I never imagined. I highly recommend the cow testicles in pesto sauce and all 4 parts of the cow tongue!

When my friend booked a reservation for 12-am ramen here I thought her was nuts. But oh my god. Forget the amazing broth and the noodles--the beef belly. It will haunt your dreams that's how good it is.

Best japanese BBQ. Must have beef tongue, beef belly, kalbi.Have the makeolli but be careful as it is unassumingly strong. Before you know it, your SO will be giving a huge tip w your cardAlso, don't drop your phone in the grill when trying to take food porn pics...

Meat with BallsI loved this place, but the food was OFFAL!With dishes like Testicargot and Calf's Brain Cream (in tube), Takashi NYC delivers creatively on a delectable array of adventurous beef and organ meats. The style is Yakiniku: a Korean-influenced, non-traditional method of Japanese grilling that (according to the fun chalk art on the restaurant walls) grew in popularity due to a scarcity of beef after World War II.While we opted for some choice appetizers and specials, Takashi's heart is truly in their Yaki menu (literally). Each table comes with its own small grill, and diners can order Ã  la carte from a premium selection of cuts and organs, all beef. Each dish and meat is prepared carefully with ample attention paid to presentation. The food is as gorgeous as it is delicious - various Instagram shots of the Yooke (a sweet, fresh beef tartare served with a quail egg) was what brought us to this spot in the first place.And how difficult it was to get in! Make sure to come early, because wait times of up to two hours are not uncommon (however, our table opened up after only one). Despite the seating delays and hefty prices, the food and service justify your sacrifices. You may never eat fresher ingredients, and the staff is friendly and helpful along your journey through some of beef's more obscure parts.For those with palates meek and timid, the kitchen also offers some more typical beef dishes such as the Kobe Filet Mignon, grilled at your table and dunked in a boiling garlic butter bath. They may serve almost nothing but beef, but I've got no beef with that!

Only highlight for this place was the niku-uni (uni atop chuck flap, shush, and nori). The overall grilling experience was decent but Korean BBQ is infinitely better. I hate to pay extra sub charges for a refill of salad and kimchi especially with the overinflated prices per meat item. Also the protein portion was extremely stingy. Â Not pictured is the liver and heart proteins. The liver was horrendous! The other cuts of protein (beef belly, cheek, heart, and ribeye) ordered were good but stingy portions!Tip: go to the many amazing options of BBQ in ktown unless u want blow ur money in this place. Ban chan and refills are complimentary

I would have given this place 3 stars, but the fact that the waitress spilled soy sauce on my girlfriends pants and only gave her a wet napkin and said sorry, was the last straw. Â She had to spend five minutes in the bathroom trying to get them not to stain, and then walk around the rest of the night with a big wet spot. Â No "let us pay to have your pants cleaned" or "here's a free dessert". I can appreciate good food (the food here is fantastic) , and I don't mind paying for it ($168 for two), but we were rushed, the portions were incredibly small, again, the spill, and we left hungry. There's too much good food in New York to put up with that kind of service. Oh, and the "complimentary" cabbage is $2 if you ask for a refill. It's a tiny plate of raw cabbage! I just paid $32 for 6 quarter size pieces of meat. Give me some free cabbage.
