Pricey and salty Japanese BBQ. Â We got there around 6pm to avoid having to wait. Â They don't take reservation unless it's for party of 4 or more. Â But surprisingly it wasn't crowded, but then again it was a Wednesday night. Â We ordered foie gras stuffed mini Kobe meatball with chocolate BBQ sauce, bone marrow & crawfish dumpling w/hot peanut oil, the tongue experience, Kobe short ribs, bakudan, beef pancetta, baby whitebait fish & monkfish liver ajillo cooked in tin and chef's selection. Â Our chef selection included 1st stomach, 2nd stomach, sweetbread, liver and heart. Â Most of the food we ordered was a bit too salty. Â My fav items were tongue experience, Kobe short ribs and beef pancetta, baby whitebait fish & monkfish liver ajillo. Â I think we over cooked tongue and the chef's selection. Â Restaurant was too dark to see the food we were cooking. Â The one thing I didn't like is that the food came out too quickly and waitress told us how to cook it but it was too much at one time. Â We forgot how long to cook certain items. Â My recommendation for the restaurant is have one item brought out one at a time and let the customer enjoy and cook that item properly. Â Pace it out to 15 mins for items that we need to cook ourselves. Â Not all diners know how to cook and thus giving us all the raw items with instructions at one time can be quite overwhelming.
Amazingly good.. their meat is top grade and their flavors are on point. Love Japanese BBQ. It's a small shop so make sure you make reservations in advance.

This wasn't one of the typical and super popular restaurants that is usually recommended to visitors. Â It wasn't recommended to me, but I am sure glad that I found this wonderful gem and tried it during my first visit to NYC.The food and service were both on point! Â Quality of the food was excellent, my favorite dishes were:Niku-Uni - this is a MUST HAVE, especially if you love uni like I do! Â pieces of chuck flap topped with sea urvhin, mmm!Yooke - my ultimate favorite at Japanese BBQ joints! Â raw, thinly-sliced chuck eye tartare with a raw qual egg in a special sauceTsurami - cheekShio-Tan - tonguebeef bellyI wish I was able to try everything! Because I wasn't able to, I am definitely coming back here the next time I make a trip to NYC :)

The food was great, but this rating is for the fact that the restaurant manager blatantly allowed his friends to cut line when they showed up without a reservation. We had been waiting for close to an hour when a party came in and told the host they had no reservation. At that point they were told the wait would be over an hour. A guy in his thirties with well manicured eyebrows then came from around the bar, gave the Patrons a big hug and then grabbed the seating ipad, smirking as he Â  Stated they did have a reservation and added them to the list. The whole thing was really awkward as I clearly heard the entire exchange and they weren't fooling anyone. They were seated within 10 minutes and we had to continue waiting until the next table was available.The only reason I am giving two stars is for the amazing food and the rest of the staff being very attentive.
Came here for the midnight ramen. My first and only ramen experience.Amazing. Needless to say - the bar has been set very very high. I can't wait to try the other things on the menu.

I've done the ramen midnight seating twice now and it's so damn delicious. Â It's the only all beef ramen I've ever had but this ramen is on par with the ramen I had in Tokyo. Pork belly topping just melts in your mouth. Worth staying up past my bedtime any night :) Make sure you make a reservation!

Great food, amazing service, will definitely come here again. Order: Bone Marrow and Crawfish Dumplings, Squid Ink Rice & Miso-Marinated Sweetbread, Kalbi and Beef Belly - and the ice cream in salt caramel! Get a seat at the bar if you can.
The beef are tender to hell. You have to call before to reserve the 16 kinds of meat tasting experience!I love all their dishes!

It's meat lovers' heaven. Â Takashi has my favorite steak tartar in Manhattan and love everything in the menu with either seasoning. Â Sometime I eat whatever the staffs recommended for the evening and it's always a good meal. Â And if you could, make it to the homemade soft serve iced cream ...

AMAZING! I love ramen, so when I heard this was another "secret ramen place," I had to get here. Ready for my midnight snack, we came ready to indulge in the bowl of goodness. We had the spicy ramen and woah. Blown away! They serve it to you with everything in its place -scallions on one side, intestines on the other, egg here, spicy paste there. Once they present it to you, you mix it all up and prepare for an adventure your mouth will be dying to go on again. The broth was amazing. It wasn't too spicy, but just the right amount of spice. The beef was to die for. It was so tender and so flavorful and it just melted in my mouth. Takashi clearly knows what they are doing with this. The ramen is a little pricey at $17 a bowl, but definitely worth trying. I will say though, the broth seemed to be very greasy. It was good, but I wasn't ready to drink the whole bowl, seeing the amount of grease that was there. If you can get over that, you'll fall in love with this bowl of noodles.

Small place so you're going to smell like korean bbq when you leave this place. We ordered a few appetizers including 2 orders of beef sashimi topped with uni, beef tartar and Kobe meatball stuffed with foie gras with chocolate bbq sauce. Everything was flavorful and the chocolate sauce was interesting in a good way.Then we ordered a bunch of different parts of beef to grill including the tongue, intestines, Kobe beef belly, kalbi, etc. I LOVE intestines but not theirs. It was meh. Everything else was pretty delicious. We ordered the ice cream for dessert because that's the only option. They let you pick the toppings and the sauce. We went with the rice flour dumplings (big-sized Mochi basically) and the green tea sauce. The green tea has that bitter matcha taste and I loved it. Service was friendly.

The restaurant probably is the size of my apartment (And trust me apartments in NYC are small!)- fits around 25 customers and divided into two halves. First half for walk ins and second half for reservations for 4 or more. Â If you are coming in a big group, definitely try to make reservations and if you are coming as a "walk-in" customer be ready to wait. Luckily for me, my friend made a reservation 3 weeks ahead of time. Service was great and staff were very friend and attentive. But that was the best part. Unless you are really into eating weird parts of a cow or "delicacies" this is not the place for you. Portions are small, fulfilling and overpriced.

I think the main word that comes up at Takashi is underwhelming. A few friends recommended Takashi and of course Bourdain raved about the place. Let me explain why it's underwhelming especially if you come before 7 you have an hour wait otherwise it's 2 hours or more. The grilled meats are of higher quality so you're paying about $25+ for 7 pieces of meat slices that are marinated for a few minutes. I think when you start off the meal with the side dishes of kim chi you'd expect the rest of the meal to go up with flavor. The kim chi basically overpowered everything else.The KFC (Kobe beef, foie gras, caviar) app is questionable as the caviar and foie gras really over power the flakes of Kobe beef. The kobe beef wasn't necessary... perhaps it's there for texture but it didn't add anything to the over powering taste of the foie gras and caviar.The ramen quesadilla is interesting in theory but I didn't taste anything.And the testicle/ escargot sauce was also bland.Perhaps everything is suppose to be bland but comparative to Korean food (it'd Korean inspired Japanese food) it's underwhelming. Again, the kim chi overpowered everything else which was way too subtle. Perhaps a palette cleanser would have been nice for inbetween dishes? Maybe having rice on the side with all meat dishes isn't too much to ask. Also our bill for 2 came out to $170 and we still needed to grab a slice of pizza after.

Came here with a good friend because of Anthony Bourdain's show. Â It was hard to spot because there was no sign I couldn't see but once I found it, We were greeted with a cheerful welcome. Â Our waitress was very happy and cheerful to explain the menu to us. Â It was amazing. Â The meat was prepped on the spot, the tartare had great flavor, and so on.The food was great, the service was great, atmosphere was great, and the chefs were wonderful.

Well,it took a while,but I came in for dinner after loving Â the late night ramen. Â  Â  Takashi is one of the best restaurants Â I have ever eaten at,but it is also one of the most original menus I have ever experienced  Â  Â  We started out with the beef tartar which was superb,and I usually don't eat raw beef.The quality Â of all of Takashi 's meat was first rate. Â  Â  The manager,Reece,was a complete gentleman and assisted us with our ordering.We tried a few dishes based on his recommendation Â and they were Â all out of this world. Â  Â  We had the bone marrow,sweet breads, grilled tongue and even braved the brains with caviar! Â  Â  We shared the ice cream sundae Â and it was a great ending to an amazing Â meal. Â  Â Now I know why why many consider Takashi Â to be the best restaurant Â in NYC !

Disclaimer: I have only been to Takashi for the midnight ramen as the ritzy dinner courses are still out of my budget. Anyways, my tip for the midnight ramen is to get it spicey!!! I did not like the aftertaste of the regular Takashi original, because there was a strange aftertaste. I'm not sure if this is related to the bowls or utensils. My favorite part about the ramen is the crunchy beef intestine, which adds a deep meaty flavor to the broth. The braised beef is also quite delicious. Noodles are pretty standard fare. Overall, this is a decent ramen, but I needed the spice to mask the strange aftertaste flavor. It tasted sort of artificial, so I think this could be easily remedied by changing the bowls/utensils.

One of the best Japanese bbq place in NYC. Serving premium wagyu meat and great selection of different part of beef. They only do cow experience from Sunday to Thursday, make sure call ahead to book this meal. We try most of their famous selection from the menu. Usually waiter will let you know which one is popular and good for sharing. We had Takashi KFC, so good, mixed of foie gras and caviar with toasted bread. I don't think there is any bad choice in this restaurant. The only think I will complaint is price. I think this is little over price compare to the amount of food they serving. But you paid for what you get.

Ordered nuki uni, kali, squid ink rice, pork belly, and Ribeye. Uni was good but mint flavor was way too strong and overshadowed the meat. Squid ink rice was uniquely delicious, and all the other meats were tender as well. Unfortunately the portions were tiny. Be prepared to order two or three times your usual amount.

Long overdue review! This place is dope dope. That's right.. i said it twice! Ever since this place showed on Anthony Bourdain's No Reservations, i knew i had to try it. This place is small but they take reservations which is a good thing, just not for people who want to do a walk-in. All three time I've went was a walk-in, quoted about 2 and half hr wait. Due to the natural of people canceling and just not showing up when they were called., our wait time was usually less than an hour. Takashi doesn't have a bar but while you're waiting for your seats, you can actually order a bottle of sake or drink to ease the wait time. Menu has a lot of the lesser eaten parts of the cow which is awesomeee!The MUST get - Niku-Uni ( chuck flap topped with sea urchin and fresh wasabi)- Yooke ( (thinly-sliced chuck eye tartare in special sauce )Both items are raw but the quality is second to none matched by absolute freshness. That's pretty much Takashi's theme in a nutshell.For the grilling session, I'd recommend the Kalbi or the Rosu ( ribeye ). The flavor of the beef when cooked perfectly needs no sauce and the marbling on it is like a meat lover's wet dream . Downside is that you get 4 or 6 pieces ( can't remember) which leaves you begging for more. At about 20ish an order, it can add up. If you're adventurous, give the Testicargot (cow balls made escargot style) a shot. With an updated menu since my last visit, i'll be returning sooner than later. Takashi is not for the faint of heart but you'll need to throw this on your bucket list.

Everything was delicious. Didn't even look at the menu and went off recommendations from the waiter. Like:- Beef belly- Beef tartare- Niku-Uni- Squid ink rice- Filet with garlic butterDisliked but glad I tried it: - Testicargot- Calf's Brain Cream

Review on service not food.I made a reservation for three on Tuesday over the phone for my birthday on Saturday. When I get there 10 minutes before my reservation time I am then told that they actually couldn't seat me because they only reserve for four and over (which I should have been informed over the phone). The host then said that she meant to call me, to let me know. I asked if I could go on a list hopefully still being able to have the birthday dinner I planned for. The host (that took my original reservation) then said they wouldn't be able to serve me at all. I was told they were going to be busy until the end of the night... It was Seven pm.. My friend was so mad she almost went off on her but, it was my birthday so I was not going to deal with any drama. I made a reservation and they never called to even tell me they would not honor it. I wasted my time going to that restaurant and having my friends meet me there. I left it at that, and went to kbbq 10 minutes away.

Had no idea what I was getting myself into here. Stumbled on this tiny tiny place and I was blown away. So unique. They have some really really exotic meats and organs on the menu. Not for the feint of heart. But you should definitely get out of your comfort zone and try some. Loved the Nikki-uni, steak tartare, quail egg, Kobe, and bone marrow. So delicious.

I came here for the ramen on Friday night--we had 12am reservations, and were running late, but the place was very accommodating. Good start. When we got to the restaurant, we were checked in via an iPad. Since I'd called ahead of time to tell them we were going to be late, they'd already marked us and set up our table. Each table is outfitted with a grill, against a backsplash of cute little cartoons. Â The grill is low, so it's easy to hit our knees accidentally. Luckily, our waiter warned us before seating us. The ramen menu boasts two types of ramen, both featuring the beef broth that has been lovingly cooked for 13 hours to maximize the flavor and richness of the beef, the staple of the restaurant outside of their Friday/Saturday late-night ramen hours. The two choices were original ($16), and spicy ($17). The spicy feature's grandma's spicy sauce, a classic Asian spicy sauce that has a distinct taste--it's a tangy chili-heavy flavor, with chili seeds for good measure. They were also offering their menu of sake, of which there is only one hot option, but they did have unfiltered sake. We got a carafe of unfiltered, mild sake ($24) to split between two people. The other two people in our party opted for coke, and a light spritzer drink. Out of the four of us, we got three bowls of ramen. My roommate and her boyfriend were splitting a bowl, since we'd gorged ourselves on apps beforehand at home. But my boyfriend and I each got our own--he got the spicy, and I got the original. Both come with beef, beef belly, crispy intestines, and a soft-boiled egg. The ramen was served in a roomy bowls, the ingredients floating in the rich broth, swirling with grease from the beef and the spicy sauce, when applicable. The crispy intestines had a bacon-y flavor, and I barely registered or considered the fact that I was eating a pretty strange part of the animal. The beef was tender and perfect, melting into the broth and offering it even more flavor. The noodles were fantastic--the perfect "al dente" (ramen edition) texture, thin, and springy. They were fantastic for the broth, which was not too heavy. To help you with the amazing broth, you get your own ladle--Takashi's had a square, flat head that was strange at first, but proved to be as efficient as a rounded ladle. I think that the ramen was definitely some of the best I've ever head. Definitely top 2. The only downside is that it was pretty pricey for a bowl of ramen... But worth it.

Great services and interesting food! Â The sweetbread caviar appetizer and chef's choice cut for the BBQ were super delicious. Â I don't know how they make all the intestine cuts so tender. Â Normally they are chewy and need to be cooked for a long time to soften them. Â We also liked their soft ice cream.

Wanted to check this place out after seeing it on Anthony Bourdain. We first came on a Friday night but the wait was 3 hours so we passed, came back again on Monday when they opened at 6pm and got seated right away. The restaurant is very small and only take reservations for groups of 4 or larger so be prepared to wait if you are a party of 2! They do provide a free side of kimchi, soybean sprout and salad when you sit down so you have something to munch on right away. The menu is large so look at the pictures of the foods on YELP first or ask questions!! Our server was amazing, knowledgeable and took the time to recommend menu items. We ended up with:1. TAKASHI'S KFC ($38)- this was AMAZING. Salty and savory. TRY THIS!2. BONE MARROW AND CRAWFISH DUMPLINGS ($16)- good but nothing special. Just tastes like the inside of a dumpling to me. I would skip and save the $16.3. NIKU-UNI ($26)- a lot of people raved about this but I wasn't a big fan. Maybe it's the texture thing with the raw beef or the sea urchin which was very strong. It also comes with a side of wasabi and a dipping sauce so there are a Iot of complex flavors. It's very expensive if you don't like the fishy taste.4. GRILLED BEEF BELLY ($20)- flavorful and so tasty. Thin strips that grill in just a minute.5. GRILLED FILEY ($30)- cubed and came with a side of melted butter and garlic in a tin placed in the middle of the grill. They recommend you grill then place the meat in the tin to "braise" and then grill again. OMG it was so good. I ended up dumping the leftover butter/ garlic into my rice with a little bit of dipping sauce and ate it! Overall the meal was very expensive for the portion sizes but worth trying.
Was easy to make a reservation on Yelp and we were seated right away. Service was great and friendly. Food was absolutely delicious but portions are small.

I can't help but love Takashi.The meat here is very good, and I haven't had a cut I don't like. Â The tongue, though chewy, is delicious, and the wagyu cut is also great. The sauces compliment the meat in an excellent way and I love the experience of grilling the meat yourself, which is often not done at most korean bbq places.The uni and beef tartar, though I love both of those things, I did think was a bit underwhelming. Feel free to skip on this app. Â The beef pork buns with spicy mayo, however, are a must for an appetizer -- don't miss these.Takashi is unique and not just great food but a great experience as well. Still dying to try their ramen.....
This place is pretty special! The food is amazing and cooking in the table BBQ is always exciting! It's pretty hot so don't wear your turtleneck ;)

1.U.s. Kobe Marbled Chuck-flat Steak2.Squid Ink Rice & Miso-Marinated SweetbreadsIts my recommendation!!!... Then ...Been here twice. It's really good for Taste good quality beef. And they have all parts of beef.( liver, heart, intestines), and at 12:00am they evan have Ramen. Wish I could have a chance to try it.

I've been dying to try this place since it aired on The Layover.A new Japanese bbq place in the city? Hell yeS!And the Niku-Uni looked amazing!So we ventured in on a Friday night. I looked like a scmuck, in a black tank top and grey cotton pants and my hubby in a tee and jeans. No one cared. Other people were in tank tops, or summer dresses. Tip: Get seated by the bar and you can watch the chefs prepare every bite! If you get a table seating, the chefs back is to you the whole time. We were seated in 5, ordered niku-uni, foie gras burger, tsurami, hatsu, scallion vinaigrette and kalbi.The Niku-Uni was as delicious as I imagined! I loved the textures of the crisp seaweed with the smooth richness of the uni and the buttery taste of the Kobe beef. Must have!And please take your time to appreciate the flavors and textures! I watched a couple next to me wolf it down and I wondered if they even chewed before swallowing.I also watched the same couple load their grill with stacks of meat. One of them said, "Hey this beef is still raw" (after grilling for 10 s). This is what NOT to do. The Kalbi was buttery rich, well marbled beef with Takashi sauce. I closed my eyes and let my tongue do all the interpretation. This was a romantic, bonding moment. My husband and I did not say much but our eyes and the food did all the speaking for us. It was a wonderful soul fulfilling meal. I didn't want to lose the taste of this last dish so no dessert/coffee/tea or gum for me. I went to bed blissful happy.
This place offers a lot of choices! You will be surprised that there are so many edible part of a cow. And they are all tasty! SORRY cow! I'm not after chicken tonight.

I wanted to come here for a long time, so I had pretty high expectations. Â While the service and the ambiance were great, I was disappointed by the food.Squid Ink Rice & Miso-Marinated Sweetbreads - Rice tasted okay but both the rice and sweet breads were mushy. Â Texturally, the dish would have been enhanced with crispy sweet breads. Â Blue Ribbon's version of this dish is much better.Niku-Uni - Beef was delicious with a generous help of uni, but the beef overpowered the delicate taste of the uni. Â This is probably meant to be eaten in one bite, but I insisted on eating it in two and had a difficult time cutting the beef with my incisors.Tongue Experience - Definitely not the best tongue I've had. Â (Hmm. Sounds a little dirty). Â I prefer thin tender slices seasoned with salt and pepper and grilled. Â No sauce.Beef Belly - These marbled beautiful pieces of meat were my favorite. Â The fat coated your tongue and melted in your mouth.

This place is unassuming from the outside... Almost walked right past it. However, the food on the inside speaks volumes.This is my kind of place. A shrine to meat. Nary a vegetable on the menu. The curtains to the kitchen proudly states that.Mega rib. Only three available each night. Get it if you can, even if you're there by yourself. It's fantastic. Cooked in the oven beforehand, brought out to your individual grill. Then seared with the bone off, drenched with bourbon, and set aflame. Hand cut in front of you on a carving board, aroma just filling your nose. Heavenly.Beef belly. Soft. Marbled. Melts in your mouth. Get it.Niku uni. Sea urchin (no briny taste... Texture of sour cream) on top of a tender slab of raw beef, a leaf, and seaweed. Unique, tasty, unlike any other sea urchin i've ever had.Service was great. Waitress and hostess were both polite and patient. Would come back in a heartbeat, as long as they have a seat for me!

Awesome midnight ramen!!! A tad pricey, but it's worth it once in a while. My friend actually forgot her credit card at the restaurant, but they were nice enough to keep everything safe until she came back to retrieve it!! Definitely will come back during normal dinner hours.
Place is very clean, cozy. Â Food is a little expensive but overall satisfied. I recommend this place if you want to try Japanese/Korean bbq.

Went here for the ramen. They take walk-ins now, but if you want to be seated immediately, email or call them. I emailed them the day of and got to secure a reservation for that night.I ordered the original and all the components of the ramen were on point. The staff were friendly and attentive, but not overbearing in anyway. I don't know if it is worth mentioning, but perhaps it is, since it kind of affected my eating experience for the night. The only minor thing was the ladle used for the soup and ramen noodles smelled very strong of dish soap and I hesitated to use it. I ended up not using it and continued happily eating my dish with my chopsticks.Overall, I am very happy I went and got to taste one of the best-tasting ramen you can find and have in nyc, hands-down. I will definitely be going back to try Grandma's Spicy Ramen.

We were there obviously for the well known niku uni! We weren't disappointed, it was great! Very fresh uni on top of a piece of thin beef sounds like a unique combination! I could eat 20 pieces of it. The place is small and crowded, and they don't accept reservation for people less than 4, we were told we had to wait for 2 hours, but were called about 40 minutes later.

I was generally not a fan, although I will say it's a pretty unique experience. They have a ton of unusual meats and dishes on the menu. I'm a pretty adventurous eater, but my first complaint is that there wasn't ANYTHING normal. I'll all for branching out with a few weird meats, but then I'd like to be able to order some sort of non-meat appetizer or side to accompany the meal.I agree with other reviews about it being too overpriced for grill-it-yourself, especially given the tiny portion sizes. Additionally, and I'm not sure if this is fixable or not, but since you're cooking on your table the heat emanating from the center of the table is overpowering. I attended the restaurant on a double date, and we had trouble hearing the other couple because we had to lean so far back from the table to avoid the heat. I would recommend that the restaurant only dial up the heat at your table for the ~15 - 20 minutes when you are actually cooking the meat.

The food at Takashi is delicious. Its obvious that they take their ingredients, and especially their meat, very seriously. The raw dishes are excellent, especially the beef tartare with the quail egg.Desert was pretty great as well; one of the most delicious ice creams I've had in a long time.One minor nit is how difficult it is to get a table here, and the long and uncertain wait time after you put your name on the list. Since its also quite expensive (but worth it), why not take paid reservations for small parties (e.g. 2 people)?Strange suggestion for diners: bring along a timer (maybe one of those things they use for speed chess?). You will want to make sure you grill your meat carefully. I found myself constantly counting seconds in my head as I raced to flip my food over on the hot grill.I will be back for the ramen.

Everything is simply magnificent. Best place in NYC period. Beef belly and ribeye are by far my favorites, along with the uni on thinly sliced beef appetizer. The staff is very kind and welcoming, also explains everything you need to know very well. Without a doubt worth even a four hour wait. A place you must must try at least once.

Do you like red meat? Do you really, really, really like red meat? If the answer is yes and yes, then Takashi is right up your alley. Here, you can get something called The Cow Experience. Imagine that. Not only does Takashi provide succulent portions of kalbi and beef belly for the meat lover in most of us, but it goes a step (or 10) further: you can indulge in myriad other parts of the cow such as the heart, the tongue, the second stomach, the intestines. If that doesn't satisfy your meat lust, not sure what would! In all seriousness though, if you're a little squeamish hearing this (which I don't blame ya), you may be pleasantly surprised. When each type of meat is cooked the right way, the result is something delicious, familiar and far different from the beastly gore that you might imagine. First time I came here, I was blown away. It was years later that I recently returned, and although it wasn't as mind-blowing as I had remembered (typical), the meal was still delicious. I should clarify that if you're looking to gorge on meat, this might not be the place for you. Each serving is quite small, and for the price point, you might as well get yourself to an all-you-can-eat Korean bbq place to satisfy your (bottomless) meat lust. If, however, you want to shock your palate and try something new, go to Takashi! Some of the highlights of my recent meal included the beef belly, which I found juicier than the kobe beef, and the squid ink sticky rice, which was pungent and definitely a specialty you should try.Service was excellent. They are very attentive, I think partly because of how crowded this place gets later in the evening, so they want to make sure you get your fill and leave without delay. Note: they only take reservations for parties of 4+. When we arrived as a party of 3, they tried seating us at the bar instead, which would've been a tad less comfortable than the tables. Then, for some reason, they changed their mind and allowed us a table. This seemed a little stingy. I also noticed there was already a couple sitting at a table that could seat 4 people. Hmph.

Takashi is as much experience as it is a delicious eatery.Its signature dish, Niku-Uni, is a sea urchin layered over a piece of raw beef with marbles of fat wrapped in a shiso leaf and nori. Quite the mouthful, it is a morsel of intense pleasure orchestrating taste notes you have never heard. Definitely a must-try.The tables sport a mini grill in the center where you get to cook your second stomachs, sweetbreads, and hearts. The spicy Kimchi is some of the best I have tried.Looking forward to coming back and trying the midnight, spicy ramen special!

Great food! A meat dish usually gives u 8 slices so it could get pricey. The food is amazing quality. I come here when I have guests visiting town. Book in advance if you have a party of 4 or larger. They don't accept parties smaller than that.

Went there at 6:50 pm. I smelled the food when I went in. Smoke was everywhere. Waited for 1 hr 40 min for a table. Miso cabbage, bean sprouts, and kimchee are the compliments; I didn't have to order side dishes. Ordered beef belly and tails. Belly have more muscle that fat like pork belly. Tails were tough. Offered a drink while waiting. The grill consists of a bucket of water, electric rods, and a ceiling vent, unlike the smokeless grill at Gen and Gyukaku. Got there by PATH as the station was two blocks away and the route was more direct than the subway.

It was the most worth $90/person (including tip) satisfying meal i've ever had. Everything was perfect. Me and my friend had plum wine, raspberry soju, unika-uni as and squid ink rice as a starter, between the rib meat, tongue, beef cheek and belly. Damn! I was in heaven for around 1,5 hours. Host was sweet, service was great, we had nice server named Reece! Will definitely be back here!I wish I make $500/day so I can eat here everyday!

Went for midnight ramen. Probably the most unique and one of the best bowls of ramen I've ever had. The crispy intestine is terrific. I would get ramen here more often, but you almost always have to get reservations beforehand.Probably one of my favorites ramen in NYC.

While Takashi has long operated as a yakiniku joint, it was only recently that this restaurant joined in the latest ramen craze to hit New York. Appropriately, Takashi now serves the only all beef-based ramen in the city, and given the outstanding feedback received from multiple sources, I'd only grown more and more anxious as the weeks went by. Getting a bowl of Takashi's ramen isn't as easy as one might assume; it's served only on Friday and Saturday evenings at midnight, and reservations need to be made on the Monday of that same week.Once the reservation gets confirmed, it's easy enough to show up to Takashi the night of. The restaurant is conveniently located in West Village, and although the storefront is small, it's hard not to pass by the growing crowd of waiting guests on an otherwise empty street. We arrived a few minutes prior to opening, and after seeing off the lingering guests from the last yakiniku meal, the staff was quick to make the change over for the Midnight Ramen. We gave our names to the host and were promptly shown to one of the grill tables, which had chopsticks and a large spoon already set for us.There is a menu for the Midnight Ramen that lists the two options (Takashi Original and Grandma's Spicy), although the only difference between the two is that the latter has a generous serving of the special "spicy paste". There's also a number of additional toppings and add-ins, such as the Kobe beef belly, kaedama (noodles), and the Foie Gras Sensation, which will add a succulent piece of foie gras to the bowl, although it comes at a rather steep price ($14). I was wary of how overpowering the foie gras addition would be, however, and decided to stick to the Grandma's Spicy Ramen for my order.As for the ramen: The broth was a dark brown and opaque, and flecked with several droplets of oil. The promised nori (seaweed), kasu (crispy intestines), half of a soft-boiled egg, and the spoonful of spicy paste were all spread across the top. At first sip, the broth has an unmistakable meaty, and deeply savory flavor to it, highlighted by the aromatic additions of garlic and ginger. There's a thickness in consistency to the broth which only adds to the richness, yet, each spoonful achieves that difficult balance in pungency and unctuousness. The noodles, custom-made by Sun Noodles, are thinner and slightly wavy, and cooked to a slight al dente so that they complement the rest of the bowl. The kasu, a creation originally from Osaka, are chewy and retain their exterior crispness despite being submerged in the broth and call attention to the many possibilities of offal. The soft-boiled egg is done to a tee, and the luscious beef belly somehow manages to retain both a sinewy yet melt-in-your-mouth consistency, all the while imparting that delightful beef flavor that doesn't get lost in the hours of braising. I've heard mixed responses to the addition of the spicy paste, and I believe it boils down mostly to personal preference. Unlike most rayu, the paste isn't oil-based as it traditionally should be. Instead, it bears more resemblance to the Korean gochujang, which I find is a better addition to an already rich bowl of ramen.In retrospect, it's almost mind-blowing how well Takashi has executed their ramen. Just as the founder, Takashi Inoue, wanted to highlight the influences of his Korean background and Japanese upbringing in his yakiniku restaurant, there's a seamless melding of Japanese and Korean cuisine in each bowl. The focus on the cow, especially the use of the under-utilized offal, is similarly present, and elevated to a commendable point. For ramen lovers and aficionados alike, Takashi's Midnight Ramen is well worth the trip; just make sure to bring your appetite along.

BEST. BBQ. EVER5* BBQ -- Nakaochi Kalbi (between the ribs), Tetchan (Large intestines) and Shibire (sweet breads) are my personal favorites. Grilling the meat by yourself makes the whole experience fun and convivial. 5* for Midnight ramen on weekends. The beef broth is truly amazing and the crispy intestines bits are so yummy.5* for staff. Reece and Lisa are awesome, very knowledgable about all the different cuts of meat if you are unsure of what to order and they are always spot on when recommending what I want.This is a great place to go if you want high quality meat in a fun environment. I. LOVE. TAKASHI.

A cozy BBQ place that reminds me a lot of Japan! If you love good quality of mean, Takashi is the right place to come! Â came here with a Japanese friend and some friends who have lived in Japan, I don't eat meat but they do and they loved everything they ordered, including ribeye, tongue, beef belly, kolbi, Niku-Uni (sea urchin sashimi), beef crostini...and some stuff I can't name, they all really enjoy it. The only thing is that unlike other Japanese / Korean BBQ in the city, if you are pascaterian or vegetarian, then Taksahi is not a great place to be, the selection of seafood or vegetable is limited. I ended up ordering a lot of kimchi, cabbage and spicy cucumber. While these side dishes are also great, they are not cheap for the size they offered. I like the venue itself as well, small and cozy!

One of my favorite places. Everything on Â the menu is amazing. The Niku-Uni is a must get along with the beef tartar. The squid ink rice is also very very very delicious. The wagyu beef and beef belly is tender juicy and super tasty. The yuzu soju is very nice and has nice crisp finish. The Madagascar ice cream with everything and green tea sauce is awesome. The rice balls are my favorite topping. It's nice and chewy. Â It's my all time favorite place. My advice is to come here early when it opens for seating so you van avoid the long wait.

One of the best Japanese barbecue in New York City. I enjoyed it very much with my friends there. Raw beef is a must try food at their store, fresh and delicious. One thing I'm not satisfied is the serve is too small. If you are looking for a place to really satisfy our empty stomach, you probably need another place. You need to spend a lot to fully become full in takashi. But it's $$$, and it's Japanese, so the size is normal. Just a reference for people with full stomach feast demand. In total, a nice and decent restaurants for Japanese and barbecue.
If you love beef this is the place to go. Delicious and every dish was incredible will be coming back!

Niku-Uni (beef with sea urchin on top) was great. I didn't really like the bao (buns). Of the meats, the tongue was interesting (soft), and I don't know if I'd try it again. Kobe beef ribs (kalba?) was probably my absolutely favorite! Gyotoro-temaki sushi I liked and it was a very safe choice, but my Japanese friend didn't.

The food and the service from the wait stuffs was more than wonderful.However, I will say this place is not for large group of people...go with a party of 4 & under is the best. We were a group of 7 and it was very tight. They messed up our reservation, so we were being seated at a 6-people table, then for god knows why they sat another party of 6 right next to us at a 4-people table... So, literally 13 of us were sharing a table for 10. Also, the 2-hour time frame was not enough for large group.One more note...if you go and unfortunately have this hostess with zero smile, just ignore her, don't let her ruin this place for you.

Went here for a couple bday celebration. Â Thanks to Dan who suggested the cow experience. Â It is now offered at $35 and only one platter offered per night with a minimum of 4 people per table. Â Reservation is not hard to come by. Â I got ours one week ahead for a Thursday 7.30pm reservation.We were seated promptly and service was one of the best ones I've experienced. Â Friendly and not pushy.We had the spicy plum wine. Â Certainly interesting but a bit reminiscence of Robitussin. Â And of course we had to order the Niku Uni. Â They look smaller in person ;) Â I enjoyed it, the uni melt together with the marbled chuck flap. Â The chuck flap is very thinly sliced (like other meats they offer) so I almost didn't notice it. Â Though my friend thought it was too chewy.Then the cow experience, comes with 16 cuts of meat, head to tail. Â It started with tounge, cheek, shoulder, neck (I think), aorta, intestine, large intestine, second stomach, liver, heart, sweetbreads, oxtail, and then a few kobe slices. Â We also opted for the Takashi marinate. Â I think the key is the fact that all these items were sliced really thin. Â They provided clear guidance on cooking time. Â One of us actually used a stop watch to ensure we follow. Â My favorites are the tongue, shoulder, and of course the kobe cuts. Â We were taking our time to cook them one by one. Â I was initially nervous that we will leave hungry but after the meal, we were comfortably full. Â I guess you do get full when you eat slower. Â Overall, a very interesting experience. Â For the price tag, not sure if this will be our staple restaurant but glad that we tried it!

Okay. Call me crazy, but the best experience I had here was the infamous 'Midnight Ramen'. Just do it and make your life complete. But! Needless to say, all the other food I have had here has been GREAT. Excellent place for groups and a fun dinning experience.

Everything was superb! You have have to order to kalbi. The best cut of meat for us that night. Not even the wagyu A5 with golden specks could top the kalbi. Get the dessert with green tea sauce. Too much topping will just ruin it for you. Will definitely be back if I'm back in New York. I would love to give five stars for the whole experience but we were not offered the coat storage service and ended up with jackets smelling like barbecued meat for the rest of night.

Takashi---------how could you be hidden for long! It's the best Japanese-Korean BBQ restaurant in NYC. We ordered uni-niku: pretty goodTecchan:aww amazing Shio-Tan: best shio-tan in NYC Harami: very soft and tender.you must orderAbout soft cream as a dessert, we were very lucky got kuromirsu sauce! We will be back soon:)

The Food and the service were good.Bone marrow dumpling - delicious but not much bone marrow flavorChef recommended plates - enjoyed all the different types of flavors and texturesWagu - tender but too pricy Good place to try Korean-Japanese barbecue style

Back to Takashi after 2 years (just doubled checked my last review. wow!) and I still love it. Went for midnight ramen. Made a reservation about 3 days before. The place was packed at midnight and everyone was ready to eat. Only 2 ramens to choose from, basically spicy or not spicy. I think it was better than two years ago when they came out with it. We ate and left but promised to come back for BBQ!

This is my second time at Takashi and I can't get enough. Â This review is actually for their late night Weekend Ramen Special only available from midnight to 2ish on Fridays and Saturdays. Â Can you say wow?! Â It's definitely one of my top Ramen's. Â I mean it has to be good right, that's all they serve during that time...We reserved for 2 people via email with Takashi and came right at Midnight last weekend. Â We were seated right away and the super friendly servers got us the menu quickly. Â There's only 2 things available, the Original or Grandma's spicy Recipe. Â You can also order braised beef, extra egg, noodles, FOIE GRAS or other ingredients. Â My boyfriend and I got one of each and had to get extra noodles on top of it cause it was so delicious. Â He had the Foie gras on his ramen and that was such a treat. Â It blended so nicely with the taste and add extra fat to make it even more savory. Â I wish I could go back for more!!Overall, the experience was great! We got seated quickly, the food was amazing and the servers were so nice. Â What a nice was to end a weekend night!
Amazing. If you are a meat eater you must go, if you love seafood go. KFC (Kobe, Foie Gras, Canteloup) is unreal. The food is decadent and delicious. Need to come back and try the midnight ramen.

I love meat, and maybe my expectations were too high. Â And while I do think it's worth it to go once to try their unique creations (chocolate sizzling meatball, testicargot, kobe-stuffed large intestine, 1st/2nd/4th stomachs), I can't say I'd rush to go back. Â It's all pretty tasty, but just so damn expensive for the amount of meat.Like some others have said before, be prepared to order a LOT of different platters of raw meat in various forms to satisfy any carnivore's craving for grilling. Â Like Gyu-Kaku (a similar Japanese BBQ establishment), you choose from a long menu of meat and basically decide as a group how daring you want to be.I went with a group of 6 people, and each person in our group chose a couple options off the meat menu. Â However, we each ended up spending about 1.5x what I spent at Gyu-Kaku, since each small meat plate costed $15-25 on average... and left not-super-full. Â Maybe it's so pricey because Takashi is in the West Village, but this really does change my thinking of this place as a meat-fest. Â Especially since I could eat at a nearby all-you-can-eat Brazilian churrascaria for less, which is what I would suggest besides Gyu-Kaku if you really want to stuff yourself with freshly grilled meat.I do still recommend checking it out once to try their original ideas (which are among the more creative ideas I've seen)... but after that first time, can't say I'll be back for sure.NB: I did not get "The Cow Experience", since you apparently have to reserve that menu item in advance... which may have been a much more worthwhile option.

Thymus.I ate a thymus. Â Or perhaps several thymii (?) here. Â I'll admit we ate it more for the novelty; I generally don't like organ meats. Â LUCKILY there is a ton of other stuff to choose from if your'e squeamish like me.The kalbi beef, beef belly, beef tongue, and beef tartare are all awesome and delicious. Â The uni/beef/nori appetizer is amazing and I'm a little disappointed we didn't order more of that because it's something that I definitely would never try to make at home on my own. Â Despite all that raw beef, they are quite clean and I didn't feel too worried about any of it. Â The server was very friendly and explained all the dishes and even helped position the light when I needed/wanted to take pics of the food with my camera. Â Bring a healthy limit on your credit card and a not quite so robust appetite as things can easily get pricey...we didn't exactly go nuts (we filled up a lot on rice) but the bill was just under $180 after tip and tax for two people.

A supremely entertaining place, T.H. and I went here to meet some foodie friends for dinner a few months back. Â It's smaller intimate tables with individual grills and darker atmosphere made for a cozy experience with some really delicious meats. Â We ended up ordering the whole cow experience which, if you go, I HIGHLY recommend. Â The whole shebang comes out on a cow shaped platter with little divots for meat to grill on the table grill. Â The server comes over every time they realize you are about to start on a new row and gives you a description of what meats are in the next row as well as the cooking times for each meat. Â Though my details are foggy on each of the cut of meat, I distinctly remember the beef cheek being incredibly tender and wonderful in combination with the Takashi house sauce. Â Additionally, the heart was incredibly tender despite its nature as a tougher cut of meat. Â I would guaranteed drag T.H. back here again for another meal. Â Delicious!

I felt unbelievably greedy when I opened up the menu at Takashi. I came because of the enticing uni on top of raw beef appetizer pictures that I kept seeing floating around on the internet, but what they offered was much much more! All the appetizers here were prime instagram opportunities, like the meatball wrapped fois gras drizzled with hot chocolate sauce and the bone marrow topped with crawfish dumpling dunked in hot peanut oil. My god, just typing all of this gets me all excited again! Â  Last but not least, you MUST order the ice cream here. As boring as vanilla sounds, it's amazing even without the green tea or caramel sauce that they offer.

One of my favorite restaurants in NYC. Tiny place with great innovative food. Sweetbreads, foie gras stuffed Kobe burger, and everything else on the menu. I always order too much because I try to taste everything on the menu. Everything's been good so far.

The interior was a lot more modern than I expected after taking a look at their website. I remember shiny stainless steel, decorated 'chalkboard' walls with cute illustrations, wooden interior, and a really high tech toilet (complete with bidet).The draw of this place for me was their midnight ramen. I emailed them for reservations on a Friday for Saturday midnight and they got back to me really quickly. I had a party of 5 which was a little tight at a table clearly meant for 4 - but no troubles since we fit and there was absolutely no wait, even though our party came split up. I was the only one that ordered the grandma. It was really spicy - I think if I ever came here again, I'd ask for the spicy on the side. I personally loved this ramen. It reminded me of a shin ramen brought to real life (as in non-instant). I absolutely love shin ramen, so I had no qualms. Although I think there might have been too much seasoning - one of my friends likened the broth to not putting enough water in instant ramen. Crispy beef intestines were surprisingly good - wish they were a little crispier if anything. Wish I could afford to spring for the foie gras addition, but as it was, the ramen had enough meat. I would appreciate more noodles, but I'm not sure if it was because of the soju that I just wolfed them down too quickly.Would love to come back for their unique BBQ fare - especially after feeling adventurous with the crunchy beef intestines.They take credit cards, but not Discover fyi.
nice and cozy place, amazing food... crawfish dumplings are my fav!! definitely try. Attentive stuff and great atmosphere, absolutely love this place

This review is specifically about our latest experience at midnight ramen, and not about food.We've been here before, so we were excited about our reservation tonight. We decided to leave home to arrive right on time for our midnight reservation, and walked in at 11:51. Someone walked in right in front of us and asked the bleach blonde hostess if she could change her reservation for that night to include a bigger group. The hostess was super accommodating and said that there would be no problem. Then she turned to us and we gave our name to check in. We sat down in the waiting bench, expecting to be seated shortly, but the hostess came up to us and told us they weren't ready and that we could either 1) wait outside the restaurant or 2) get called when they were ready to seat us. We asked how long that would be, and she said midnight. Keep in mind that the restaurant was empty at this point, and midnight is a couple of minutes away. Surprised that we were virtually being asked to leave, we said we'd take a walk around the block and come back in a couple of minutes. We did, and were at the door again at 12 sharp. Plenty of people had been seated in the five or so minutes it took us to return, including the table that had more people suddenly added to the reservation. Feeling more than a little annoyed, we were ushered in and led to a table with two other people sitting. For some reason, instead of spreading out the people who arrived, we were all clustered together and the middle tables left empty. When everyone is wearing thick layers, you can imagine how awkward it is to be seated so close to a stranger when the place is filled with other empty tables. The couple beside us didn't seem happy, and we soon discovered ourselves why. The table that had new additions was being incredibly noisy, shouting out at random intervals and loudly singing along to the music being played. This is not particularly enjoyable when you're in such a small place and people (like the couple beside us) were clearly trying to have an intimate dinner date. I honestly felt bad for the couple, since they were dressed so nicely and had clearly been very on time to the reservation. At one point, the noisy table got so noisy that the couple sitting beside them asked to be moved and sat down elsewhere. I saw the waitress apologize to them for the noise, but maybe asking the noisy table to quiet down would've been more effective. We also noticed that the service was less than steller. Maybe it's because we are close to the holidays, but some of the waiters were not acting very appropriately. I saw a waiter slap the butt of a waitress right in front of me (!!!) and it seemed like this same waiter/manager was giving somewhat of a special treatment to a table at the corner that had his friends. They were the only ones with a table to themselves, and when they left they all took their coats from a cabinet on the side. Everyone else in the restaurant had their winter jackets resting uncomfortably on their laps or wrapped around their backs on the booths. If coat check was available that night, no one else was told about it.Every other experience I've had at Takashi has been very positive and with great service, but tonight was very disappointing. I don't know if everyone was already in a Christmas mood, but if they weren't ready to give as good a service as every other night, maybe they should not have been open today. I've always been the biggest advocate for this place, but this negative experience has soured my opinion of Takashi.

Although the place is almost 15 min walk from the train station, I really liked the interior design. Â The space is a little tight. Â We went as a large group of 7. Â Each table can comfortably sit 6.The service is great, complimentary coat check to their closet. Which saved space while you are sitting and it won't smell like BBQ at the end. Â We had pork belly, skirt steak, Kobe, and tongue. My favorite is skirt steak. They are all very good and well marinated. Our server was helpful in recommending a set of meal for us when we were all very clueless. Â We all had a good time.One thing to mention is their grill gets really hot and you'll feel like you are next to a sauna if you are too close.

Mmm mmm... been here twice. Our second time we asked our very experienced server to make us an omikasa of her fave dishes. Â They were all delicious:Beef Tatare - don't usually love beef tartar usually but this was done a little differently where the meat was long strip like noodles and so fresh!Squid ink rice and sweetbreads - really goodFoie gras stuffed kobe beef meatball with chocolate sauce - the meatball was over done this time around. Â Was delicious the first timeStewed Beef Tendon Casserole - Tendon was melt in your mouth tender, Â just the way I like it!Grilled liver - a lil iron - ie tasting for me

So my review is bifurcated by their midnight ramen and their BBQ dinners. The former being waaaaaaay superior to the latter.I just found the dinner to be really overpriced for the actual value of the meat presented. I get it, "tee hee let's order testicles to BBQ" has a certain novelty about it, but after you've chosen your fill of eccentric items you're hit with a really large check with a not-so full stomach (even if you choose to eat the cow stomach -- haha bad joke).That being said, the midnight ramen that they serve on the weekends is amazing. Wow. I had the spicy ramen with the foie gras sensation and I can say that it was the best ramen I had in NYC. However, to get a reservation you have to send them an email after 5PM on Monday. Definitely worth it though!

Not bad. cozy but lots of smoke. The food was not bad. They have some food that are not common such as beef stomach and stuff. But wierd thong is that their menu is all korean food and they sell it like its japanese food. Such a copy cat japanese patriot. Haha but try. I like it.

Made reservations for the team a week in advance. Â We were looking forward to this restaurant for the whole week. Â Unfortunately, we arrived 20min late due to traffic. Â When we checked in the hostess told us we would have to wait over an hour for an available table. Â Despite the fact that she had our table still for 8 still open, and also despite the fact that we were only 4 instead of 8. Â She clearly was trying to make a point. Â "Company Policy...."Extremely disappointed given the fact that I had been recommending this place/trying my best to encourage my team to try it all week, we stepped outside and planned our next destination. Â Meanwhile the hostess comes outside as if to try and make amends trying to backtrack and say "oh if you still wanted a table it would take less than 30min". Â  Â give me a break. Â You turned this brand ambassador into a 1star yelper that will continue to warn anybody who will listen about this restaurant's prioritizing of "Company Policy" over Customer appreciation.

AMAZING DINNER!Docking one star for the price to food ratio and how we were in charge of grilling our own food. We didn't have any issues grilling everything to the idea medium rare but I can see how this can go totally south if people got their drinks on and then left the meats on too long. We ordered:Uni on Rare Beef - Wonderful combo of creamy/savory/salty. Highly recommended!Tongue Combo - Didn't realize that there were that many diff textures on a cow tongue. Definitely enjoyed it!Beef Cheek - YUM!Beef Toro - OMG. Cow bacon. AMAZING!Make sure you get reservations!

O. M. G.The uni melts in your mouth along that raw piece of meat, leafy green leaf & seaweed.The yooka was incredible. The eye of the meat is the largest part but mixed with that quail eggs & it just gave that oomph in terms of creamy texture. Plus the seasoning?! WOW.My friends & I shared the beef belly & the cheek. The beef belly was a good combination of meat & juicy fat all in one bite. The cheek had a slight crunch to it & tasted so good with that spring of lemon juice!Tends to get really crowded so definitely make reservations prior. I'll be back to try their ramen. Can't wait!

Holy Hell!!We came here for the late night Ramen. They have a great sake menu, and they let you pick your glass!!They have 2 Ramen options, regular and spicy, both come with a half an egg, fried intestine, scallions, a piece of kobe beef and nuri. I ordered the spicy and added another egg. It was really awesome, the noodles were perfectly al dente, the broth was meaty and rich, but lighter than the chicken ramen I've had in the past.The service was great, the ambiance is really cool and laid back. We sat at 11:30pm, and didn't get our ramen until 12:30am, which was torturous, but totally worth it.

Wow... That's the one word I would use to describe a lot of things here. First tip: Get there early, even if you're not hungry because the wait list will already be around 1-2 hours even 30 minutes after they've opened. The place is not big, and you don't have to wait there. There are plenty of things you can do around the West Village while you wait. Once you finally get in, you're in for a tour of japanese delectable bites (grilled and not grilled). You're served some kimchi, bean sprouts, and cabbage while you mull over the menu. For appetizers, we ordered the Niku-Uni (one of the most popular items on the menu), and the Gyutoro-Temaki Sushi. My boyfriend advertises himself as not one for raw stuff but he bravely gulped down two of the uni's. The meat sushi was more up his alley though. He enjoyed that thoroughly. For grilled meats we ordered a total of four plates: Kalbi short ribs, Ribeye, Shio-Tan (tongue), and Harami (outside skirt). You get to choose how the meats are marinated, we chose the Takashi sauce. We also had a side of the Bakudan, which goes well with the grilled meats, as everyone has mentioned previously :)Everything was amazing, from the food to the service :) Â To top it all off, the dessert, as simple as it sounds, is madagascar vanilla ice cream. Get it with the works and choose a sauce. I got the salted caramel, while my wonderful boyfriend got the green tea. I love green tea, and his ice cream was great but omg, i think the salted caramel was even better :) Btw, they also have a bathroom with a heated toilet seat lol. Use the control panel to lift the seat cover or it'll get mad at you :D

My boyfriend and I were visiting Manhattan for the weekend. We had Momofuku for lunch and Soto sushi for dinner on Friday....but Takashi was BY FAR the best food we had all weekend. And it's definitely one of the top dining experiences we've both had. (We're both big foodies and are very open to trying all types of food)Reservations:We called at 5:30pm-ish Saturday and they said they had no openings but offer walk-ins for 2 or less. She said she recommended we come in sooner rather than later. Well, I'm a girl and there is no way I'm not getting dolled up for a night on the town in NYC. By the time we got there at 8pm, there was a 2 hour wait. We just went to a local bar and had a few drinks until 10pm. Make reservations!!The Restaurant:You walk in there and the smell of korean barbecue captivates you. Not your typical K-BBQ smell that makes you worry that you're going to leave with stinky hair. I was drooling before I was even sat. It's very small and intimate. Great for dates!The drinks:We started with a bottle of soju. It warns you on the menu that it's "not for the faint of heart". We said meh and ordered it anyway. It tasted harmless but definitely caught up to us later on that night. I'm pretty sure the soju is the reason why we ended up at an afterhour karaoke bar that night!The food:I loved everything we ordered.Beef sashimi and uni with shiso leaf- the beef was so fresh and the marble was beautiful. I have had a lot of uni in my life and this uni was definitely up there in quality.Sweetbreads-It was so creamy and tasted so fatty, you want to feel guilty eating it. But don't feel guilty. Eat it!Liver- I love liver so it's very hard to unimpress me with any type of liver. This was wonderful and it had that tad of bitterness that I love in a liver.Kolbi- you just have to order this here. It's a staple BBQ and it was also great.The service:She was the sweetest server I've ever met. She was extremely down-to-earth and helpful in suggesting items on the menu. She even asked us about our plans for the night and gave us suggestions for local bars. We were more than glad to give her a fat tip.When we left, we ran into Takashi himself chatting with a friend outside the front of his restaurant. The food was so amazing that I was starstruck meeting him! He was very kind and took a picture with us. Thanks for the food experience, Takashi!

Just love it. Very cute Japanese restaurant with small tables. If you like Korean bbq you must try this place because their bbq is amazing!!! But they do charge for every little dishes such as kimchi. Must try the Yooke! My mom doesn't like raw meet but she loved it. Make a reservation if you want to try the cow experience. I gave a 4stars instead of 5 because the server was very rushed and didn't really care about our table. I will be back because the bbq was great!!
Takashi was bomb! The beef rib was my favorite, best bang for your buck! HUGE rib brought out and cooked perfectly!

I got really lucky with Takashi. Was craving ramen and it was the only place open after midnight. Went in without a reservation, was told it's reservation only but the hostess quickly came back to give us seats. Score! And I didn't even know they only served ramen after midnight on Friday and Saturday. Although, I was really hoping for bbq and ramen.. but I guess I'll have to come back for the bbq. The ramen itself is an all beef broth with beef belly and beef intestines. I got the spicy ramen with the foie gras sensation for a total of $31. The most expensive bowl of ramen I've ever had but sadly, not the best. It was still good... The foie gras was very fatty and was marinaded too much. The broth was flavorful but too oily. I was hoping I wouldn't get a stomach ache as I was eating it. The intestines were yummy but didn't come with much. The egg was spot on. The beef belly was yummy. It's a big slab of tenderness. The foie gras and the spicy paste didn't go well together. It's a clash of flavors.

We had a reservation, but had to wait over 40 mins. Also, we were told table is limited for 2 hrs??If we are spending over $400 with four people, I think we should deserve more than that. We tried many different dishes and overall they were too sweet. Not worth the wait and money.

Such a blast!! Â This place takes Korean BBQ to a whole new level with an interactive experience, but please, no vegetarians...Come on a special occasion, as the prices are high and it is an adventure! Â We had the following:Starters-Sea Urchin: which was a unique medley of flavors and a bit chewy due to the beef, but still very good. (One bite ladies. Â No trying to be cute!)-yooke (tartare): one of the best ever! Presented with a quail egg on top and then mixed together table side - bone marrow and crawfish dumplings: good, but it reminded me of Chinatown dim sum I get for $2. Not worth it- pork buns: same as above Mains- just about everything's, so our favorites were: belly, cheek, tongue, and between the boneDesserts- Ice creams with "the works" Caramel was a little burnt and green tea a little strong, but could not stop eating both!!My only advice for this place is to order a side of rice! It's filling since the portions are small and only meat. Have fun!!

I don't know what people are yapping on about with the niku uni. What, have you never had uni before? Because I know you can't taste the beef. It's completely overpowered by the uni.The chefs selection was a scam. None of the cuts (all offal) are enjoyable when grilled. Liver is easily overcooked especially when in tiny slivers like everything else at Takashi. Stomachs end up being way too chewy unless you undercook them. Tongue experience was unimpressive and skimpy. Your average yakitori spot can do it just as well.Kalbi tasted fine but you're better off at Kbbq since you'll get thrice the quantity plus banchan for the same price. Service was good despite the hourlong wait. My waiter was super friendly and knew his shit. Ambience is cute but doesn't make up for the lazy menu.Overall, a complete waste unless you live for the Bourdain hype and DIY nose to tail gimmick. Pop your innards cherry elsewhere if you're a virgin.

Review is solely for their after hours ramen stint.Two seating times: 12am and 1245am on Fridays and Saturdays. No walk-ins. Reservation is a must and goes pretty quickly. Email your reservation on the Monday of that weekend after 5pm. Replies are very prompt. I've been trying to get reservations to their ramen eats for a month til I finally got one. Sending reservation email after Monday will definitely be futile as I learned after a couple of attempts lol.It's a basic menu. Original ($16) and Spicy Miso. You can add extras in it such as foie gras or beef intestines. No sides. Just ramen. Unlike most ramen in town, Takashi's is beef based. I love pork belly but the beef belly that came with my ramen was too die for. So tender and tasty. And the $14 add on foie gras was aptly called foie gras sensation cause it was sensational. Worth every penny. Super yummy! No other side dish is needed. Pork bun? What is that? My ramen satisfies me enough. If you're a self-proclaimed Ramen connoisseur or a lowly glutton like me, there's no way you can pass this one up. Two thumbs and big toes up!

i randomly picked this place for early BBQ dinner. If only i can pick lottery number like i did with this one :) Â They only take reservation for party of 4+ Â It's a very small place but good food. Staffs were super friendly and knowledgeable when asked "what's your favorite and what do you recommend... " if you have less and want to catch dinner, i suggest you hit the door at 5:30PM or earlier. Â Not only i got lucky on picking the good spot but i was right on time. After a few mins of reading the menu, the line started forming. here are what i ordered Horumon-Moriawase - i did not like this very much but will give you a taste of all the stomachs. I had more exotic stuff so it wasn't something i order to say i ate it :) Shibire (sweetbreads) - yummy, soft and tasty!! Niku-Uni - O M G can i have some more? Yooke - beef tartare, a bit sweet for my taste but still goodKalbi (short rib) - get the US Kobe one - i think i order 2 of theseNakaochi Kalbi (between-the-rib) - i ordered 2 :)Beef-Belly - nice and tender and flavorful my bill came out to be about $200 + tips for party of 2. All meat no rice with a bottle of sake and beer. i'll be back :)

Ramen - mmmmmm.My friends and I came here for midnight ramen. Â I've had tons of ramen. Â Tons! Â This had to be my second favorite bowl ever. Â Ramen is nothing if not a balance and harmony of flavors. Â Takashi hit all those notes aside from one small thing, the noodles. Â I'm of the opinion that the broth is more important than the noodles, but again there has to be some balance. Â What I loved about it all was that the ramen was non-traditional. Â It was obviously Korean inspired and delicious. Â The meat was unbelievably tender. Â They were not stingy either with the portion. Â It always bothers me when a bowl of ramen has a small piece of meat and then you're fishing around for more when there is no more to be found. Â The one thing I wish was that the noodles were a bit firmer. Â This was a common complaint around the table.Although Takashi has been said to be busy and completely full every night for ramen, there were still seats throughout our entire visit. Â This must have been an off night for them since I've heard stories of people lining up down the block to get in even with reservations.If you love ramen, you'll def have to make time in your schedule to go to Takashi.

This is one of those places that I would give five stars if I was already a practicing physician in NYC without too many worries about budget. The food was of superb quality. We had unique dishes that included lots of raw beef vs. beef grilled in front of us, sea urchin, cow testicles, etc. But at the end of the night, was I full? Not in the slightest.This was the asian fusion equivalent of a French restaurant. We paid quite a lot ($30 plus) for what was essentially a bunch of small appetizers/hors d'oeuvres. Everyone I was eating with had a great time and kept praising how much the experience was "worth it" but I couldn't bring myself to appreciate it at the same level. Maybe I'm too stingy? I love places with food like this, but as a student in debt, it made my wallet hurt.

I tried taking my girlfriend here for her birthday on a Saturday. Knowing that would be tricky, I called the day before and asked if there would be much of a wait if I showed up when they opened at 5:30.The person on the phone said showing up at 5:30 should be fine, so off I went the next day.At opening I was given a wait time of 90-120 minutes.Turns out the person on the phone was just wrong - not only was there a line of people outside at 5:30, but only a small handful (maybe 6 total) were seated before the rest of us were turned away. We couldn't wait inside either.I overheard someone asking why this was, and being told "The chef has special guests", and thus letting in quite possibly only 6 people with nowhere to wait inside.I don't mind making a reservation or waiting a bit for a restaurant, but the way this place handles reservations/wait times is not worth the hassle to me. I tried calling in advance the day before, etc etcI also get why they can get away with this, but in my opinion there are plenty of high quality restaurants in New York that don't require going through that process.If I had simply even been told on the phone there would be such a wait at opening due to 'special guests' I would have been happy with that as well.

I love this place. Worth the wait eventhough I have only waited once out of the four times I was here- come early just when it opens to duck the wait time.The food is amazing. My favorites: The Niku Uni (raw beef with Uni- only for people who like Uni and raw beef. My BF hates it but he doesn't like any of the ingredients), Crawfish Bone Marrow Dumpling with sizzling hot oil (delicious I can not describe it, if I could eat it everyday I would.) the cheek and ribeye barbeque (so tender, melt in your mouth deliciousness)It is for meat lovers only- Â do not come here and expect anything but meat. Please. Don't.It is for people who are like adventure in their food! Try Cow brains! Cow Testicles! Cow Stomachs 1-4! Cow Cheeks (which we found to love and order often!). I sampled everything. They have meatball foie gras with chocolate (which is pretty good!). From the cow brains to the different types of stomach I can say so much about it. Â The only dessert they have is their soft serve vanilla ice cream which you can top with a few things. My favorite is the strawberry sauce... sometimes they have specials all which I love. One of them being honeycomb and some sort of cotton candy like sesame seed tasting thing. Delicious.I have yet to try their ramen. I need to! Next time I come back that will be my mission.

Literally the best meal I've ever had. We had to wait 45 minutes to get a table at 5:30pm on a Friday, but it was certainly worth it.The Niki-Uni literally tasted like the ocean and a forest (in a delicious way) and the the shio-tan (tongue) and kobe beef were so tender. I think the kobe beef was the best thing I've ever eaten. You can really tell how high quality the meat is and the restaurant has a really great, clean, unpretentious vibe. The waitress was also really nice and even brought me a tide to go pen when she saw I got kimchi on my pants.

Super delicious! We're almost eating our tongues. Decorated well and beautiful traditional dinner ware. The Chef's selection, a wrap with urchin(forgot name) and the homemade ice cream worth a try! The only thing we're not satisfied with is that exhaust tube didn't work (or just not strong enough).

Authentic Japanese yakiniku. We got the meat specials of the day and because it was higher quality meat and the restaurant didn't want us to mess it up, the waitress cooked the meat for us and it was perfection. The meat just melts in your mouth. The Kobe/wagyu beef was amazing. We also got the Kobe kalbi, it is to die for. Not too lean, not too fat. What more can you ask for from beef. I thought the skirt steak was okay... Prefer the kalbi. The spicy cucumber was also a nice vegetable to have along with the meats so you can cleanse your pallet a bit. The ambiance of this place is really nice for small groups. Don't recommend for dates since some of the best meats come with garlic sauces. Also you'll smell like bbq meat after dining here (it's inevitable with yakiniku). This place is definitely better than the chain most people go to - gyu-kaku. We got the best meats and spent about 50/person (without alcohol). Come with four people so you can make a reservation. Only parties of 4 and above can make reservations.

This is an interesting restaurant worth exploring further. Â Happened to end up here by mistake, but it was worth coming here.It is a tad overpriced, which in this context is not a problem. Â Like the offering and the richness of the alternatives. The beef is sublime and well executed. Â Some of the organs I just do not like, so no comment on those.Cannot speak about the ramen.

A very good dinner option!We went there on a Monday evening for dinner @~6:30. Â The waiter told us there'd be a wait for ~45 min. Â We decided to wait with cocktails which I later thought so glad we waited because the service and food definitely worth it. Â The decoration was quite cool- there was a fruit tree in the middle of the room! The ventilation was quite effective I suppose because there room was cool given there were ~10 grills in the room. Â We ordered two appetizers and three Yaki cuts. Â For appetizers we had the beef brain caviar and uni wagyu sashimi. Â The beef brain's texture and taste was similar to foie gras, and the tiny pancake on which the brain was spread was chewy. Â The uni beef sashimi was interesting, if you are an adventurous foodie I definitely recommend these two. After appetizers we ordered the beef tongues, cheeks and body for Yaki. Â They were all super tasty and memorable. Our waitress was very attentive And made good recommendations. Â I'll definitely be back !

This review is for an aggregate on the food since I really dont remember exactly what we ordered besides the fact that we pretty much ate all kinds of meat, ribeye, shoulder, chuck steak etc. All of the meats were extremely fresh and tender, and they tell you how long to cook it on each side, not entirely accurate at all times but generally a guide. For the harder to cook things like the skewer sausage which was my fav, they cook it for you as it takes about 10 mins and different positioning. The rice they give you is also out of this world, its fluffy soft and not the dry crap you might be making at home... or is that just me?We got one app, Uni Beef Sashimi on seaweed was insanely good and the raw beef really complemented the taste and texture of the uni (and they give you a TON of uni). Each order is 24$ and comes with 4 pieces. We had 5 people but they generously gave us another.Dessert is a must have, their ice cream with red bean and your choice of caramel or green tea drizzle is amazing...Somehow they make their ice cream taste amazing and actually sweeter than what it should taste like. Presentation is excellent too.This restaurant is very small, you cannot fit more than 5 people to a table (2 chairs, squeeze 3 max on the bench). Also reservations are taken for 5:30, 7:30 and 9:30.

Takashi was the highlight meal of a recent 12-day stay in the city. The reviews on Yelp did not let us down. It's yakiniku style so if you aren't comfortable grilling your own meals table side--don't worry--the staff will assist. Of course the great cuts like short ribs and Kobe are there, but the highlight of the meal was the horumon... i.e., discarded parts like liver, heart, sweetbreads. We tried them all (party of four) and they did not disappoint. Only item I personally found that really didn't kill me was the raw Kobe with sea urchin. Mildly disappointing in that it seemed overwhelmed by the seaweed it sat on but it wasn't bad. Just didn't rock my boat. The service is impeccable, the atmosphere comfortable and casual--and lively! Reserve ahead and don't show up unless you're prepared for an opening that may not occur. This place is smoking hot.A destination meal if you're in the city. Pricey but not outrageous. Oh, and don't pass up the raw liver with sesame. My God, these people are geniuses. Must return soon.

I got out foodie by a non-foodie. Â How does that work? Â It's called, magic. Â I love good surprises, I really do. Â Big balloons, pleasant shouts from random strangers, a high-five, guess you can say, I've always felt really comfortable with a bright light shoved in my face. Â Well, Takashi, you did not disappoint. Â I was craving Korean, and well, non-foodie says, "oh, I've been here, it's really good." Just matter-of-fact, like grabbing a sammie at Subway or something. Â So, I'm thinking it's another rando Korean restaurant, cool beans. Â Ugh, no, it's frickin' the most amazing food, ever! Â It's Anthony Bourdain, all day, everyday, twice on Sundays. So the menu is not for the faint of heart (literally). Â They serve all kinda of animal body parts soaked in the most delicious sauces, and grilled to perfection. Â For example, the fois gras with chocolate sauce? Â Booyah. Â Short beef ribs buns w/ scallions and love, topped w/ this spicy mayo. Â Daddy. Â And of course, the most juicy slab of prime beef bbq'ed in front of you (the waitress cooked it because we were lazy and she did one heck of a job).
