Â If I wasn't drunk off two nyquils (and full), I could have eaten that entire thing. Â Mind you, we were not that adventurous eating here, but people sitting next to us, were eating all kinds of "meats" and lovin' it! Â I've just never been a huge fan of intestines. Â Hearts - pretty darn tasty. Â Chicken butt - excellent. Â But, brains and livers, unless it's duck, not really my thing. Â Yes, it's a Japanese-Korean fusion place, the menu is extremely creative, and if you're a foodie, or even if you're not, but like to just put things in your mouth (that's what he said), Takashi is worth every bite. Â Out foodied by a non-foodie and I was pleasantly surprised? Â Fist-bump worthyyyy. Â  *bow*
This place might not be for you if you're not adventurous. Great selection of high quality meat. The uni over raw meat is to die for. It's a bit pricey, but i don't know any other place like this.
Highly recommend!! Met the owner randomly sitting next to us and bought us a bottle of sake!

To enjoy Takashi, one must fully embrace his or her inner carnivore and indulge without prejudice against offal, since it is, without question, the star of the show here. Â If you can't handle offal, they do offer some "normal" cuts. Â But really, don't even bother coming here if that's the case. Â Just don't. Â There are many other places to go get traditionally boring food.When you enter, one of the first things you might wonder is whether Takashi is a Japanese restaurant (since the name sounds it), or if it's a Korean BBQ house (as the grills at each table would suggest). Â The short answer is both! Â It's called Yakiniku, which started in Osaka, Japan, by Korean immigrants. Therefore, it's no surprise that Chef Takashi is an ethnic Korean from Osaka, and he has graced New York with this special delicacy from his hometown.The menu has a lot of options and can be a little intimidating, especially if you don't know what to get because too many things sound good (as was my table's case). Â To make it easy, we simply let the staff handle the ordering decisions for us, and we were not disappointed. Â The selections were brought to the table one at a time, with each new offering seemingly better than the last. Â And thanks to the amount of Soju I drank, it's too difficult for me to recall all of the dishes that were consumed over two hours, however, some honorable mentions include the Calf's Brain Cream (with blinis & caviar), the Yooke (chuck eye tartare in special sauce), the Niku-Uni (chuck flap topped with sea urchin and fresh wasabi), the Tsurami (cheek), the Tongue Experience, the Tetchan (large intestines), and lastly, the three stomach choices listed on the menu. Â As for some other details about the restaurant... Â It's not too big nor too small, but is warm & inviting and has a very Japanese feel thanks to the extensive use of wood throughout the interior. Â The service is first class. Â Again, we had the staff make our ordering decisions for us, and they were extremely attentive and friendly. Â They also went into great detail explaining each dish along with recommended grilling times, etc.If you're adventurous and looking to try something new that will be memorable and delicious, definitely consider Takashi. Â I'm already planning my next visit!

This review is for the midnight ramen only. There's only two options for the ramen, a spicy $17 and not spicy $16 version. Since I was doing the $14 Fois Gras Sensation add on, I didn't want to risk too much the chili paste overpowering it so I asked for it on the side. Surprisingly on the side meant $16 regular + $3 Grandma's chili paste add on meaning it cost me $19. That plus the Fois Gras Sensation + $14 is $33. The chili paste on the side was very peppery and overpowering so I only ended up using 1/2 the amount in the soup. It was very thick and difficult to mix as the broth wasn't that hot. The Fois Gras Sensation is a grey gelatinous blob. I'm not sure if it was cooked enough or just a bad cut. It doesn't taste like any fois gras I've ever had and wasn't pleasant. It was also cold in the middle. I pick up flavors as if it was marinated in some sweet wine and soy as well. That texture of grey gelatin with the sweet alcoholic undertone is gross. The thin noodles were cooked well and the beef broth was very flavorful. I wish the temperature had been hotter. The braised beef belly was very delicious, tender and falling apart with the cut having the perfect balance of lean and fat. The crispy small intestines added a nice texture to the dish and the pieces that weren't completely folded into the soup had a nice crispy crunch. The first server was nice and asked if I was there for the first time and explained the menu to me. A different server took my order so I'm not sure if the first would've just charged me for the spicy and noted chili on the side instead of the +3 up charge for the add-on but be careful about that. You also need to ask for your water to be refilled every time as you will not get any no matter how empty your glass is and how many times they pass by your empty glass. The broth really shines and I just wish everything else could be better.

Um yes please. When people know you are a foodie and your cousin and one of your best friends want to take you to the same restaurant on different days without talking to each other, you know the place has to be good. Takashi didn't disappoint! It's a small place, reservation only for parites of 4 or more and they are booked weeks in advance. We waited for over an hour and a half but it was so worth it. You essantially grill your food. Their food was super fresh and their service was great. They source their beef from the northwest and it's worth it. Takashi uses every part of the cow and they do it marvelously. Every dish I had had great flavor. I grilled my meat and only put a little bit of salt and pepper only, it's all it really needed. You have to go, it's a different experience from anything you find elsewhere. I'll stop talking now... just go.

Terrific food, vibe, and service. Took a tour of the menu and sample chef's choices as well as some of their best sellers. All the Kobe beef dishes were excellent as was the chef's choice organ meat platter. Highlights included the foie gras stuffed kobe beef meatballs with quail egg and spicy chocolate sauce. It was the perfect 2nd-last course (kind of pre-dessert). Also, the Niki-Uni was delicious (a sort of kobe carpaccio with uni and seaweed), and of the chef's choice organ meats, the beef heart was perfect and the 1st stomach was far more tender than the 4th. This restaurant is a must try, and a must be adventurous. It is worth it.

This review is about the midnight ramen and nothing else.Best. Ramen. In NYC. Right Now.Despite the hurdles they create by making you make a reservation on the Monday before your intended ramen meal, once you get there at 12 or 1 AM and they set down the most aromatic bowl of ramen in front of you, everything else gets forgotten. The garlicky, rich, meaty broth is so scrumptious I still think about it, months later. On my ramen quest of NY I have tried the best and the top secret places, and yet Takashi left a special note in my heart.

This is a very special place that should be reserved for special occasions. The Kobe beef we were served was without exaggeration the finest beef that I have ever eaten in my life - which is not to disparage anything else on the menu, as it was all delicious.When celebrating anything, consider Takashi NYC as the perfect location for a small celebration (downside: a bit cramped for space.)

They serve crack here. Addictive delicious cuts of crack, crack beef. Some people may be scared of crack but after the first time it's much easier . Eat it all. Ramen is good too but the grilled meats are the best. Awesome staff , cool people. Oh yeah , music is on point . Go now .

omg uni over Kobe beef and beef belly are definitely bombing, soooo good! Also, strongly recommend the ice cream dessert (the works) but make all the toppings the white little Mochi thing. Gonna come back for sure :)

I was warned - delicious but pricey. And so it was. Like really really delicious. Also your clothes will definitely smell like oil and food after, so leave your nice sweaters at home. I'd like to try their after hours ramen next.

Simply perfection. I ordered:Uni sashimi - extremely fresh! The uni kind of burst in the mouth with aroma. Wasabi was of high quality as well;Tartare with quail egg - again, very fresh and tender. Perfectly marinated beef and with the egg it had a touch of silkiness;Squid ink rice - the sweetbread was the highlight. Didn't know it could be so tasty!Beef belly & skirt steak - well cut and nice texture.Would love to come back anytime.

Yaki = barbecueNiku = meatTakashi is the best yakiniku restaurant I've been to in NYC; it just does so many things right. Â First off, its small, a proper size for a place specializing in one style and focusing on making it well. Â The attractive dining space has a central prep area with bar seats to look in on the action, and one row of tables along the perimeter. Â Sleek and simple, utilitarian yet handsome. Â Gleaming electric grills set into the tabletops and a thin, black vent that you can pull up or down over the grill (complete with an adjustable spotlight). Â Along the biggest wall is a blackboard just as large, the de facto guide to the meat options, as friendly to the offal-shy lay public as it is to the diehard, food adventurer. Â The descriptions and sketches are cheery and whimsical, not encyclopedic, and do more to convey the idea rather than the details. Â Makes for fun reading.The short menu celebrates all parts cow, and if you're open-minded, it is in so many ways awesome. Â Want to try the first stomach? Â What about the second? Â The third? Â The fourth?? Â Creamed brain in a blini? Â Raw liver? Â Cow balls? Â Achilles tendon? Aorta? Â I was so taken with the menu that it was almost impossible to decide what to order. Â And although the portions are small, all that meat and meat parts fills you up quicker than you think. Â It seems I am destined to go back again, at least until I've tried most of the offerings.DIY beef shank was juicy and intensely flavored, tucked inside pillowy buns. Â Stewed beef tendon casserole was rich and satisfying. Â The mini kobe burger looked more like a giant meatball; the fun starts when you take a bite of it, stuffed with foie gras Â and doused in a chocolately sauce. Â Niku-uni was a particular highlight: nutty uni sitting on top of a slip of raw beef, topped with grated wasabi. Â Uni is a chameleon food that I've had wonderfully paired with so many different flavors and textures, and here it impresses no less paired with the bracingly fresh beef. Â And later added to our order as we spotted it on its way to another table, is the gorgeous yooke, a tartare of thinly sliced, raw chuck seasoned with sesame oil, garlic, soy, sugar, egg yolk, lemon, and possibly more; I am still dreaming of the luxurious mouthfeel of this one.It is worth pointing out again that the beef here is astoundingly fresh, beautiful to behold; it justifies the effort made to source such high-quality meat and the price charged for it. Â In its raw form, it is sublime. Â Grilled, it can be had simply seasoned with salt, garlic, and sesame oil, or marinated in their sauce; we went with the former to better appreciate the meat's intrinsic flavors. Â Mind you, this is DIY cooking; you'll get the tongs and the meat, some pointers on how long more exotic stuff should be left on, then you're on your own (although I'm sure their staff will hand-hold if you needed it).After some debate over the blackboard descriptions of the four stomachs, we tried mino (1st) and akasen (4th), don't ask me why because it was confusing enough to get four people to decide based on their loopy descriptions. Â Suffice to say both these were very, very chewy, giving ample time to savor their respective flavors. Â I personally liked the fourth better, but liked the flavors for both, but the chewiness is putting an end to a repeat in the near future. Â The tongue experience (three types) was also interesting, but in the end, the textures were not appealing enough to me. Â The marbled, tender cheek was universally loved. Â Decadent fatty belly to finish, like butter.Highly recommend that the sides don't get overlooked. Â Their refreshing scallion vinaigrette salad, generous topped with shredded seaweed and sesame, was a perfect foil for the meats, as was their fun "Bakudan" dish of Japanese rice rolled up in Korean seaweed or pickled sesame leaf (the latter could pass for a tubby stuffed grape leaf).As we wound down our meat orgy, the efficient staff cleared out all the plates, shut the grill, and pulled up the vent. Â It seemed criminal not to have their single dessert to end, a vanilla soft-serve with your choice of interesting toppings (rice-flour dumplings, black sesame and soybean flour, azuki beans, hoji syrup, green tea syrup, salted caramel syrup, and goji berry syrup). Â Or just have them all, topped with gold flakes. Â Its enormous, and we shared it just fine with four.Reservations advised, and a max group of 4 would be most comfortable. Â Don't wear nice clothes, you will smell like BBQ when you leave. Â Grilled meats portions are perfect for a group of 4 to try a bit each, but at $12 - $24 per item, it will add up. Â Not too extensive of an alcohol list, but a good selection of sake, shochu, and beers to go with the BBQ. Looking forward to my next round of raw and grilled meats.
Very over priced for food that was not fresh nor the quality they claim, which was upsetting after waiting two hours for a table. The Japanese/Korean fusion did not work for me either.

Takashi Restaurant Do serve AMAZING Japanese Premium Beef kalbi! (What Hideki K. Says!).This Place has been on my TO GO list for over a year and Promised my friend not to go without him (How funny, My Japanese friend's call Takashi too!). Finally, 6 people. Â Up for a challange of quality meats (RAW or COOKED).So here are 2 options for you to choose if you decide to come for a nice meal:Never had this in my life. And It was worth it! Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  ****CHALLENGING CARNIVORE****  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â (WARNING!, EAT AT YOUR OWN RISK!)1) Hatsu Sashimi (Beef Heart) - Raw thin sliced and comes with lime and special sauce to have some flavor. Â This dish is not always available since they need to have it super fresh!. Â yelp.com/biz_photos/6qzNâ¦2) Yooke (thinly-sliced chuck eye tartare in special sauce) - Raw Chuck Eye meat covered with takashi's special ingredients, a great taste and sliced into small pieces for better chewing and taste. yelp.com/biz_photos/6qzNâ¦3) Namagimo (ultra-fresh liver with sesame oil Â and roasted rock salt) - Very chewy, but crunchy and fresh. yelp.com/biz_photos/6qzNâ¦If you don't like RAW, but still want to eat some of this. Â They offer a BBQ Style Meats!Ordered a Chef's selection "Horumon Moriawase" And I got Â Akasen (fourth stomach) Kimo (liver) Hatsu (heart)yelp.com/biz_photos/6qzNâ¦ Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  FOR CONSERVATIVE CARNIVORE:1) Spicy Japanese Cucumber (Spiciness I would say a 4 out of 10?)yelp.com/biz_photos/6qzNâ¦2) Smoked Liver Pate with Yuzu - This was one of my favorite !yelp.com/biz_photos/6qzNâ¦** You can ask for more crackers If you have pate left.**3)Smokey Beef Flavored Popcorn - Shots of Before and After cooking the Popcorn.yelp.com/biz_photos/6qzNâ¦yelp.com/biz_photos/6qzNâ¦4) Bakudan (rice bomb with Korean seaweed and pickled sesame leaf) - A must to get so you can have a smooth flavor of Rice and Meats.yelp.com/biz_photos/6qzNâ¦5) Rib Eye Â - yelp.com/biz_photos/6qzNâ¦Short Ribs - yelp.com/biz_photos/6qzNâ¦Tongue - yelp.com/biz_photos/6qzNâ¦everything was Superb!. Meat quality has met its standards. Service was pretty quick but seating was a bit uncomfortable (they gave us a Â 4 table seat for 6 people). Â After Spending over $ 400.00 on food and drinks. I wish they gave us more space. Â Otherwise I would have given you 5 stars. Â (That means I would not recommend if you are coming Â with a large group since the restaurant is pretty small).

WOW! Takashi is def. a fun experience....especially for my tummy! Every dish was deeeeeelish! I don't quite remember ALL the names of the dishes we ordered since we drank lots of delicious sake (called gasanryu-the pretty big blue bottle) :D but heres a list of MUST-HAVES: -yooke : (Mmm..can't get enough of it.)-niku-uni: (had a nice balance..was not overwhelmed by the uni.) -squid-ink rice w/marinated sweetbread: (I regret sharing this dish cuz I wanted it all for myself. hehe) -stewed beef tendon casserole: (nice rich flavor and beef that falls apart in your mouth..slurppp!) -foie gras stuffed mini Kobe burger w/ chocolate sauce. (hellooooo chocolate..either u will love it or hate it. I loved it)-beef belly (zomg I wanted more.) -the tongue experience. (def. interesting and fun to try. 3 diff cuts. The tip,middle,back and yes they taste different.)-cheek (my favorite!!! esp dipped in the spicy ponzu sauce. Give me moreeeee!)Tip: Make sure you choose a designated timer for when you grill the meats. The server tells you how many seconds to grill each type of meat. You don't want to overcook any of it.The most adventurous dish that night,would have to be the calfs brain w/ caviar. The server recommended this dish so we were all down to try it. Why not. The smell was off putting but it didn't taste too bad. Not something I would order again. I would order more....MEAT!!!Overall, the service and the whole experience at takashi was GREAT esp. with good company. I didn't even mind smelling like BBQ all the way home. The only complaint that night came from my bfs wallet. Thanks wabe! salad night soon ;)

I finally got the chance to try one of the fabled late night ramen spots of NYC. Takashi Ramen is a weekend night only ramen spot. BBQ spot by day. Ramen by night. The menu is only available Friday and Saturday nights from 12am to 2am. Reservations are to be done the prior Monday via email starting at 5pm. Reservations were easily made, and they were very accommodating when at the last minute we added another person. In a world of 2 hour ramen waits, this was a welcome change.Takashi's decor is sleek, but with a bit a whimsy added with the multitude of chalk drawings adorning the walls educating you on the ins and outs of Japanese bbq. The space is small, and tables obviously more suited for their day job, but suitable enough for ramen service. Only complaint was that our table was definitely not big enough for our party of 6, or even our original party of 5 for that matter.Takashi's ramen is full beef broth ramen. Something I have grown a huge liking to lately. It really helps you stand out from the crowd of tonkotsu and shoyu. Add to that a piece of delicious beef belly, intestines, and Grandma's spicy paste and you now have one of my favorite bowls in the city. The only complaint I would have is that Grandma's spicy paste isn't spicy at all, but it was damn flavorful. The girlfriend also took them up on their option for some foie gras in her ramen. At an additional $14 dollars, it made for the most expensive bowl of ramen I've ever encountered. Yet she will be the first to tell you that it was worth the $30.Takashi Ramen is a place I would definitely love to frequent. The bowl definitely delivers on all counts. Just let this aging ramen obessed take his nap before the midnight seating.

The atmoshere:The place is dim lit with a tiny light overhead on each table which makes it great for intimate or small group occasions. Each table also has a cool industrial looking exhaust fan to reduce the food grease smell that gets on clothes.The service:The hostess does a really good job at responding to reservations and accommodations. Even with changes in party numbers they were quick to change but it also helps to plan things early like with most places. The waiter/waitressed are attentive to all our needs without being bothersome. The small square walking path in the restaurant makes it very easy for them to check to see if we're doing okay. They've also been very helpful in explaining the dishes and offered possible recommendations based on size of portions. The food:Their Ramen is one of the best I've had in New York. It's different from all the other ones because they use a beef based broth instead of the usual pork or chicken. To go with the beef broth, instead of the usual pork cha shu, they use their wagyu beef. It was so tender and soft with an amazing smokey fatty flavor. The noodles were a nice Al Dente chew. If you have the money for it, try the Foie Gras topping as well. There's only 2 options to go with - the regular or the grandma spicy. if you want to try the best of both, just ask them to get the hot sauce on the side and you can add it in as you eat.Their grilled food on the other had was a bit expensive. Most plates end up costing about $3-$4 for a sashimi sized slice of meat with about 4 pieces per plate. If you have the money it's great for a splurge but otherwise I think most korean / chinese bbq places does a better job in terms of quantity over quality. Overall, it's a place i find myself coming back to again and again for the Ramen. It's a little hard going because it's only offered 2 days out of the week after midnight, but for the price and the flavor, it's all addicting and worth it at the end.
Best ramen I ever had. The beef was juicy and the soup was savory. I wish they will make ramen during the day time.

great authentic Korean BBQ. Â Small place and the wait staff is friendly. Â The kimchee and Bulgogee were heavenly. Â I definitely did not leave feeling hungry....portions were huge! Â I will come back again.

I would like to be clear this review is not for the food, but for the overall experience of stepping into this establishment.We called earlier to confirm if reservations were available, although we were told that no reservation was available, the person who answered the phone also stated that walk-ins are excepted but with a significant wait time. Â Which was perfectly fine for me.So, excited to try this new place on the same day as we called (which also happened to be a special occasion) we took a LONG walk to what seemed to be the only restaurant on the otherwise empty block.Once we arrived the second after stepping through the door we saw it was very small but had no one at the front to welcome us, finally a minute+ later a man wearing lipstick approached us to inform us that they aren't taking walk-ins and that the kitchen will be closing. (we came in at around 9pm)WHY is it stated that they are open until 2am when they close the kitchen early and then reopen hours later for a "soup only" menu and WHY do they tell people they are welcome to come in at anytime when they turn you away? I fully understand that this restaurant got popular after being on the show and that for this reason reservation maybe necessary but please don't tell people they can come in and then TURN THEM AWAY AT THE DOOR acting like we are crazy for not making reservations. Â Truly disappointing.Because of this rude and indifferent lack of-service am not longer interested in trying this restaurant.

I've got mixed feelings about Takashi. They only accept reservations for groups of 4+. I arrived with my date at 7:30 and was told that it would be a 2 hour wait. Having read some reviews and finding that some folks were seated earlier, I had hope. Alas, we were seated 120 minutes later. A 2 hour wait sucks because you really aren't sure how long you'd actually wait. What if someone is a fast diner and our wait is shortened? We decided to go to a nearby bar and just wait it out. By 9:30 we were starving. If you're going to have wait times for a party of 2 upwards of 2 hours--you might as well offer reservations FOR EVERYONE. But on to the good stuff. Food was truly delicious. We ordered the very popular Niku-Uni: very flavorful and fantastic. Bone Marrow and Crawfish Dumpling: tasted like other dumplings I've had, meh. Kalbi (short rib): loved it, must try! Shio-tan (tongue): first time I've had tongue and it was a pleasant surprise! Homemade Madagascar Vanilla Ice-Cream: yummmmm, got the works with green tea syrup. An excellent balance. TL;DR: great food, very pricey, long wait. Plz offer reservations! 3.5**

Nice cozy place with table and bar seating. Â Prices are OK, but QUICKLY add up. Â Spent $300+ (before tip) for 2 people.Get the following:Bone marrow and crawfish dumplingCalf's brain cream with blinis and caviarGrandmom's steamed beef shank bunsNiku-UniThe tongue experienceKalbiRosu (Ribeye) House-Smoked Beef Pancetta, Newborn Whitebait Fish and Monkfish Liver al AjilloHouse Bresaola (Kobe Beef Prosciutto) with Blue Cheese, Hazelnut Apple Honey Soy MustardU.S. Kobe Marbled Chuck-flat Steak (6oz)Carafe of Junmai Daiginjo (just asked for it and it was good)

We made a reservation for 4 but the other 2 people cancelled. They do not let you make a reservation for just 2 people so when we got there they had a 2 HOUR wait. We didn't really want to wait 2 hours but we wanted to see what the big hype was about. While we waited we went to a bar near by and had a couple of drinks. We came back an hour and half after and sat by the bar. We ordered the umi with the beef which was good but I really don't like Umi too much. I think this is over rated. What was Amazing was the Kobe beef with foie de gras and chocolate sauce!!! Delicious!! For entree we had the beef belly and the sweet bread. You cook it yourself on the grill for about 3 mins each piece. The beef belly was very good! In the meantime we sipped on cold floral sake which was tasty and went well with the combination. I wouldn't come back for a second time but I think everyone should at least try the experience once.

Shocker! Anthony Bourdain was sooo right about this one!!Want some high quality beef? With about 20 different options ranging from run of the mill to the 4th stomach? Well, Takashi is your place. Oh wait, don't forget about the awesome atmosphere!I took my girlfriend here and we sat next to the open kitchen and I was blown away by every aspect of this restaurant. The service was top notch. The waiter was attentive and thoroughly explained the menu to us and gave us advice on some of the stranger menu items as well. Hint, the liver is an absolute must! The steamed bun appetizer is perfect for a couple to share without filling you up prior to the main entrees which you grill right in front of you! At the end of the night when I got the bill my jaw dropped after having 3 meats, 2 appetizers, and sake for $105. For a NYC restaurant I was blown away with the all around great meal for a reasonable price.
The 4 stars is because of kalbi and beef belly.Niku uni - 3 starsKalbi - 5 starsBeef belly - 4 starsTongue experience - 3 starsHeart - 3 starsSquid ink rice and miso marinated sweetbreads - 3 stars

Came here for 4-person late night ramen. Good, complex beefy, and definitely worth trying. Not a repeat for me. And the promising crunchy bits were kinda stale. Oh well.But the grilled offal is the ticket here--I'll be back for REGULAR dinner hours.

This place is the stuff of dreams. Setting is intimate (only 40 seats), but effortlessly cool. Cook your own "off cuts" (like crispy beef stomach lining) add some sides, and dig in! On weekends at midnight, they offer the BEST ramen I've ever had. You need to make reservations. A bowl of ramen and some saki will set you back about $50, but it's worth every penny.
So many meats, so little time. This is the best bbq I think I've ever had.
Best Yakiniku place in NYC. Â They have various kinds of beef stomach. Beef tongue, Â special part of beef cuts. They don't take reservation for 2 people so 1 hour wait is must for diner time.

Takashi is a great treat when it comes to enjoying luxurious cuts of beef and experiencing the cuts of organ meats. Â Keep in mind many items of the menu are an aquired taste, and the small plates and price might be a deterrent. Â If you come in hungry, get the Kobe Chuck flat steak (6 oz steak) and rice and you should be able to enjoy the other cuts of beef without worrying that you'll be hungry. Â My Favorites:Niku-Uni - How can you go wrong, Kobe slice, Fresh Uni, this dish melts in your mouth and you really have to savor it.Kalbi (Kobe Shortrib) - Amazing and buttery cut of beef, the texture was smooth and fatty, we got it marinated with Takashi sauce.The Good:Tsurami (cheek) - very flavorful, we got it with garlic and sesame oil eat bite was delicious and the texture was rough and chewy.Hatsu (Heart) - I liked this a lot, I've eaten chicken heart at some yakitori places but never tried beef heart, this comes in very small bit size bites, you place them on the grill and grill for 1 minute each, the flavor is very hearty but not striking, the texture is like a smooth paste.The service was fantastic and very friendly and attentive, we sat in front of the chefs near the entrance, we got in after a 5 minute wait and were luckily because the people behind us were quoted a 40 minute wait and the manager took their numbers to let them know when a table would be ready. At no point did we feel rushed and we were able to enjoy each part of the meal at our pace.I sat looking at the large warning sign with a silhouette of a cow on it, I didn't really get it until I saw the sign, from my experience Japanese do not eat a whole lot of beef so when they do they explore the small cuts of every part of the cow and discover the flavor of each part. Â That's what Takashi is to me, beef by nature is a luxury in japan, and Takashi takes the time and energy to translate the experience of japanese beef eating in america where beef is plenty, I learned to slowed down and enjoy the flavors and textures of each parts of the meat, it's an interesting and delicious experiment.

To celebrate some good news, we decided to grab some meat at Takashi, a place which so craftily served us some delicious beef ramen just a week or two prior. For the run down on that, scroll down to the bottom of this review, or check out The Great Noodle Chase post on my website.This time around we wanted grilled beef the whole way. No broth. No noodles. Just the protein. And that's kinda what Takashi is all the fuck about! They ONLY serve beef. No pork. No fucking chicken. BEEF. And not only that, but it's all top notch kobe quality, and they ain't afraid to serve up the nasty bits - the offal. Fuck... This place even has testicles on the menu, and they have no shame in putting the words BEEF BALLS on the fucking menu! Needless to say, this fucking place is made for guys like me.First came some small dishes of Kim chi, bean sprouts and cabbage with soy ginger dressing. Yeah, I ate it...Next was the raw sea urchin on top of a nice slice of kobe chuck flap with wasabi, shiso leaf and seaweed paper. This dish is called niku-uni. It was really clean and delicious. I could easily eat a dozen of these shits, no problem.Then came the soft beef shank steamed buns with spicy mayo and scallions. These were tender and juicy, and fucking packed with bold flavor.Then there was this awesomeness. Aged kobe prosciutto (whaaaaaat!?!!) with thinly sliced blue cheese and micro scallions, topped with a soy hazelnut honey mustard seed jam. It was earthy and robust. The characteristic aged flavors were highlighted with a nutty, funky-ass barnyard kick from the cheese. Yet it didn't destroy the pallette. Props to the chef.Then the grill heated up and the meats came out. Essentially the grill is just a heater coil element like what you have inside an electric oven. I think NYC has some shitty law that bans open flames in dining areas. So this is not technically the traditional open flame yakatori style you find in Japan, but it did fill the craving for grilled meat.All of the meats were marinated in the house special Takashi sauce, and served with a small dish of sesame oil for dipping. They could have maybe brought out some lettuce leaves to wrap the meat, or a crunch element like fried crispy onion or shallot to sprinkle on top. The meat by itself was good, but I can see how maybe some people would want to mix up the textures a little bit.Beef belly was the first plate of yum to come. Delicious. Not too chewy, not too fatty. It was cut about a quarter inch thick.We ordered the chef's selection of meats as well.Here's what came in that plate:The front left is 1st stomach (cows have 4 stomachs, morons). It was chewy, and we were warned that this would be a lot of mouth work to get through. Why even serve it this way, I wonder? Better to braise it slow and low I would think.On the front right we have beef heart. It cooked up like a very lean meat: good for a nice quick even sear.The back right is 4th stomach. This was way more tender, thicker, juicier and flavorful than 1st stomach.That's liver on the back left. This was my least favorite. It was gamey, mealy, and very irony. I guess for my taste, liver is best served in pate form.In the center are the sweetbreads. These glands were creamy and smooth. Very nice, with a great crisp.The last meat we tried were the cheeks. This was the best of them all. It was sliced thin like bacon, and they crisped up nicely on the grill. Perfect.Then we saw the table next to get the nose to tail beef platter.Fucking bastards. We asked for it when we sat but they said we needed 4 people to order. Bullshit. We definitely could have finished it all, and I wouldn't have minded paying 60pp for two instead of 30pp for four. Oh well. Maybe if there's 4 of us next time...Dessert was Madagascar vanilla soft serve ice cream, topped with soft chewy mochi balls, soy powder, sweet red beans, gold leaf and salted caramel sauce. Thankfully the sauce was served on the side. It was too bitter for our liking. The ice cream itself was great, and good with the sweet beans.Pretty solid meal. It was a little pricey, but definitely enjoyable. I'd definitely go back to try out some more shit.MIDNIGHT RAMENReal deal beef ramen DOES exist. I heard about some late night ramen joint in the west village called Takashi that serves up an all-beef broth ramen on Friday and Saturday nights only, from 12:00am to 2:00am. It was tough, but I ended up getting a seat for my wife and I to slurp up some of this delicious shit. We started with some beer and took in the surroundings:As I mentioned, it's a beef broth, but it contains crispy beef intestines, FUCKING BRAISED KOBE BEEF BELLY!!!, a soft boiled egg, and alkaline ramen noodles. The little blob of red you see in the middle is the spicy paste that my wife got with her bow

I've always enjoyed yakiniku in Japan and didn't think it was possible to get anything close to it in the states. Â I'm also pretty wary of "celebrity endorsements." Â However, I had to try this establishment after seeing my culinary rival, Anthony Bourdain (AKA, "I need a shower after seeing his sketchiness)", chow down on his pitstop tour. Â My party and I arrived without reservations (get the reference?) on a Monday night and we were shocked to find that there was actually only a 7 minute wait. Â One of the stars of our dining experience was the waitress - always efficient, always chipper, always making us feel welcome, and making, well, our day much better.Happily, as other yelpers mention, we were brought some house panchan and a pretty refreshing salad. Â I tried the niku-uni appetizer. Â Being a HUGE fan of perilla, I needed a special moment to myself when I saw that It was topped with a healthy, fatty piece of raw steak and a generous heap of uni. Â Warning - small children should stop reading about the subsequent description of mastication techniques (R) - However, when you chew all of the ingredients together, the meaty texture of the beef holds the concoction together while the beef fat melts in your mouth with the uni. Â The perilla soaks up any off-putting flavours and provides a perfume-like quality to the dish.The yakiniku wasn't shabby either - the beef belly, shio-tan, hatsu, and tsurami were amazing. Â Out of the bunch, I would have to honestly say I enjoyed the beef tongue the most. Sure, the three of us (with alcohol) dropped over $200, but you know what? Â It was totally worth it.I'll definitely be back!

Called around 11 pm for a ramen seaing and got lucky with a 1 am reservation that got bumped up to 12:30 am.Incredibly rich, flavorful broth. Pork belly was deliciously tender. Pork intestine is fried to a very crispy state, which I liked, but my friend didn't because she likes chewing on it a bit more. Still, we both thought it was great overall. Though, even after brushing my teeth, I'm still tasting garlic on my breath in the morning.

I've eaten here like 25 times, listen up - Niku-Uni is out of this world delicious. Always order more Rosu (ribeye) than anything else. Also, the beef cheek is great.Please bring back the vegetable plate, it was awesome!

We ordered the tartare appetizer, short rib (regular and kobe variants), cheek, tongue, heart, oxtail, ribeye and beef belly. Everything was delicious, particularly those dishes which our server had specifically recommended. The side of rice was perfect as well as the sauce accompaniments and kimchi. All that plus a healthy amount of sake and a few beers and the price was still entirely reasonable.Next time I'll probably stray less from the recommendations and maybe just stick to one of the pre-curated course sets. Anyway, I loved it and will hopefully be back soon.

Hands down AMAZING. My top 3... let me just say these are all a must and they all melt right into your mouth.-Niku Uni, the beef and nori compliments the dish perfectly. -Foie gras kobe beef burger was phenomenal....loved the sauce and flavor of it all-Bone marrow & crawfish dumplings-Interesting but sooo good!!Had a bunch of other items to cook on the grill and they were all good. I'm a fan of this place, just don't bother with the testicargot.
Food quality is great; the prices are not. There are better options in the city. Drinks are overpriced.
Niku-Uni is soooo good! Niku is super fresh and Uni is creamy. Wanna try the midnight ramen next time.

Seriously delicious. Came in last night at 1045 and sat down right away which I didn't expect to happen. The scallion and seaweed salad was crunchy, fresh and delicious and the beef was cut perfectly and was beyond good. I think my favorite thing was the 'between the rib' cut YUM. Love this place definitely coming back to try the ramen.

The midnight ramen was amazing. I got the grandma's special spicy ramen, and opt to have the spicy sauce paste on the side in case it was very spicy. The beef was very tender, and the soup was warm and tasty. Would definitely go back to try out their japanese BBQ and other dishes on their menu.
Best ramen in NYC, hands down. They only have it on the weekends after 11 or midnight (hence "midnight ramen"), but it puts Ippudo and Toto Ramen to shame.

Food is absolutely divine and 5 star worthy but the manager who runs the place lacks class and should not have the responsibility of running this establishment. After waiting an hour for a table we received a call to come back only to find that our table was given away. When we were obviously disappointed, nothing was done. We were given no option only to sit and wait another 30 min for the next table. A simple "so sorry about that, how about a drink on us while you wait" Would have sufficed. My boyfriend and I have been here 3 times before and spent upwards of $300 and they can afford to lose customers like us because Â of their numbers- regardless of treatment.This is a perfect example of a Resturant that is doing very well because they serve a great product but their ego ultimately Â destroys the joy of eating there.Go here is you want good food and to be treated poorly.

Takashi is my new favorite restaurant in NY. It's absolutely amazing for those of you who are looking for something adventurous and off the beaten path. It's also a super fun date spot if you're looking to impress a foodie who has tried it all. Who would have though that raw meat would be so decadent and addicting...?Here's what I usually get:RAW: Niku-Uni - uni (sea urchin) on top of raw chuck, shiso leaf, and seaweed. This is probably one of the most amazing things I've ever eaten. I actually insisted on ordering two orders last time I was here. I think it would be on the short list of things that I'd want to eat if I only had one more meal on earth. Yooke - thinly-sliced chuck eye tartare with raw quail egg yoke. The waiter pours out the egg yoke from the tiny little speckled shell and mixes it into the tartare, The first time I tried this, I was a bit skeptical. Despite the beautiful presentation, it looked a bit like little mound of ground beef with a tiny egg on top. My skepticism was disarmed at first bite and now I order it every time I'm back. Delicious! GRILLED:Horumon-Moriawase (chef's selection) - if you want to try unusual cuts, go with this. It typically comes with sweetbread, liver, heart, and two types of stomach. My favorite was the heart because it was super tender with the sweetbread in a close second. The only thing that I wasn't crazy about was one of the stomachs because it was too rubbery. Definitely ask the server how long each cut should be cooked because that will have a large impact on how it tastes. They're happy to cook it for you as well. SAKE:Hakkaisan from Niigota - dry, crisp, and delicious. When you order sake, they bring out a tray of all different cute little cups for you to choose from.

Another place with a great potential ruined by a visit of Antony Bourdain.I was here on my b.day with my lovely girlfriend. I had a good time, and did taste some interesting and delicious things. But it was too overpriced for what you get.We had the bone marrow and crawfish dumplings. ATTENTION: you get 2 dumplings for $16, and you can't even taste the bone marrow.Testicargot: kinda tough, unfortunately.Foie gras stuffed mini Kobe burger w chocolate sauce: Here you get ONE for $20. Truly delicious, but quite small.Yooke (chuck eye tartare w quail egg): delicious, but, again, $16 for a bite or so.Niku-uni (sea urchin): #4 for $24, not to die for, way overpriced.Horumon-Moriawase (chef's selection: first stomach, fourth stomach, heart, liver and sweetbreads): #15 microscopic pieces for $28, meat kinda tough, very underwhelming.Super small portions. Super overpriced. Super rushed. As soon as u empty a dish they're on you. They keep pushing u to order and eat your food as soon as possible. They bring many dishes at the same time, which, for the price u pay, they should give u the time to taste them.Supermarket feel. Never ever again.

The food was just average quality and you have to cook it yourself. The waiter did not change our grill and claimed that the less expensive appetizer was not available even though I saw it arced to other customers. The restaurant is overpriced and not worth it.

Absolutely amazing! I have been here twice (wish I lived closer so that I can go more often). Â It is not for the faint of heart though. Â However there are things on the menu that everyone can try. Â It's a fun atmosphere where you get to cook your own food. Â Could be a perfect spot for a first date or just some friends catching up. Â The ability to order as much as you want and try a few different things is so perfect. Â You can always add more once you are done with your first order if you are still hungry which I like.Some of my favorite dishes: 1. Testicargot (cow balls escargot style with garlic shiso butter)2. Kalbi (short rib)3. Mino (first stomach)4. Home-made Madagascar Vanilla Â - it comes with a gold leaf! What girl wouldn't want that. One item I was not a fan of is Calf's Brain Cream (in tube) with Blinis & Caviar. Â The presentation was perfect and Caviar was delicious. Â The only thing that bothered me is the brain in a tube that I had to squeeze out. Â I would have preferred it be chucky and in it's simple form. Review by SassyNatty

We came here for the midnight ramen menu and ordered the Grandma's Spicy Ramen. The beef broth was hearty, spicy, garlic-ky and delicious. A lot of good flavors - love the ramen and the soft-boiled egg. This is some good ramen! I was so full and satisfied. This will be a quick midnight meal with great service. Will come back to try their dinner menu.

My friend from college visiting from Boston insisted on doing Bourdaine's layover tour... He wanted to hit all the same spots in a weekend. Top on the list was Takashi. While, I wasn't exactly excited to do the layover tour, I was intrigued by Takashi...I called at 5:30 when they opened and was told there were not any reservations available until 11:00 PM. we decided to go the walk in route. We arrived at 7:30 and put in our names and were told we had about a 90 minute wait. We left, went to Little Branch for a few drinks and came back about 9:00. We were seated at about 9:45, but it was well worth the wait!The Kobe meat ball and the short rib bun special were both great. We also had 4 meats on the BBQ:Sweetbreads - best I've ever hadCheek - YUMMBelly - my favoriteAngus - very good...I've had Korean BBQ many times, but for some reason, this was just better. I loved this meal.

As soon as I walked in, the smell of delicious food immediately hit me! Â The hostess estimates a 30 min wait... Which turned out to only be 20. My friend was running late and they were still kind enough to hold our table! Our waiter was extremely knowledgable and checked up on us several times (I think he also may have been the manager). The woman cleaning up the plates was adorable!!We got the:- Â Bone marrow and crawfish dumpling --Out of this world. And the presentation is so fun!- Â Beef belly -- So tender and flavorful. - Â Cow heart -- Â Not bad... But wouldn't get it again. Was more for the experience...- Â Steamed beef shank buns - I want to eat this everyday. - Â Beef tartare with quail egg - Amazing.

My brother was visiting me from our home country and since New York is near where I go to school, we decided to tour New York. I came to Takashi for the ramen before during the Christmas period of 2014 and it was damn good so I thought i'd bring my brother for a memorable unique ramen experience. I made a reservation and even received email confirmation. When I got there, I wasn't on the list. But no matter, the really sweet guy at the door asked me to show him the email. He immediately apologised for his colleague's oversight and promised us seats. So without a hitch, we got seated - no fuss at all. Everything is still all smiles and rainbows. Within 3 minutes of being seated, we ordered. So we weren't being long-winded whiny people who can't decide - anyway there's only like what, normal and spicy and then extra toppings.This is where I can't give the 5-star raiting. We waited 30 minutes for our food. The table next to us got their food WAY BEFORE us. They ordered later than us. The cherry on the cake was that the table next to us finished their meal before we got ours.My experience the first time in the winter left such an impression that I had to bring my brother. But 8 months later, I get treated badly. TLDR: Table next to us orders after us and finishes their meal before we get ours. Ramen was damn good. Noodles were well-cooked and the broth is to die for. The pork cut was tender and fatty - super awesome to have that fat melt in your mouth. My brother loved the ramen so much he couldnt stop telling the parents about it. They say they would like to visit the place when they come for my graduation. I will veto that suggestion when the time comes.

Man if you love beef, you will love Takashi. The Miyazaki A5 Wagyu is the finest in the world and even better than Kobe beef. It was delicious and so was the Wagyu filet mignon with the garlic butter dipping sauce. Everything was good and the Nika-Uni was delicious too and I dont even really like Uni. We came back the same night for late night Ramen, which they only serve after midnight I believe, and it is a beef based broth. Very flavorful and tasty as well and good to combat the cold weather in NYC. Must try place in NYC

This place makes me happy that I'm a carnivore. A friend and I wandered in around 530 and were promptly seated at one of the 3 open bar seats that don't require reservations. The other table grills requierd a minimum of 4 and were atleast 1.5 to 2 hr waits because those are the time limits imposed on the spots. I ate so much raw meat it was amazing. For appetizers we ordered the crawfish and marrow dumplings. These were delicious and meaty, but not dumplings at all. I would have to say that they were more like delicious meatballs. But... I didn't taste any crawfish. It was marrow, meat, and love magic in my mouth. I mean that in the best way possible.We also had the beef tartare, this was less mashed meat and more strips of raw meat with some seaweed and a quail egg mixed in. Who know raw meat could be this delicious? I didn't, but now I do.Also, the Uni on squares of raw beef. Delicious. That's all I can say about it. Fresh Uni and awesome meat on a square sheet of seaweed.The beef cheek was good. Nothing special, but delicous.The 6 oz. Kobe beef for $30 bucks. It was cooked amazingly by the server. It was fatty and delicious and cooked a nice rare bloody tone. The sesame oil style dipping sauce was perfect for this.I love this place. So delicious. Best BBQ ever.

I take clients out to dinner several nights a week. The restaurant had terrible service. Â I wish I could give a negative star. The staff was arrogant and what they forgot to tell me was the tip was included with the bill. Â I glanced at the bill because I was having an important conversation with a top client and didn't catch it. Â I ended up leaving an additional 20%. I noticed the following morning and immediately called the restaurant. Â They said they would reverse the charge. Â They never did and when I followed up again they said I signed the bill and they would not refund me. Poor service is the reason why most things fail. Â Last week alone I hosted three dinners over $2500 total. Several of my clients recommend eating here and I enjoy sharing my story! Â Then they have me make the recommendation! Â Hope it was worth the $73.80 service charge you didn't refund me back!
One of the greatest Japanese BBQ I have been to. Make sure you get the bon marrow dumplings and beef tongue!

Came here tonight with my friend around 930pm. Â It was a busy night and We were told to come back around 1015pm. When we retuned at 1015pm, we were told we had to wait longer since manager' circle of friends drop by and we were bumped back to the waiting list. After 11pm, we were still waiting for a table and we asked to speak to the manager. Â The manager were not apologetic at all. Â In fact, he gave us the attitude that we should thank him for not cutting us out. We were finally seated around 1115pm. Â In my opinion, the food was average at best. Â Worth the wait and the attitude from manager? Â Definitely NOT!

Bad service. Unprofessional. Expensive. The food was ok but not worth your money. We had a reservation for 6 people at 10:30pm. As we got sitted, after 20 minutes wait, the waiterress told us we have 10 minutes to order everything because the kitchen is about to close. Why do they let 10:30 reservations if they close the kitchen so early?? We asked the waiteress for her recommendations to make things faster and then we realized that one of her recommendations was an appetizer with two small buns. Obviously cannot be shared among 6 people. So we removed this one and confirmed with her that the other recommendations were good for six people. As we got the food we realized that nothing could be shared. One of the appetizers for example was a single small bite size meatball. All good if we could order more food but the kitchen was already closed. Same happened with the meat orders. We ordered 4 plates by her recommendations and it definitely wasn't enough. We ended up hungry, disappointed with $120 bill per couple. Definitely was not the Korean BBQ experience we had expected.

I haven't left a review in a long time, but I had such a great experience here that I had to. Our server Lisa was amazing! So friendly and helpful. Some of the best service I've ever had. We originally came in looking for ramen, but she explained to us that they only have ramen on Friday and Saturday nights at 12am and 1am. Â She said it happens all the time that people come in looking for ramen. She told us about a ramen place around the corner if we didn't want to stay, but we ended up staying, and I'm so glad we did. Their food is delicious, and you grill it right in front of you. We had the special filet with garlic butter sauce (so delicious), oxtail, and rib. Note that it's meat heavy - there are very few vegetarian options. I highly recommend!!

I love the brain!! It was super delicious! Also the sea urchin is absolutely amazing! The brain is my favorite in NYC so far!!! Now I have sympathy to zombies. They love brains for a very good reason :)

Came here for the late night ramen and I was pleasantly surprised. I'm not sure what I was expecting but what they offered was 10x better than any ramen I could've hoped for. I don't have much experience with ramen in Manhattan so I can't compare this to anything but it really was delicious. There's only two options on the menu- spicy or original. The beef belly was so tender. I wish it came with more! (Which you can add for an extra 5$). And they give you each a piece of Wrigley's gum with the check which is a nice touch so you don't have to have ramen breath all night. I can't find anything to complain about so I'm giving 5 stars! Nice staff and good food, their late night ramen is definitely worth a try.
The food was awesome!! But it didnt fill me up, though I wasn't expecting it to. Our server was really helpful and super cute.

Verdict: Think you know beef? Wait until you try this!I am biding my time to make plans that include their late night ramen. Until then, I have to settle for some of the best beef you can find. This is no porterhouse place, but rather a spot to savor beef in its purest form. You control a lot once you've made it through the entrance; what cuts, the temperature, the seasoning, the texture.For casual beef fans, you may have to lean on the waiters for recommendations. Try those out, and make it a point to go back and try some of the more adventurous cuts once you've made your decision on whether you like the experience or not. It's a very hands on eating experience, but well worth the effort.

They do not take reservations for 2 people, so show up early! My good friend Danny got here early Tuesday night, and there were seats available from the 6:30-7:30 time frame. Around 8pm, we overheard the waitress telling people it is an hour wait.Let's jump right into the food...Fabulous:Chuck Flap with Uni - so delicious, we got two orders. Must try!!Kobe beef - melt in your mouth deliciousness. Â This is why I am glad I eat beef again.Decent:Beef belly - it was good, but it followed the kobe so...kobe just wins. Â Kobe Meatball stuffed with foie gras and chocolate bbq sauce - it was good, but there was a lot going on here... Almost wished it was either just the chocolate bbq sauce or just the foie gras.Meh:Beef Tongue experience - I've had tongue before, and I don't see what the big deal about this is. Â Maybe just shock value??I'm giving it 4 stars because I liked the uni and kobe a lot, but this is more of a 3.5.I'm also rounding up because I liked our waitress! She was really nice and she had awesome hair. Can we be friends?

Amazing food. Great service. Ordered: Uni on chick flap meat with shiso leaf, seaweed, freshly grated wasabi, with housemade soy for a little dipping. WOW. Extremely fresh and flavors were absolutely perfect together. Ordered this as an appetizer and enjoyed it so much we ordered another when it was time for dessert. Also had Kobe meatball stuffed with foie gras, topped with chocolate barbecue sauce with a quail egg on the side. Again, WOW. Ground beef belly and kalbi. Delicious. Kimchi and bean sprouts were good as well. Even the white rice was made perfectly. I will definitely return when I come back to NY, and will try the more adventurous dishes.

I came here with really high expectations. Arrived around 7pm on a Thursday and the wait was about an hour long. That's fine, my friend and I just stopped by a bar near by for the meantime.  The only things I like about this restaurant is the Niku-Uni..it is delicious. I also liked how they let you choose your own cup for your drinks. other than that...the food is just ok.

This place is special - I am excited to write a review about it. Takashi is a total culinary experience. They nailed it. This goes without saying but I'll say it anyway - don't come here if you aren't an adventurous eater or at least a person who appreciates the experiential aspect of dining - e.g. if you don't like the idea of "cooking your own food". Come early during the week & you will have a shorter wait if you don't have a reservation. Ambiance is intimate & trendy. It's a sexy little spot for a date or to go with a group of friends. The service was awesome - our server was a total doll. She was very attentive & made excellent suggestions. Standouts: to start the soft-boiled egg cocotte as well as the bone marrow & crawfish dumplings are both SO SO GOOD. For the BBQ, the beef belly & short ribs were our personal faves. The sauce was super tasty. We also really enjoyed the homemade ice cream to finish. If you aren't a seasoned pro, definitely ask your server for sake recommendations with your meal - we tried different pairings that were indeed very complimentary to the food.Also, sidebar: they have a suped up toto toilet in the bathroom... Â If you don't know what that is, it's basically the rolls royce of toilets, which may seem insignificant until you use the restroom & realize even THAT was extra pleasant.

Once upon a time, I saw Anthony Bourdain on TV, eating uni-covered meat at Takashi. I don't always insist on doing whatever's done on TV, but I knew that one day, that niku uni would be mine. I finally met this destiny on a recent trip to New York, when I went for a Friday night dinner with my mom and two friends.We made a reservation for four people, the smallest table you're allowed to reserve. The walk-in line was pretty deep the entire time we were eating. Takashi is a cute place, small and casual with a festive izakaya air. We were helped by a friendly waiter who was really enthusiastic about intestines. The menu had a lot of unfamiliar items, and he was a great guide.Chef Takashi is ethnically Korean, born and raised in Japan (and, incidentally, looks like this: metro.us/wp-content/uploâ¦). His food reflects that heritage--it's Korean barbecue with a Japanese presentation, with a gutsy focus on innards. The more prepared dishes show a flair you'll never see in a traditional Korean barbecue joint. You can get things like brain cream and testicargot, which is exactly what it sounds like.A couple of our party were not feeling super adventurous, and I was happy sticking to the safe stuff. I've had some organs in my life and I can take or leave most of them. We shared some appetizers and a whole lot of meat, and all left full and happy.The niku-uni was an appetizer, and it came with four portions of uni over raw beef over shiso over nori. I'm not sure why I don't see uni with beef all over the place. The creamy brine of the sea urchin went beautifully with the beef, and the fragrant shiso and salty seaweed were pleasant as well. I wanted another order, but we did have more things to eat. The other standout appetizer was the yooke, Takashi's version of Korean steak tartare, made with thinly sliced chuck eye. It was cool and zesty, the beef silky and bound with quail egg. We also shared the gyutoro-temaki sushi, which was chuck flap "sushi," essentially slices of beef over large mounds of rice. This wasn't bad, but the beef got lost in all that rice. The soft-boiled egg en cocotte was sort of the odd man out in our meal--it could have walked in from an entirely different restaurant. It was pretty good, if small and hard to share, a loose boiled egg topped with tiny bits of beef pancetta, caviar, blue crab, pear, smoked dried tomato, pickled new ginger, cucumber, and yuzu zest.The bulk of our meal came from the grill, just plenty of beef, beef, and beef. We ordered kalbi, ribeye, and beef belly, along with some large intestines. We had a choice of preparations for each order: either seasoned with salt, garlic, and sesame oil, or marinated in Takashi's sauce, which was sweet and soy saucey like you'd expect from a yakiniku marinade. We mixed and matched, and everything was delicious. We were on our own for a lot of the grilling, but our waiter gave us detailed instructions and we were able to cook everything up without mistakes. It helped to have a mom at the table. All the cuts were excellent, but I have to say, the large intestines, or tetchan, were the winner for me. Our waiter recommended the tetchan as a universally beloved innard, different from the rest of what we were eating without being off-putting. He was right. The tetchan was chewy in the best way possible, elastic and yielding, with a mild, wonderful flavor, with the marinade caramelized by the grill. If I make it back to Takashi, I'd love to explore some of the other organ meats. The intestines made me feel like I was ready.We ate our meat with some rice, mostly an order of bakudan, which was basically onigiri studded with Korean seaweed and pickled sesame leaf. Kind of horrendous that it cost $8. White rice should do the trick fine.For dessert, Takashi serves homemade Madagascar vanilla soft serve ice cream with several choices of toppings. We ordered two of these with the works--shiratama (white mochi balls), kurogoma kinako (black sesame and soybean flower), azuki (red beans), and syrup (syrup). We got one with green tea and one with strawberry syrup. The soft serve was fantastic--I would go to a dessert shop that only served this ice cream. It was the perfect consistency, with the right amount of sweetness, and the toppings were delightful.I understand that Takashi does a late night ramen, which is just coolness overkill. I don't spend too much time envying New York, but I'd probably trade something big to get Takashi to move to L.A.

My husband and I are in the city for the night and he has been wanting to come here for a very long time. We got to the restaurant early because they don't take reservations with parties with less than 4 people. When the doors opened promptly at 5:30, we were greeted with friendly smiles and we were seated quickly. The restaurant is quite small that seats approximately 35 people so you need to get there early. The decor was unique and very interesting. The menu board on the wall goes around 3/4 of the restaurant and the tables were similar to picnic tables with a small grill in the middle of it. Hanging from the ceiling was a black vent to catch the smoke from grilling. The noise level was very minimal and I never even noticed it on. Our waitress came to our table quickly and introduced herself. She explained the menu to us and made suggestions on some dishes since it was our first time there. She was very knowledgable and described all the dishes when they were brought out to the table. Â We ordered many of the specials to share: Soft-boiled eggs en Cocotte, Bone marrow & crawfish dumplings, Calf's Brain Cream - one of our favorite dishes, Testicargot (cow balls escargot style w/garlic shiso butter). It was slightly chewy but an interesting dish. Raw:Namagimo (liver w/sesame oil & roasted rock salt)Niku-Uni (chuck flap w/sea urchin and fresh wasabi)Grilled: You cook! Kalbi (Short Rib) Beef Belly - our favorite, it was so tender and so delicious! Make sure to squeeze a little lemon juice on top to give it some added flavor! Chef's choice - 1st & 2nd stomach, Kimo (liver), Hatsu (heart) and Shibire (Sweetbreads) I tried their Japanese plum wine, which was a bit sweet so I had it with some ice to dilute it. We also tried a craft brew beer to compliment our meal. Dessert to top off our dinner: Home-made Madagascar Vanilla soft serve ice cream with a piece of honey comb laid on top. We had a choice of various toppings and syrups. Â Most restaurants have after dinner mints, well this restaurant offers you Wrigley's chewing gum to refreshen your breath! I thought it was great and it went with the uniqueness of the restaurant. We would definitely like to go back for another fun and exciting dining experience, but the restaurant is a little pricey and not for you if you're on a budget. You'll have to be somewhat adventurous and open minded to try different parts of the cow not commonly eaten.

Do yourself a favor and email Takashi to participate in their Friday/Saturday midnight broth. You usually have to make a reservation the Monday of the week you want to attend, but it is definitely worth it. You only have two choices of Regular or Spicy when you arrive late night, but both are excellent. I had the regular broth that had the perfect pairing of ingredients resulting in a combination of flavors that every ramen lover will appreciate. There are a ton of bars in the area around Takashi and I found it to be a perfect break in my night out with friends. I would definitely recommend it for anyone looking to get some late night ramen and I will be returning very soon for another delicious bowl.

Personally, I really give 3.5 stars if I could. I went to Takashi for my birthday night out last week. Â Since they don't take reservation for group smaller than 4, I invited other couple, so I could make reservation. Â It was good idea. I get there 6:15 and I over heard waiting was 3 hours.... I had high expectation Â I guess because I read Takashi's blog and expected to be top notch because of this high pricing. We had hard time deciding... But I ordered, Namagimo (ultra-fresh liver with sesame oil and roasted rock salt) to start. No one except me in my party were Â interested in NAMA (Raw meat) so I went for basic. I kind of missed to have this dish. It's so simple but it must be fresh. I wish I could have ordered NIku-Uni,but I am not a big fan of Uni. So I did this instead. It was good, but it was buried with scallion and soaked in sesame oil...It is nothing wrong with Raw liver. It should taste sweet and shouldn't be iron taste like cooked liver. Â It didn't impressed me. But they were fine slice of liver.Then, my friend was interested in "Soft-Boiled Egg en Cocotte" So we ordered.This tiny dish was $16I was not sure why dish was frozen. Menu didn't say anything about it. Just said "Soft-Boiled Free-range Egg en Cocotte Topped with House-Made Beef Pancetta, Caviar, Blue Crab Meat, Pear, Smoked Dried Tomato, Pickled New Ginger, Cucumber, and Yuzu Zest" It was disappointing. because it was frozen. Soft-boiled was VERY HARD FROZEN Egg. It must have been a joke??? I didn't get that. Sorbet style??? Â It was tasty but kind of yucky. Grandmom's Steamed Beef Shank Buns with Spicy Mayo (2 pieces) $16.You know, they charged us $16 for this appetizer. I don't mind price being $16, but I was a bit disappointed that they made it self-serve. They brought out hot buns in the steamer and meat in small bowl. When I picked up buns, it was quite HOT. I mean,.. burning HOT. This restaurant doesn't give us wet towel like normal Japanese restaurant and all of the sudden, we have to use own hands to create buns? Â WITH THIS PRICING? I wish restaurant should prepare them and bring out to the table or waiter/waitress should prepare buns at the table. You know, just a little bit of consideration, maybe??? Well, Â buns were really yummy, though! Foie Gras Stuffed Mini Kobe Burger with Chocolate BBQ Sauceã$24It is tiny. Yes, it is very tasty. But I don't know if it is worth $24. Bone Marrow and Crawfish Dumplings with Hong Kong-Style Hot Peanut Oil Sauceã$16 Â (2 piece per order, so we ordered 2)This was pretty good dumplings. Again, portion is very small. They are yummy. Presentation was amazing. Bring out boiling peanut oil and pour over at the table. We ordered Kobe Beef Kalbi $26 It came with 7 slices on one plate, so I ordered another one. They are really good. Melt in the mouth... Shio-Tan (tongue) I had better tongue and it was not the best, but I say it was pretty good. I think Cuts are a little too thick for me. I want to have simple salt and sesame oil ROSE (RIB EYE) was a little tough. My boyfriend ordered Shibire (sweetbreads) I enjoyed, I was totally distracted by Kobe Beef Kalbi on the menu, I forgot to order Harami.Overall, quality of meats are outstanding. But portion are VERY small! After that, we had Home-made Madagascar Vanilla Â softserve ice cream This was really good ice cream :) Service is very attentive and I do not have any complain with our sweet waitress. Our dinner took about 2 hours. We ordered a bottle of red wine, three glasses of white wine, two beer and above all.... about $400 + Tip. Overall, appetizers were very creative. But I think they are not worth to be that high price. If I ever go back, I will only stick to NAMAMONO and BBQ. Atmosphere is totally Japanese Style Yakiniku, it was NOT Korean BBQ - I love that. But I have to ask myself one more time, "does it worth it?" Well, I may give another try (for Namamono & BBQ) ... but I don't know If my boyfriend want to spend money on ridiculously over priced meat again. Don't get me wrong, food is excellent here (except Egg) But I don't think it's worth it. Â . Â Well, yeah, this place was Anthony Bourdain's must go place in NYC... but I don't think you will be missing out so much.... Â Well, if money is no issue. Then, this is the place for you! Next time, I want to try RAMEN after midnight.....

Takashi is cute and cozyJapanese BBQ place in West Village. Takashi specialized high quolity beef BBQ. We sitted down at counter seat and watch chef prepare our meat and after we cooked 30 secounds each side of beef by ourself which like a they suggested. I had two great appetizer. Niku-uni was great combination of Uni and beef sashimi, shiso leaf and dry agi-seaweed. Yooke we had was great too. Â (^_^) YayOverall - Â 4Food - Â 3.5Atmosphere - Â 3.5Price - $$$1/2

This place is awesome! I learned about it by watching an Anthony Bourdain show as he could not get enough of it. He's a meat whore, so it's definitely a place if you like grilling your own cuts of top choice beef. Including everything from filet, heart, sweetbreads, pork belly, etc. The item I liked most however were the pork buns which were out of this world! The BEST buns I have EVER had. They melt in your mouth and are not dense at all. I only gave it 4 stars because the wait was 2 hours long. However, the bar across the street was a great hole in the wall while we waited, and was definitely worth it! Definitely you should check it out!P.S. Can't take reservations for 4 or less...

AMAZING. Super yummy yakiniku place, definitely one of the best around. The meat is good quality, but what makes Takashi alot better than other yakiniku places is that the appetizers are so good! You have to order Niku-uni and the Yooke if you come here since they are fantastic. The soft serve is also great and on Friday-Saturday they do midnight ramen which is really really flavorful since they use beef broth (order the spicy one if you can handle it).

Came here for dinner on Sunday evening. 3rd time for yakiniku. Been here twice for their ramen too (which is amazing!)Takashi is one of the best yakiniku places in the city, with prices to match! It's difficult to get full here for anything less than $100 though. Had the niku uni, kalbi, misuji and super thick tongue. Kalbi was the best! I think the tongue was too thick, maybe I would go for the shio tan next time.Great food, prices could be slightly more reasonable but this is one of the best places for Japanese style yakiniku in the city.

This is a review for the late night ramen. Â Takashi does a somewhat of a different spin on ramen, as it is a beef broth. Â Think bowl of Pho at a Vietnamese restaurant done well, except with ramen noodles in it instead...and very garlicky. Â Which I was kind of torn about. Â I generally like garlic, but there was a lot, and it kind of took something away from the broth. Â It's kind of like wrapping scallop with bacon; sure, it won't taste bad, but was it good scallop?Anyway, it's definitely worth a try if you've never been, just for the sake of something different.
This review is for the ramen. Â Very delicious and flavorful! Â The spicy paste isn't spicy at all. Â Service is great! Â Will come back for the bbq.

This is my favorite restaurant in the city! A super unique experience for adventurous eaters. The mega rib is a must and the meat couldn't be any more fresh. Great for entertaining seasoned New Yorkers and tourists alike!

Midnight ramen! I made a reservation two days before the midnight Friday seating. I wasn't expecting to beat back but fortunately they came back with a confirmation.The three of us showed up at 12am, hungry and ready to stuff our faces. The restaurant was buzzing and we had to wait for 10 minutes before we were seated. Between the three of us, we ordered: 1 original with foie gras sensation, 1 spicy and 1 original. The broth is salty, greasy, flavorful, garlicky and full of scallions and crispy beef intestines. I love it!If you're getting the spicy version, be sure to mix it thoroughly. I ate half a bowl before realizing it had to be mixed. The Grandma's spicy ramen was the original with additional chili flakes or togarashi spices. The foie gras pieces did not add much to the ramen in my opinion. If they ever open up a dedicated ramen restaurant, I will definitely visit. Not sure if I will ever do the whole midnight thing again.

I LOVE THIS PLACE, meat lover's paradise! 5 STARS. There is always a wait, so try to make plans in advance.Foie Gras stuffed mini kobe burger with choclate sauce sounds like a strange combo, but it's really good.Must try their Uni & wagyu chuck ontop of shiso leaf. Â Perfect combo of flavors. My fave meats: tounge, short rib, and chuck flap (hand grated fresh wasabi is the perfect compliment).They have really good dessert as well, try their Madagascar soft serve ice cream with mochi.My friends and I felt like we ate a whole cow! Tip: They only take reservations of 4 or more. You can make reservations online. It's a BBQ place, so your clothes will most likely smell afterwards.

Out of 200 reviews, this is my 3rd 1 star review. I've previously loved this place for their food, and the service during my last visit was absolutely spot on. but the staff I met today ruined everything.I reserved for 4 people at 8pm. 2 of us were on time, the other 2 were late. The maÃ®tre d or whoever you want to call her, told us it's policy to wait for the full party to arrive. Fair enough, so we waited. Our 3rd guest arrived and the final guest was going to be late, so we just told them to seat us for 3. The response was definitely unexpected. She told us, "it's not our policy to sit 3 people for a reservation, and you would probably have to wait 2.5 hours for a table, but we will let you guys sit anyways...we don't take reservations for 3 people. Please wait." That was fair enough, so we waited.5 minutes later, 2 people arrived and she leads them to the only open table available, which I thought would be ours because we came first. I thought there must be a reason for that, and didn't say anything. 5 minutes later, a 3rd person arrives and joins their table. Confused, I asked her why did she seat them when their full party didn't arrive? She answered "because your party isn't here. we are letting you guys use the reservation even though you have 3 people. Your wait would have been 2.5 hours otherwise." that made no sense to me because I asked her why the guests that came later then us got to sit before us when their full party wasn't present. so I asked her again, and her reply was "oh, they know the manager, and they come here twice a week."her response ticked me off, but we waited. that party knew the managers - who am I to take their table. 8:25PM and we were still waiting for our table that was supposed to be available at 8PM. So i asked the maÃ®tre d, when is our table going to be ready?She replied, since you're party isn't here yet, you have to wait longer. I admittedly got a little angry, and I asked her, "okay, so hypothetically, if all 4 of us were here, at 8PM, would you have sat us down?"She replied "oh...no because the table we had reserved for you - they're still paying the bill."See what's going on here? The whole time she was just trying to justify us waiting by making us look bad because 1 of our guests came late...but the whole time, they had no table available at 8PM, but made us believe we were waiting 30 minutes because one of our guests was late.I know it's not her fault that the earlier guests finished their meal later, but at least explain the situation instead of trying to make it seem like she was doing us a favor.We finally got seated, and we wanted to order right away. We tried to grab the attention of the waiters/servers (couldn't tell who was who), but they told us to wait.During the meal, we also didn't have a waitress or waiter. Each time the food came out, someone different brought it. And none of them interacted with us.all in all, I was so dissatisfied with the service, we gave them a low tip. that may be cheap of me, but I don't understand this concept of tipping in the US. The amount of tip should correlate to the service you receive. We came out of the restaurant, and shortly after, the manager stormed out and demanded an answer to why we gave them a low tip. I told them, your maÃ®tre d gave us attitude and made us wait 30 minutes for a table we reserved for 8PM. we waited 15 minutes until someone took our order. no waiter asked us how the food was or bothered to check in with us. we didn't even know who to tip because we interacted with so many servers. that's why.the manager snapped back, alright if that's what you want to give, go ahead. and walked back into the restaurant. why even ask me why I tipped you in the first place if you're just going to head back inside. Did he want more tip from me? Usually at a restaurant, if the service was bad, the manager at least tries to understand what happened. by all means, the customer isn't always right. but when a customer is clearly upset, there's usually a good reason behind it. /rant

Honestly, I would give this place 1 star, but the Niku-Uni alone is worth a star. This is definitely not your average dining experience.I came here with a friend on a Friday night around 8pm, and since Takashi doesn't take reservations for parties less than 4, it ended up being a 2 hour wait. The hostess recommended 2 wine bars closeby for my friend and I to grab drinks at while we waited. The space is very small, with an area in the middle where two chefs prepare the cuts of offal taking most of the space.
